Summary Abstract: Sukayna bint al-Husayn (Sakina; born 47–51 AH/c. 667–671 CE) was the daughter of Husayn ibn Ali and Rubab bint Imra al-Qais, a great-granddaughter of the Prophet Muhammad. As a child she witnessed the Battle of Karbala (680) and, with the surviving women and children, was taken captive and paraded and imprisoned in Damascus before being released. Sources record an early, likely unconsummated marriage to her cousin Abd-Allah ibn Hasan (killed at Karbala), with some later accounts adding marriages to Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr and others; she is noted in early literature for eloquence, patronage of poets, and transmission of hadith. Most reports place her death in Medina on 5 Rabi' al-Awwal 117 AH (8 April 735), with her burial in al-Baqi.

Summary Abstract: The Gathas are 17 hymns in archaic Avestan that constitute the oldest core of the Avesta, traditionally attributed to the prophet Zoroaster and commonly dated to around 1000 BCE. Through these linked narratives, the book depicts emigrants navigating the gap between their aspirations and lived realities in a postcolonial world.

Summary Abstract: Abdellatif Laâbi’s autobiographical novel recounts his childhood in Fez in the 1950s as Morocco moves toward independence from French colonial rule. Summary Abstract: An interpretive survey of the Maghreb—primarily Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia—from antiquity to the mid-20th century, the book proposes a unified framework for the region’s long-term historical development. Laroui analyzes political authority and social formations—including the makhzen, tribal organization, nomad–sedentary relations, and urban networks—in relation to economic change, Islamization and Arabization, and interactions with Roman, Arab-Islamic, Ottoman, and European powers. He reassesses nationalist and colonial historiographies and advances a periodization grounded in modes of production and shifts in sovereignty culminating in colonial rule and the emergence of modern nation-states.

Summary Abstract: Maxwell Staniforth’s Penguin Classics translation (first published 1968) collects foundational writings of the Apostolic Fathers from the late first and second centuries. Title of Work: The Didache (Teachings of the Twelve Apostles)
Title of Work (AI check): The Lord’s Teaching Through the Twelve Apostles to the Nations (Διδαχὴ Κυρίου διὰ τῶν δώδεκα ἀποστόλων τοῖς ἔθνεσιν)
Summary Abstract: An early Christian manual dated around 90 CE, the Didache provides instruction on ethical living via the “Two Ways” (life and death), communal discipline, and church order. It outlines rites such as baptism (preferably in living water), distinct fasting days, set prayers including the Lord’s Prayer thrice daily, and formulas for the Eucharist. It offers criteria for receiving itinerant apostles and prophets, distinguishing true from false teachers, and guidance on appointing bishops and deacons. The text concludes with an eschatological exhortation and brief apocalypse, urging vigilance for the Lord’s coming.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work (AI check): The Book of Judges (שופטים)
Summary Abstract: The Book of Judges (שופטים) recounts Israel’s history from Joshua’s death to the rise of the monarchy, depicting cycles in which Israel lapses into idolatry, suffers oppression, and is delivered by divinely empowered judges. It profiles leaders such as Othniel, Ehud, Deborah and Barak, Gideon, Jephthah, and Samson, including episodes like the defeat of Sisera, Gideon’s victory with 300 men, and Jephthah’s vow. The book concludes with accounts of religious and social disorder—Micah’s idol and the Levite’s concubine—underscored by the refrain that there was no king in Israel and everyone did what was right in their own eyes.

Arranged by psalm with proem-style openings, it offers verse-by-verse homiletic expositions that incorporate parables, ethical teachings, and theological motifs from earlier rabbinic sources. The extant work covers many psalms—especially 1–118—with later or fragmentary material for portions of the remaining psalms.

Summary Abstract: Published in 1996, Questions of Cultural Identity is an edited collection by Stuart Hall and Paul du Gay that places the problem of cultural identity at the center of debates in cultural studies and social theory. The volume includes Hall’s introduction “Who Needs ‘Identity’?,” which critiques essentialist conceptions and frames identities as historically contingent and relational.

Title of Work: Enchiridion ad Laurentium (Handbook on Faith, Hope, and Love)
Summary Abstract: Written circa 421 for the layman Laurentius, Augustine’s Enchiridion is a handbook that summarizes Christian doctrine by organizing it around the theological virtues of faith, hope, and love. It uses the Apostles’ Creed to explain what Christians believe (faith) and the Lord’s Prayer to set out what they hope for, then treats love as the ordering principle of Christian life. The work addresses creation and providence, the nature and origin of evil, sin and grace, the Incarnation and redemption, resurrection and eternal life, and practical piety.

Summary Abstract:
Composed in 1233, The Way of Everyday Life (Shōbōgenzō Genjōkōan) presents a Zen exposition of how ultimate reality is realized in ordinary activities, describing the nonduality of delusion and enlightenment and of life and death.
It emphasizes that studying the Way is studying and forgetting the self, and uses images such as the boat and shore, firewood and ash, the moon reflected in water, and birds and fish in their elements to illustrate practice-realization in daily life.
The text concludes with the fanning story to demonstrate the actualization of the ever-present Dharma in embodied action.

Summary Abstract: Émile Zola’s 1890 novel follows Jacques Lantier, a locomotive engineer on the Paris–Le Havre line, who is plagued by violent hereditary impulses. After station official Roubaud and his wife Séverine murder Grandmorin on a train, Lantier becomes entangled with them and begins an affair with Séverine. Planning to kill Roubaud, Lantier instead succumbs to his compulsion and murders Séverine. The story ends as Lantier and his fireman Pecqueux fight and fall from a speeding troop train, which continues unmanned.

Voices from Chernobyl is an oral history of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster, assembled from interviews Svetlana Alexievich conducted with survivors, firefighters, liquidators, officials, and local residents. Presented as first-person monologues, it documents the human, social, and environmental consequences across Belarus, Ukraine, and Russia, including evacuation, illness, and the state’s response. The book organizes testimonies into thematic sections that span the initial explosion and emergency efforts through the long-term aftermath and memory.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Nishida Kitarō’s 1911 work introduces “pure experience” (junsui keiken) as a pre-reflective, non-dual awareness that grounds knowledge and reality. From this basis, he analyzes the emergence of self-consciousness, will, ethical value (the good), beauty, and religious awareness, treating them as developments of pure experience. The book engages Western philosophy and psychology alongside East Asian thought to frame epistemology, metaphysics, ethics, aesthetics, and religion in terms of pure experience.

Title of Work: Moralbewußtsein und kommunikatives Handeln (Moral Consciousness and Communicative Action)
Summary Abstract: Habermas develops discourse ethics by grounding moral validity in communicative rationality, claiming that only those norms are justified which could meet the informed agreement of all affected participants in practical discourse. He formulates a formal, deontological universalization test linked to the discourse principle, distinguishes moral rightness from ethical-political values, and examines the justification and application of norms. Drawing on speech-act theory and Kohlberg’s moral-development research, he reconstructs the perspective-taking and argumentative competencies that underwrite moral consciousness.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Remake the World (2021) is a collection of Astra Taylor’s essays examining democracy, debt, technology, labor, and solidarity across the 2010s through the COVID-19 era. Drawing on her organizing with the Debt Collective and experiences in movements such as Occupy, Taylor analyzes how austerity, platform power, and inequality shape public life. The pieces connect financial, ecological, and political crises and present strategies for collective action and structural change.

Summary Abstract: This work by Pope Tawadros II outlines the Coptic Orthodox understanding of faith and spirituality, grounding them in Scripture, the apostolic tradition, and the life of the Church. It describes how these principles are embodied in communal worship and personal discipleship within the Coptic Orthodox community.

Summary Abstract: Carol Tavris examines the psychology, physiology, and social functions of anger, challenging common beliefs—especially the catharsis hypothesis—and distinguishing anger from aggression. Drawing on research in social psychology and cross-cultural studies, she analyzes how gender roles, cultural norms, and cognitive appraisals shape when and how anger is expressed. The book details the costs of chronic or misdirected anger and describes research-based strategies, including cognitive reappraisal and assertive communication, for managing conflict and anger expression.

Summary Abstract: Harsh Mander’s 2015 book “Looking Away: Inequality, Prejudice and Indifference in New India” examines the social consequences of India’s post-1990s market liberalization, documenting widening inequality, marginalization, and homelessness alongside expanding middle-class prosperity. Summary Abstract: Graham Greene’s novel follows Querry, a renowned architect famed for ecclesiastical designs who, spiritually exhausted, slips into anonymity at a remote leper colony in the Belgian Congo. There he assists the leprosarium’s doctor with practical building work, drawing unwanted attention from missionaries and a sensationalist journalist who misconstrue his motives. His efforts to help a troubled planter’s young wife ignite jealousy and rumor, culminating in violence and public scandal.

Taking Back Philosophy: A Multicultural Manifesto argues that academic philosophy in the West has marginalized non-European traditions and calls for systematically integrating Chinese, Indian, African, and other global philosophies into teaching and research. Bryan W. Van Norden traces historical causes of this exclusion, rebuts common objections to cross-cultural work, and uses comparative examples to show the relevance of these traditions to central philosophical debates. The book closes with practical recommendations for curricula, hiring, and publishing to broaden the philosophical canon.

Title of Work: How the Way We Talk Can Change the Way We Work
Summary Abstract: Robert Kegan and Lisa Laskow Lahey’s 2001 book outlines seven shifts in workplace language to enable adult development and organizational change: from complaint to commitment; blame to personal responsibility; New Year’s resolutions to competing commitments; big assumptions that hold us to assumptions we hold (tested); prizes and praising to ongoing regard; rules and policies to public agreements; and constructive to deconstructive criticism. It provides structured exercises and tools to help individuals and teams surface hidden commitments and test assumptions to achieve durable behavior change.

Summary Abstract: Prisoner’s Dilemma (1992) by William Poundstone is a nonfiction account of the origins and implications of the prisoner's dilemma in game theory, interwoven with a biography of John von Neumann. It traces the development of game theory at RAND, the formulation of the prisoner’s dilemma by Merrill Flood and Melvin Dresher, and its influence on Cold War nuclear strategy and mutually assured destruction. The book also covers experiments with the iterated prisoner’s dilemma, notably Robert Axelrod’s tournaments and the success of Tit-for-Tat, and explores applications in economics, politics, and biology.

Title of Work: Sefer Hayei ha-Olam ha-Ba (Book of the Life of the World to Come)
Summary Abstract: Composed in 1280, Abraham ben Samuel Abulafia’s Sefer Hayei ha-Olam ha-Ba outlines his program of ecstatic/prophetic Kabbalah, prescribing techniques such as permutation of Hebrew letters and divine names, vocalization patterns, regulated breathing, and specific head and body movements to attain prophetic experience and conjunction with the Active Intellect. It organizes stages of practice, requirements of ritual and mental preparation, and cautions against misuse. The work grounds its method in biblical and rabbinic sources while engaging Sefer Yetzirah and Maimonidean concepts to frame its aims and procedures.

Summary Abstract: Set in 1757 during the French and Indian War, the novel follows the scout Hawkeye (Natty Bumppo) and his Mohican allies Chingachgook and Uncas as they guide Cora and Alice Munro to their father at Fort William Henry. Summary Abstract: On Emotions (Peri Pathōn) is a Stoic treatise by Chrysippus, composed c. 250 BCE, surviving only in fragments preserved by later authors such as Galen, Cicero, Stobaeus, and Diogenes Laertius. It presents the Stoic view that emotions (pathē) are value-laden judgments or assents, classifying them into four primary kinds—distress, pleasure, desire, and fear—with multiple subordinate types. The work also outlines cognitive and ethical therapies aimed at achieving apatheia (freedom from irrational passions) and cultivating rational “good feelings” (eupatheiai) appropriate to the sage.

Title of Work: The Penguin Book of Renaissance Verse
Summary Abstract:
An anthology of Renaissance verse spanning 1509–1659, edited by David Norbrook and H. R. Woudhuysen, assembling works by major figures such as Sidney, Spenser, Donne, Shakespeare, and Milton alongside lesser-known and women poets including Lady Mary Wroth and Katherine Philips.  
Organized into thematic sections (public life, love, topographies, friends and patrons, religion, elegy, translation, and writers/language), it includes an editorial introduction, annotations, and extensive indices and glossary.  
First published in 1992 in London by Allen Lane, The Penguin Press, the hardcover edition is xliv, 910 pages and includes an index.

Summary Abstract: Written during his imprisonment under Mussolini, Antonio Gramsci’s 1932 Prison Notebooks entries examine how ruling classes secure consent through cultural hegemony within civil society and the complementary role of coercion in political society. He develops the concepts of organic intellectuals and the party as the “modern Prince,” contrasts “war of position” with “war of maneuver,” and theorizes “passive revolution” as elite-managed transformation. Gramsci also analyzes language, folklore, and “Americanism and Fordism” to link cultural practices and industrial organization to the production of consent.

Title of Work: The Book of Humans: The Story of How We Became Us
Summary Abstract: Adam Rutherford surveys evolutionary genetics, paleoanthropology, and animal behavior to examine what, if anything, distinguishes Homo sapiens from other species. The book reviews evidence from fossils and comparative genomics—including interbreeding with Neanderthals and Denisovans—and compares human traits with animal analogs such as tool use, communication, cooperation, and sexuality. It argues that many capacities once deemed uniquely human are shared across the animal kingdom, with humans differing chiefly in degree and in the cumulative nature of culture and technology.

Summary Abstract: Timaeus is a Platonic dialogue in which Timaeus of Locri presents a cosmology following Socrates’ recap of an ideal city. He posits a divine craftsman (demiurge) who orders preexistent chaos by the Forms, producing a single living cosmos with a World-Soul and instituting time as the moving image of eternity. The work expounds the receptacle (chōra), the geometric construction of the four elements, and the genesis and functions of human souls and bodies, including perception and disease. It also introduces the Atlantis story to be continued by Critias.

Summary Abstract: John Bowlby’s 1969 volume Attachment, the first in his Attachment and Loss trilogy, formulates attachment theory by synthesizing ethology, control systems theory, and psychoanalysis. He proposes an innate attachment behavioral system that evolved to maintain infant–caregiver proximity, introduces the secure base concept, and delineates the development of attachment across early childhood. The book outlines how early caregiver interactions shape internal working models of self and others and examines behavioral responses to separation and the effects of disrupted caregiving on later socio-emotional functioning.

Title of Work: From Slave Cabins to the White House (2025 pbk)
Summary Abstract: Mitchell theorizes “homemade citizenship,” showing how African Americans—especially women—have used domestic achievement and cultural production to claim civic belonging despite systemic exclusion and violence. Analyzing literature, print culture, and performance from the nineteenth through twenty-first centuries, the book demonstrates how representations of home, marriage, and family function as public assertions of citizenship. It links the material and symbolic spaces of slave cabins to the White House to trace the continuity of domestic success as a survival strategy and civic practice.

Summary Abstract: Jürgen Habermas’s 1991 work “Rechtfertigung und Anwendung (Justification and Application)” develops discourse ethics by distinguishing the justification of moral norms from their application to concrete cases. It formulates the discourse principle (D) and the universalization principle (U) as procedures for testing moral validity, and presents application as an interpretive, context-sensitive judgment conducted within practical discourse rather than as deductive subsumption. The essays draw implications for moral deliberation and legal reasoning, linking impartial justification to case-sensitive adjudication.

Title of Work: What Do You Say After You Say Hello
Summary Abstract: Published posthumously in 1972, Eric Berne’s What Do You Say After You Say Hello? presents Transactional Analysis of “life scripts”—unconscious life plans formed in early childhood from parental messages and early decisions—that shape adult behavior. Summary Abstract: On Muscle examines the biology and meaning of muscle—cardiac, smooth, and skeletal—linking these tissues’ roles in movement, circulation, digestion, and childbirth to their cultural history, including ideals of beauty, and their importance to physical and mental health. Through science reporting and on-the-ground narratives, Tsui follows the first female weightlifter to lift Scotland’s Dinnie Stones, retraces a 50-mile run that followed an escape route from a Native boarding school, and visits Oslo researchers studying muscle’s role in recovery and longevity. Interwoven with her own family history, the book also explores the brain–body connection via a historic Double Dutch club in Washington, D.C., to show how muscle underpins endurance, identity, and how we move through the world.

Summary Abstract: The 15 Commitments of Conscious Leadership outlines fifteen behavioral commitments that shift leaders from reactive, fear-based “below the line” patterns to conscious, learning-oriented “above the line” leadership. It details practices such as radical responsibility, curiosity, candor, integrity, ending gossip, feeling feelings, resolving the drama triangle, and creating clear agreements aimed at win-for-all solutions. Through concrete tools and exercises, the authors show how these commitments build self-awareness, trust, and accountability at individual, team, and organizational levels for sustainable results.

Summary Abstract: David C. McClelland posits that a society’s “need for achievement” (n Ach) is a primary psychological driver of entrepreneurship and economic growth. Drawing on cross-national historical and contemporary evidence, he uses content analysis of children’s stories and other cultural materials to measure achievement imagery and shows that higher n Ach predicts later increases in industrial output. The book analyzes how socialization and education shape achievement motivation and considers interventions to raise n Ach to promote modernization.

Summary Abstract: Jordan Hall’s 2019 essay extends his prior situational assessments to argue that a shift from broadcast “Blue Church” media to decentralized digital media is driving a new conflict across four fronts: communications infrastructure, the Deep State, globalism, and the culture war. He highlights the rise of decentralized collective intelligence (e.g., the Intellectual Dark Web and QAnon), platform battles over moderation and deplatforming, the retreat of globalism in favor of populist nationalism, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as emblematic of a “Blue Insurgency.” The piece concludes by declaring this the final installment and redirecting focus to cultivating coherent collective intelligence through embodied practice.

Title of Work: Suffering in Silence: Malawi Women’s 30-Year Dance with Dr. Banda
Summary Abstract:
This book examines how, during Hastings Kamuzu Banda’s three-decade rule, the Malawi Congress Party organized and coerced women’s dances at political rallies as instruments of praise, mobilization, and political control.
It analyzes the tension between Banda’s public image as nkhoswe (guardian of women) and the gendered coercive structures governing women’s participation within a one-party state.
Framing women’s experiences in the Banda era, it addresses themes of law, politics, human rights, and the status of women in Malawi.

Summary Abstract: An Italian epic poem continuing Boiardo’s Orlando Innamorato, Orlando Furioso interweaves the war between Charlemagne’s paladins and the Saracen king Agramante with multiple chivalric quests and enchantments. Its central threads are Orlando’s descent into madness over Angelica and his cure—featuring Astolfo’s voyage to the moon to recover Orlando’s lost wits—and the romance of Ruggiero and Bradamante, prophesied ancestors of the Este. Spanning Europe, Africa, and fantastical realms, it culminates in Agramante’s defeat, Orlando’s restoration, and the marriage of Ruggiero and Bradamante.

Summary Abstract: The Sand Reckoner is a mathematical treatise by Archimedes, addressed to King Gelon of Syracuse, that introduces a notation for representing extremely large numbers using orders of myriads. He applies this system to compute an upper bound on the number of grains of sand needed to fill the cosmos. The work also summarizes contemporary astronomy, including Aristarchus’s heliocentric hypothesis, and uses quantitative assumptions to estimate the sizes of the Sun, Moon, and Earth.

Summary Abstract: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome traces Rome’s trajectory from its mythic beginnings and the early Republic through imperial expansion to the universal grant of citizenship under Caracalla in 212 CE. It surveys political institutions, social hierarchies, slavery, and daily life, alongside the mechanics of conquest and integration across the Mediterranean. Drawing on literary, epigraphic, and archaeological evidence, Beard reconstructs key events and debates and examines how concepts of power and citizenship shaped Roman society.

Title of Work: The Roman History: The Reign of Augustus
Summary Abstract: Cassius Dio’s account of Augustus narrates Octavian’s consolidation of power after the civil wars, including the defeat of Antony and Cleopatra and the establishment of the principate. It details Augustus’s administrative reorganization of the Senate and equestrian order, fiscal and legal reforms (notably the marriage and adultery laws), military campaigns and frontier policy, urban projects, and the management of honors and cult. The work also traces his succession arrangements (Agrippa, Gaius and Lucius, then Tiberius), culminating in Augustus’s death, funeral, and deification.

Summary Abstract: Sophocles’ Oedipus Rex (c. 429 BCE) depicts Thebes struck by plague as King Oedipus, who earlier became ruler by solving the Sphinx’s riddle and marrying Queen Jocasta, vows to find the murderer of the former king, Laius. Investigations involving the seer Tiresias, a Corinthian messenger, and a Theban shepherd reveal that Oedipus himself killed Laius at a crossroads and unwittingly married his mother, fulfilling an oracle’s prophecy. Jocasta dies by suicide, Oedipus blinds himself, and he asks for exile while Creon assumes authority.

Erin Meyer’s The Culture Map (2014) presents an eight-dimension framework for understanding cross-cultural differences in global business: communicating (low vs high context), evaluating (direct vs indirect negative feedback), persuading (principles-first vs applications-first), leading (egalitarian vs hierarchical), deciding (consensual vs top-down), trusting (task-based vs relationship-based), disagreeing (confrontational vs avoids confrontation), and scheduling (linear-time vs flexible-time). Drawing on research and international case studies, it maps national cultures along these axes and explains how these differences affect management, teamwork, and negotiation. The book provides tools for comparing cultures and guidance for adapting communication and leadership to diverse contexts.

Title of Work: Human Scale Development: Conception, Application and Further Reflections
Summary Abstract: This work presents a Human Scale Development framework that distinguishes universal, finite fundamental human needs from culturally specific satisfiers and organizes them in a matrix across the existential categories of being, having, doing, and interacting. It critiques growth-centered development and proposes participatory, endogenous processes to design synergistic satisfiers while avoiding violators and pseudo-satisfiers. Through methods and case applications—particularly via community workshops in Latin America—it diagnoses “poverties” as deprivations of satisfiers and formulates locally grounded strategies. The book closes with policy implications and reflections on indicators and institutional changes needed to support human-scale development.

Summary Abstract: Albert Ellis’s 1962 work introduces Rational-Emotive Therapy (later REBT), positing that emotional disturbances stem chiefly from irrational, absolutist beliefs rather than external events. It presents the ABC model (Activating event–Beliefs–emotional/behavioral Consequences) and specifies techniques for disputing irrational beliefs and installing rational alternatives via cognitive, emotive, and behavioral methods. The book details practical interventions (e.g., homework assignments, role-plays, shame-attacking exercises), illustrates applications to common clinical problems, and contrasts the approach with psychoanalytic and other contemporary therapies.

Summary Abstract: Nietzsche’s 1886 work critiques the dogmatism of earlier philosophers, challenges prevailing moralities, and advances a perspectival account of truth and knowledge. Organized in nine parts of aphorisms and essays, it probes the psychological origins of values, contrasts noble and herd moralities, develops the idea of the will to power, and calls for “philosophers of the future” to revalue values. It treats themes including religion, scholarship, virtue, peoples and fatherlands, and nobility, and concludes with an aftersong.

Title of Work: A Modest Proposal and Other Writings
Summary Abstract: A Modest Proposal (1729) is a satirical pamphlet in which Jonathan Swift, writing as a rational projector, “proposes” that impoverished Irish families sell their infants as food, presenting the scheme as an economic remedy for poverty. Using precise calculations and deadpan logic, the essay exposes exploitative English policies, absentee landlords, and callous attitudes toward the Irish poor. The “Other Writings” commonly collected with it comprise Swift’s contemporaneous political, religious, and social satires and essays that extend these critiques across governance and economic policy.

Drawing on his work in his family’s funeral home in Milford, Michigan, and on ties to his Irish family, he describes rituals, business practices, and the social roles surrounding death. The pieces combine memoir and reportage to depict how communities and families navigate mortality.

Rudolf Steiner presents a system for rendering spoken language visible through choreographed movement, defining eurythmy as an art of “visible speech.” Across instructional lectures, he maps vowels, consonant groups, rhythm, stress, and grammatical structure to specific gestures and spatial forms for shaping poems and dramatic texts on stage. He outlines training methods, ensemble practice, staging considerations, and coordination with recitation, indicating applications in performance, education, and therapeutic work.

Summary Abstract: Havel analyzes the “post-totalitarian” system of late-communist Czechoslovakia, showing how ideology and everyday rituals of conformity—exemplified by a greengrocer’s obligatory slogan—compel people to “live within a lie.” He argues that individuals can resist by “living in truth”: rejecting ideological rituals, accepting personal responsibility, and creating independent, parallel structures of culture and civil society. The essay defines dissident activity as a practical, moral stance rather than a struggle for power, showing how such acts expose the system’s fragility and enable broader social change.

Title of Work: The Red Record: Tabulated Statistics and Alleged Causes of Lynching in the United States
Summary Abstract: Ida B. Wells’s The Red Record compiles tabulated statistics and case summaries of lynchings in the United States, primarily for 1892–1894, using newspaper reports and other contemporary sources. It catalogs victims’ demographics, locations, and alleged offenses, organizing data by year and state. The work analyzes patterns and argues that accusations—particularly rape—were often used as pretexts, tracing shifts in motives and methods of mob violence in the post-Reconstruction era.

Summary Abstract: In Chapter 1, Pseudo-Dionysius sets the aim of mystical theology as leading the soul beyond sense, intellect, and all discursive knowledge into union with God, who is encountered in the “divine darkness” beyond being and knowing. Addressing Timothy, he instructs that one must abandon every affirmation and denial about God, ascending by way of negation beyond all created realities. He concludes that the first Cause transcends every name, concept, and statement and is therefore approached through complete unknowing.

Title of Work: Love Your Enemies: How Decent People Can Save America from the Culture of Contempt
Summary Abstract: Arthur C. Brooks argues that a “culture of contempt” is corroding American public life and personal relationships, showing why outrage and dehumanization are self-defeating. Drawing on behavioral research and moral traditions, he urges replacing contempt with respect and warm-heartedness in civic engagement. The book offers practical steps for individuals and leaders to disagree better, persuade more effectively, and build a grassroots movement grounded in love to improve public discourse.

Summary Abstract: After the death of Nawal Marwan, twins Jeanne and Simon receive two envelopes from notary Hermile Lebel: one to deliver to the father they believed dead and one to a brother they never knew. Their search leads from Canada to their mother’s unnamed Middle Eastern homeland, tracing her past through civil war, imprisonment, and a long-held silence. They discover that Nawal’s firstborn son—taken from her as a teenager—later became her torturer in prison and is both the twins’ unknown brother and their biological father; after confronting him, they receive Nawal’s final letter addressed to them, ending her vow of silence.

Title of Work: Resist: How a Century of Young Black Activists Shaped America
Summary Abstract: Resist: How a Century of Young Black Activists Shaped America surveys a century of Black youth activism in the United States, tracing efforts from early organizers in the 1920s through the civil rights era to contemporary movements. It examines student-led mobilization and profiles young activists and coalitions—from figures like Ella Baker to groups such as the Bates Seven and the Wilmington Ten—showing how their campaigns against segregation, apartheid, and police violence shaped national social justice movements. The book was published by St. Martin’s Press on November 19, 2024.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Griffith Edwards’s 2000 book surveys alcohol’s history, cultural roles, pharmacology, and effects on the brain and body, distinguishing ordinary use from harmful use and dependence. It synthesizes epidemiological evidence on consumption patterns and related health and social harms across countries, and examines the economic and societal drivers of drinking. The work also assesses prevention, regulation, and treatment approaches, including public policy options and clinical interventions for alcohol problems.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Le visible et l’invisible (The Visible and the Invisible)
Summary Abstract: Posthumously published in 1964, The Visible and the Invisible is Merleau-Ponty’s unfinished late work, edited from his manuscripts and accompanied by extensive working notes. It develops an ontology of “flesh” (la chair) to explain the reversibility and “chiasm” between seer and seen, toucher and touched, and the broader intertwining of body and world. The book critiques earlier phenomenology’s subject–object dualism, shifting from constituting consciousness to an account of pre-objective “wild being” and the latent “invisible” structures that make the visible possible.

Title of Work: The Fall of Language in the Age of English
Summary Abstract: Minae Mizumura’s The Fall of Language in the Age of English (2008) examines the global ascendancy of English and its consequences for the survival of national languages and their literatures, with a focus on Japanese. She traces the historical formation of written national languages and the modern novel, contrasting “universal” languages with national and local tongues, and analyzes how translation and publishing economies shape what circulates as “world literature.” Combining cultural history with autobiographical reflection, the book argues for sustaining robust reading and writing in national languages amid English’s dominance.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Hello World: Being Human in the Age of Algorithms (Updated)
Summary Abstract: Hannah Fry’s Hello World: Being Human in the Age of Algorithms (Updated) examines how algorithms function and shape decisions in domains such as justice, medicine, transportation, finance, and social media. Using real-world case studies, it explains the data and models behind prediction, classification, and optimization, and how accuracy, bias, and errors arise. The book details where automated systems intersect with human judgment and outlines issues of transparency, accountability, privacy, and fairness in everyday life.

Title of Work: How to Be an Anticapitalist in the 21st Century
Summary Abstract: Erik Olin Wright offers a concise framework for evaluating capitalism’s harms and mapping anti-capitalist strategies, including smashing (ruptural breaks), taming (regulation and social democracy), resisting (collective struggle), escaping (opting out), and eroding capitalism. Grounded in his “real utopias” approach, he outlines practical pathways—such as worker cooperatives, participatory budgeting, and universal basic income—to expand social power and move toward more democratic and egalitarian economic arrangements.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: L’Archéologie du savoir (The Archaeology of Knowledge)
Summary Abstract: Michel Foucault’s The Archaeology of Knowledge (1969) sets out a method for analyzing discourse that replaces the history of ideas with an “archaeology” describing discursive formations via the rules that govern the production, transformation, and functioning of statements (énoncés). He defines key concepts such as the statement and the archive, emphasizes discontinuity and series in historical analysis, and provides procedures for identifying the rules of formation of objects, concepts, enunciative modalities, and strategies within discourses. The book distinguishes this approach from author-centered and teleological accounts by describing how discursive practices change without presuming continuity or origin.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Classic of Mountains and Seas
Summary Abstract: The Classic of Mountains and Seas (Shan Hai Jing) is an early Chinese compendium of mythic geography, ethnography, and natural lore compiled by various hands between the Warring States and early Han periods. Organized into sections on mountains, regions within and beyond the seas, and the Great Wilderness, it catalogs topography, deities and spirits, peoples, animals, plants, minerals, and their medicinal uses. Its entries combine itineraries and lists with accounts of myths, omens, and ritual prescriptions, outlining the cosmography and resources of the ancient world.

Organized by state and territory, it profiles Indigenous tourism experiences, cultural centres, tours, and significant places across Australia. It explains concepts such as Country and language groups to support informed engagement with communities.

Summary Abstract: The Gift of Therapy distills Irvin D. Yalom’s decades of psychotherapy practice into brief, standalone chapters addressed to therapists and their patients. It covers core aspects of clinical work—the therapeutic relationship and here‑and‑now process, therapist self‑disclosure, group therapy, dreamwork, boundaries and errors, and termination—within an existential framework that includes death, freedom, isolation, and meaninglessness. The book provides guidance and techniques for conducting sessions and engaging with patients’ existential issues.

Title of Work: Agent_Zero: Toward Neurocognitive Foundations for Generative Social Science
Summary Abstract: Joshua Epstein introduces Agent_Zero, a computational agent architecture that integrates affective (emotion), deliberative (cognition), and social (influence) modules grounded in findings from neuroscience and psychology. Implemented in agent-based models, the framework formalizes bounded rationality and learning to generate macro-level patterns from micro-level rules. The book demonstrates applications to phenomena such as civil violence, contagion, and opinion dynamics, showing how heterogeneous emotions, cognition, and networked influence co-produce emergent social behavior.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract:
The Stolen Year (2022) by Anya Kamenetz is a nonfiction examination of how the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted children’s lives in the United States, with particular attention to the effects of prolonged school closures and related policy choices.  
Drawing on reporting with families, educators, and experts, the book documents impacts across schooling, childcare, nutrition, and mental health, and describes the role of schools as social safety nets for many children.  
Kamenetz organizes the narrative around themes such as hunger, childcare, special education, and mental health, combining case studies with national data and historical context.

Being and Time (1927) reopens the question of the meaning of Being by developing a fundamental ontology through an existential-phenomenological analysis of Dasein as being-in-the-world structured by care, thrownness, projection, and fallenness. Analyzing everydayness and worldhood, it distinguishes the ready-to-hand from the present-at-hand and shows that temporality—especially being-toward-death and historicity—is the horizon for understanding Being. The published work includes the Introduction and two divisions of Part One; the planned Part Two was not completed.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Primary Subdomain(s): Metaphysics & Ontology,"Philosophy of Mind, Science, Language"

Summary Abstract: The Plant Paradox advances Steven Gundry’s thesis that lectins—plant proteins prevalent in grains, legumes, nightshades, and certain dairy—can disrupt the gut lining and immune system, contributing to inflammation and chronic disease. It presents a phased dietary program that removes high-lectin foods, prioritizes low-lectin options and polyphenol-rich fats (such as olive oil), and uses preparation methods like pressure cooking, peeling, and deseeding to reduce lectin exposure, with accompanying meal plans and recipes. The book discusses proposed mechanisms involving the microbiome, intestinal permeability (“leaky gut”), and autoimmunity, and includes case examples illustrating outcomes under the protocol.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Crack-Up is a posthumous collection of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s writings, edited by Edmund Wilson and published in 1945. It compiles the three 1936 Esquire essays titled “The Crack-Up” with additional autobiographical pieces, letters, and excerpts from Fitzgerald’s notebooks. The volume was issued by New Directions.

Summary Abstract: 50 Psychology Classics (2007) by Tom Butler-Bowdon surveys fifty books that have shaped psychological thought across psychoanalytic, behaviorist, cognitive, humanistic, social, and developmental traditions. Each entry summarizes the work’s central ideas and situates them in historical and disciplinary context, covering themes such as personality, motivation, learning, perception, emotion, intelligence, and mental health. The collection serves as a compact reference to major theories, methods, and applications in psychology as reflected in these classic texts.

Title of Work: Formalism in Ethics and Non-Formal Ethics of Values
Summary Abstract: Max Scheler’s 1913 work develops a non-formal, material value-ethics that critiques Kantian formalism by grounding moral knowledge in a priori, objective values disclosed through intentional feeling. It sets out a hierarchical order of values (sensory, vital, spiritual, holy), analyzes acts of preference and love (ordo amoris), and treats the person as the bearer of value-acts rather than a purely rational will. The book systematizes the structure of ethical experience, the sources of obligation, and the distinction between moral goodness and other value modalities.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Political Turbulence analyzes how social media lower participation costs and increase visibility, producing highly skewed, bursty patterns of collective action where many small acts coexist with occasional large cascades. Using large-scale digital trace data, online experiments, and computational models, it examines mechanisms such as social influence, information cascades, and herding that make mobilization outcomes hard to predict. The book documents how micro-donations of participation (likes, shares, clicks) and feedback signals shape contemporary campaigning, protest, and policymaking dynamics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: I’ll Have What She’s Having is a 2025 essay collection by Chelsea Handler, published by The Dial Press on February 25, 2025. The book compiles autobiographical pieces spanning her childhood and career, chronicling adventures and family relationships while reflecting on independence, love, and personal growth.

Summary Abstract: Achille Mbembe’s Critique of Black Reason (2013) traces the genealogy of “the Black” as a modern category from Atlantic slavery and colonialism to contemporary globalization. It analyzes “Black reason” as the ensemble of discourses, institutions, and practices—across philosophy, science, literature, and law—that construct Blackness and organize regimes of racial knowledge, exploitation, and control. The book argues that modern reason and capitalism are historically constituted through racialization and that the logics once applied to Black people are now generalized globally, a process he terms the “becoming black of the world.”

Title of Work: Heterosexualism and the Colonial/Modern Gender System
Summary Abstract: María Lugones theorizes the “colonial/modern gender system” by extending Aníbal Quijano’s concept of the coloniality of power to show how race, gender, and sexuality were co-constituted under European colonialism. She defines heterosexualism as the normative regime that presumes dimorphic sex, binary gender, and compulsory heterosexuality, organizing hierarchies between colonizers and colonized. The essay argues that colonization imposed these binaries on societies with different gender arrangements, often denying colonized females recognition as “women” in the European sense and legitimating violence, domination, and labor exploitation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Non-Western Educational Traditions: Alternative Approaches to Educational Thought and Practice
Summary Abstract: This book surveys major non-Western educational philosophies and practices—including Indigenous, African, Islamic, Hindu, Buddhist, and Confucian traditions—situated in their historical and cultural contexts. It analyzes how knowledge, teaching, and learning are conceived within these traditions, contrasts them with dominant Western paradigms, and examines their institutional forms (e.g., madrasas, gurukulas, monastic schools). The work delineates implications for comparative education, teacher preparation, and policy through its critique of Eurocentrism. Published in 2000.

Title of Work: Learning to See in Melanesia (Revised Edition)
Summary Abstract: Marilyn Strathern synthesizes four Cambridge lectures (1993–2008) on Melanesian aesthetics and sociality, showing how relations of exchange shape what is rendered visible or kept hidden and how persons and objects mutually constitute one another. Moving through case-focused chapters—feathers and shells; axes and canoes; netbags and masks; wig/shell/tree—she analyzes traveling objects, containers, and techniques of concealment as modes of visualization. The volume includes an introduction by Giovanni da Col and appendices on interpreting images, externality in social relations, and scales of environment.

Summary Abstract: Stephen Jenkinson’s Money and the Soul’s Desires is a meditation that examines the origins of the dread many people feel around money and how money comes to wield power that provokes conflict and discord. Title of Work: Forged in War: A Military History of Russia
Summary Abstract: Mark Galeotti surveys Russia’s military history from the early Rus’ through imperial expansion, the Soviet era, and the post–Cold War period to the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. He examines how persistent insecurity, the absence of defensible borders, and economic constraints shaped the state’s institutions, strategy, and national identity over centuries. Organized chronologically around pivotal campaigns, the book links recurring cycles of war and modernization to Russia’s contemporary conduct under Vladimir Putin, culminating in the war against Ukraine.

Summary Abstract: Arlie Russell Hochschild’s 1989 study examines dual-earner families in the United States and shows that many women perform a “second shift” of unpaid housework and childcare after their paid jobs. Using interviews and observations, the book analyzes how couples allocate domestic labor, the gender ideologies that shape these arrangements, and the effects on time and stress. It introduces concepts such as the “second shift” and the “stalled revolution” to describe the persistence of unequal divisions of labor despite women’s increased labor-force participation.

Title of Work: Behave: The Biology of Humans at Our Best and Worst
Summary Abstract: Robert Sapolsky synthesizes neuroscience, endocrinology, psychology, and evolutionary biology to explain the biological and environmental mechanisms shaping human behavior. Structured by time scale, it moves from neural activity seconds before action to hormonal states, development, culture, and evolutionary history to account for empathy, cooperation, aggression, and moral judgment. The book examines genes and epigenetics, stress and social context, and concludes with implications for free will, responsibility, and criminal justice.

Title of Work: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are
Summary Abstract: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are (1966) contends that the conventional sense of a separate ego is a social-linguistic construct that obscures our identity as an inseparable process of the universe. Drawing on Advaita Vedanta, Buddhism, and contemporary science, Watts critiques Western religious and Cartesian dualisms that sustain a cultural taboo against recognizing nondual identity. He examines implications for free will, morality, and death, urging a shift from ego-centered perception to awareness of organism–environment unity.

Summary Abstract: Begun in 413 after the 410 sack of Rome, Augustine’s City of God addresses pagan accusations that Christianity caused Rome’s decline by critiquing Roman religion and philosophy and defending Christian claims. He contrasts the earthly city, oriented by self-love, with the City of God, oriented by love of God, tracing their intertwined histories from creation to the Last Judgment. The work integrates biblical exegesis, historiography, and theology to articulate a Christian account of history and the final destiny of the two cities.

Summary Abstract: Set in Westchester County’s “Neutral Ground” during the American Revolutionary War, The Spy (1821) follows the perilous intrigues surrounding the Wharton family. The novel centers on Harvey Birch, a peddler suspected as a Loyalist agent who is in fact a Continental spy acting under the secret direction of George Washington in disguise as “Mr. Harper.” Amid raids and skirmishes, the plot includes the capture and court-martial of British officer Henry Wharton and the interventions of Continental officer Major Dunwoodie, with Birch’s covert actions driving escapes and revelations of allegiance.

Title of Work: A Story of a Brief Marriage (War Psychology)
Summary Abstract: Set during the final months of the Sri Lankan civil war, the novel follows Dinesh, a young Tamil man living in a makeshift displacement camp near the front lines. Over roughly a day and night, he enters a hastily arranged marriage with Ganga at her mother’s urging to improve her chances of safety. The narrative tracks their wedding, tentative cohabitation, and routine acts of care and survival amid ongoing shelling and forced displacement.

Summary Abstract: Paolo Giordano’s 2008 novel The Solitude of Prime Numbers follows Alice and Mattia, two people scarred by childhood trauma—she by a skiing accident and ensuing anorexia, he by the disappearance of his twin sister—whose lives intermittently intersect from adolescence into adulthood. Drawn to each other yet unable to fully connect, they navigate school, relationships, and work while remaining emotionally isolated. The prime-number metaphor frames their bond as entities that are close yet forever separated.

Summary Abstract: This work presents Yaḥyā ibn ʿAdī’s Christian philosophical theology within the Arabic discipline of ʿilm al‑ilāhiyyāt (divine science/metaphysics), employing Aristotelian logic to articulate divine unity and the Trinity. It integrates late antique Aristotelian metaphysical concepts (e.g., substance/accident and causality) and engages contemporary Muslim critiques of Christian doctrine. Topics addressed include divine attributes and foreknowledge, reflecting Yaḥyā’s broader project to reconcile philosophical reasoning with Christian dogma in 10th‑century Baghdad.

Title of Work: Present Shock: When Everything Happens Now
Summary Abstract: Douglas Rushkoff analyzes how networked digital technologies and always-on media shift culture from linear, future-oriented narratives to a perpetual present. He identifies five manifestations of this shift—narrative collapse, digiphrenia, overwinding, fractalnoia, and apocalypto—and illustrates their effects on work, politics, economics, and identity. The book traces how compressed time horizons and constant updates reshape decision-making, attention, and social coordination.

Summary Abstract: Claudio Naranjo argues that contemporary crises—violence, misogyny, racism, economic injustice, religious intolerance, and corporate greed—stem from entrenched patriarchy, tracing its effects across history, culture, and individual psychology. He proposes healing through integrating an inner “family” of father, mother, and child and through transformative education that links personal transformation to societal change.

Summary Abstract: Pastoral Song (2020) by James Rebanks recounts three generations on his family’s Cumbrian farm, charting the transition from traditional mixed farming to postwar industrial methods and their ecological and social effects. Through the stories of his grandfather, father, and himself, he documents practices such as hedgerow removal, reseeding, and chemical inputs alongside declines in soil health and biodiversity. He describes recent changes on the farm toward restoring hedgerows and meadows, rotational grazing, and other regenerative practices within contemporary market and policy constraints.

Summary Abstract: Philosophical Letters (1734) is a collection of epistolary essays in which Voltaire describes English society, focusing on religion (Quakers, Church of England), science (Newton and the Royal Society), philosophy (Locke), literature, commerce, and parliamentary government. The letters juxtapose English practices—such as religious toleration and smallpox inoculation—with those in France. Its critiques of French institutions led to official condemnation and public burning by the Parlement of Paris.

Summary Abstract: The Diwan of al-Mutanabbi (Abū Ṭayyib, 915–965) collects his Arabic poetry composed across Syria, Egypt, and Iraq during the 10th century. It includes qasidas and shorter pieces in classical meters and monorhyme, spanning panegyric (madih), satire (hijāʾ), boast (fakhr), elegy (rithāʾ), and gnomic wisdom. Many poems stem from his tenure at Sayf al-Dawla’s Hamdanid court in Aleppo and his later encounters with the Ikhshidid ruler Kāfūr in Egypt, addressing themes of patronage, warfare, pride, and fate.

Summary Abstract: Range: Why Generalists Triumph in a Specialized World (2019) by David Epstein examines how broad, cross-disciplinary experiences and late specialization can yield superior problem solving and adaptability. Using research from cognitive science and examples from sports, music, business, and science, it differentiates “kind” versus “wicked” learning environments and emphasizes the value of sampling periods, analogical reasoning, and interleaving for transfer. The book details strategies such as deliberate exploration and embracing desirable difficulties to cultivate range in education and work.

Title of Work: The Literature of Japanese American Incarceration
Summary Abstract: An anthology edited by Frank Abe and Floyd Cheung, this 2024 Penguin Classics volume assembles nearly seventy works of fiction, poetry, essays, memoirs, and letters by Japanese American incarcerees, their children, and descendants. Arranged chronologically and anchored by key government documents, the collection traces the wartime expulsion and imprisonment of approximately 125,000 people of Japanese ancestry during World War II and the range of responses recorded in these writings. It includes several new translations and previously overlooked works recovered from archives and Japanese-language sources.

Summary Abstract: No Citizen Left Behind (2012) identifies a “civic empowerment gap” in which low-income students and students of color have fewer opportunities, skills, and dispositions for civic and political participation. Drawing on political theory, empirical research, and ethnographic work in urban schools, Levinson analyzes how structural inequalities and accountability-driven reforms marginalize civic learning. She proposes “action civics”—student-led, real-world civic and political projects—as a framework to build equitable civic agency, and provides practical strategies for educators alongside policy recommendations.

Title of Work: Maldives Democratic Recovery: Leadership After Authoritarianism
Summary Abstract: This work examines the Maldives’ transition from authoritarian rule following the 2018 presidential election, in which opposition candidate Ibrahim Mohamed Solih defeated incumbent Abdulla Yameen, opening a path for democratic recovery. It details Solih’s early agenda to restore the rule of law and civil liberties, pursue anti-corruption and judicial reforms, and govern through a broad coalition. The analysis also notes enduring constraints on consolidation, including coalition management challenges, institutional weaknesses, and legacies of the prior regime.

Summary Abstract: Set in late 19th-century Java under Dutch colonial rule, the novel is narrated by Minke, a Javanese student educated in a Dutch school, who forms a relationship with Annelies, the daughter of Dutch planter Herman Mellema and his indigenous concubine, Nyai Ontosoroh. Drawn into the Mellema household’s affairs, Minke confronts colonial authorities and European relatives in legal battles that assert Dutch guardianship over Annelies and order her removal to the Netherlands. The narrative traces Minke’s encounters with the colonial legal and social order.

Summary Abstract: Set during Sri Lanka’s civil war, forensic anthropologist Anil Tissera returns with an international human rights team to investigate disappearances. Working with government archaeologist Sarath Diyasena, she examines a modern skeleton nicknamed “Sailor” found at an archaeological site to identify the victim and trace accountability. Their inquiry involves a local artisan’s facial reconstruction and an emergency physician treating war casualties, drawing dangerous scrutiny from multiple factions.

Summary Abstract: Set in 1950s Tiger Bay, Cardiff, The Fortune Men is a novel based on the real case of Somali former merchant seaman Mahmood Mattan, who was arrested and convicted for the 1952 murder of shopkeeper Lily Volpert. It traces the investigation and trial and their effects on Mattan and the local dockside community. The narrative draws on historical records, including Mattan’s 1952 execution and the posthumous quashing of his conviction by the UK Court of Appeal in 1998.

Summary Abstract: Terence’s Hecyra follows Pamphilus and his bride Philumena, who abruptly leaves his house and returns to her mother, leading Pamphilus’s father Laches to blame his wife Sostrata, the “mother‑in‑law.” The real cause is Philumena’s secret pregnancy from an earlier rape; a ring Pamphilus had given the courtesan Bacchis reveals he was the assailant. Once paternity is recognized, Sostrata is cleared of blame, the families reconcile, and Pamphilus accepts Philumena and their child.

Title of Work: Representing Atrocity in Taiwan: The 2/28 Incident and White Terror in Fiction and Film
Summary Abstract: This study analyzes how Taiwan’s 1947 February 28 Incident and the subsequent White Terror have been represented in fiction and film from the mid-20th century through the post–martial law era. Through close readings, it examines narrative strategies, witnessing and trauma, and the constraints of censorship that shaped these depictions. It situates cultural texts within evolving public memory and identity politics, tracing how literature and cinema mediate historical understanding and debates over transitional justice.

Summary Abstract: Notes to John is a posthumous 2025 publication of Joan Didion’s journal for her husband, John Gregory Dunne, documenting therapy sessions she began in November 1999. Across entries that continued for more than a decade, she records discussions of alcoholism, adoption, depression and anxiety, her work, childhood, and her relationship with her daughter, Quintana. Published by Knopf on April 22, 2025, the book is 224 pages. The volume comprises 46 diary entries from this period.

Title of Work: Federalism and Political Restructuring in Nigeria
Summary Abstract: This 1998 edited volume analyzes the evolution, structure, and tensions of Nigeria’s federal system and the contemporaneous debates over “political restructuring,” featuring contributions from leading scholars, including Eghosa Osaghae. Chapters address issues such as state creation, revenue allocation, minority protection, and the federal character principle, and assess reform options including devolution, fiscal federalism, resource control, and constitutional redesign. Published in Ibadan by Spectrum Books in collaboration with IFRA, it situates Nigeria’s restructuring discourse within comparative federal theory and practice.

Summary Abstract: Silas Marner, a linen weaver unjustly expelled from his religious community in Lantern Yard, settles in Raveloe and hoards gold until it is stolen by Dunstan Cass. One winter night a toddler, Eppie, wanders into his cottage after her mother dies nearby; Silas adopts her, and their bond draws him into village life. Years later, Godfrey Cass—Eppie’s biological father—reveals the truth and seeks custody, but Eppie chooses to remain with Silas, and they continue as a family.

Summary Abstract: Published in 1929, A Room of One’s Own expands Virginia Woolf’s 1928 Cambridge lectures to analyze the material and institutional barriers faced by women writers. Using a fictionalized narrator and the device of “Shakespeare’s sister,” Woolf argues that literary creation requires economic security and private space—“£500 a year and a room of one’s own.” She surveys women’s exclusion from education and literary history and outlines conditions necessary for a sustained female literary tradition.

Summary Abstract: The Bhagavad Gita is a 700-verse Sanskrit dialogue embedded in the Mahabharata, traditionally attributed to Vyasa and composed circa the 2nd century BCE. On the battlefield of Kurukshetra, the warrior Arjuna, stricken with moral doubt, receives instruction from his charioteer Krishna on duty (dharma), the nature of the self, and disciplined paths (yogas) of action (karma), knowledge (jnana), and devotion (bhakti). The text articulates a synthesis of these doctrines and includes Krishna’s revelation of his universal form (Vishvarupa).

Summary Abstract: Danny Dorling examines the growth of income and wealth inequality since the late 20th century, focusing on the rising concentration among the top 1% in the UK and other high‑income countries. Using demographic, economic, and geographic evidence, he links policy, finance, housing, and pay structures to the upward redistribution of resources and to impacts on health, social mobility, and democratic participation. The book argues that these patterns are the result of political choices and outlines reforms such as more progressive taxation, curbs on excessive pay, and housing and banking changes to reduce the gap.

Summary Abstract: The Shatapatha Brahmana is a major prose Brahmana of the Shukla (White) Yajurveda, compiled in the mid–first millennium BCE (c. 600 BCE). It provides Yajurvedic priests with detailed procedures, rationale, and symbolism for key Vedic sacrifices such as Agnihotra, Soma rites, Agnicayana (fire-altar construction), and the Ashvamedha. The text interweaves ritual exegesis with myth and cosmology, including the flood story of Manu, and survives chiefly in the Madhyandina and Kanva recensions.

Summary Abstract: Beccaria’s treatise grounds legitimate punishment in the social contract and the principle that only laws can prescribe penalties, rejecting judicial arbitrariness. He argues for clear, codified laws and proportional punishments aimed at prevention and deterrence, asserting that the certainty and promptness of punishment are more effective than its severity. The work condemns torture, secret accusations, and the death penalty, and advocates public, speedy trials, the presumption of innocence, and judicial restraint to apply rather than interpret laws.

Summary Abstract: Spinoza’s Ethics (1677) presents a systematic metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics in geometrical form. It argues for substance monism—God or Nature—as the single infinite substance, posits mind-body parallelism, and explains human behavior through determinism, conatus (striving), and the affects. Across five parts—on God, the mind, the emotions, human bondage, and human freedom—it culminates in an account of freedom through the power of the intellect and the intellectual love of God.

Title of Work: An African History of Africa: From the Dawn of Humanity to Independence
Summary Abstract: Zeinab Badawi presents a single-volume history of Africa from human origins through the independence era, explicitly centering African perspectives and voices. Drawing on archaeology, written records, and oral histories gathered through fieldwork and interviews across more than thirty African countries, the book surveys ancient civilizations, medieval empires, transcontinental slave trades, colonial conquest, and decolonization. It foregrounds African scholars and local storytellers to counter Western-centric narratives and integrate the continent’s diverse regions into a continuous historical account.

Summary Abstract: Paul Collier diagnoses contemporary capitalism as fractured by widening divides between skilled and less‑skilled workers, thriving metropolises and “left‑behind” regions, globally mobile elites and locally rooted citizens, and market individualism and shared ethics. He proposes rebuilding an ethical foundation across the state, firms, families, and the international order, grounded in reciprocal obligations and a renewed sense of shared identity. Policy prescriptions include place‑based strategies to revive provincial cities, expanded vocational training and apprenticeships, corporate governance oriented to purpose and stewardship, and tax and welfare reforms that reward contribution while protecting the vulnerable.

Summary Abstract: Russ Harris’s revised The Happiness Trap introduces Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and explains how the pursuit of constant happiness can paradoxically intensify distress, outlining a practical path to psychological flexibility. It teaches core ACT skills—mindfulness, cognitive defusion, acceptance, values clarification, and committed action—to help readers handle difficult thoughts and emotions while building a meaningful, values-guided life. The updated edition refines examples and exercises to make these techniques more accessible for everyday challenges.

Summary Abstract: Richard C. Schwartz’s 2021 book presents the Internal Family Systems (IFS) model, which views the psyche as a system of “parts” (e.g., managers, firefighters, and exiles) organized around a core, compassionate “Self.” It explains how symptoms and extreme behaviors arise from protective parts and outlines methods for helping parts unburden trauma so the Self can lead. The book includes practical exercises, guided meditations, and case examples illustrating IFS applications to issues such as anxiety, depression, addiction, and trauma.

Summary Abstract: Psychology of the Future presents Stanislav Grof’s synthesis of findings from psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy and holotropic breathwork, outlining an expanded cartography of the psyche that includes biographical, perinatal (Basic Perinatal Matrices I–IV), and transpersonal domains. Drawing on clinical observations and case studies, it introduces concepts such as systems of condensed experience (COEX) and shows how non-ordinary states of consciousness can illuminate the roots and treatment of emotional and psychosomatic disorders. The book examines implications for psychotherapy and psychiatry, including the understanding of spiritual emergencies and religious/mystical experiences.

This book critiques the limits of contemporary machine learning—especially deep learning—highlighting brittleness, lack of common sense, and unreliability in real-world settings. It argues that achieving trustworthy AI requires integrating symbolic reasoning, explicit knowledge, causal models, and grounding with data-driven learning. The work outlines research directions and evaluation benchmarks for building AI that can reason, generalize, and explain its decisions.

Letting Go: The Pathway of Surrender
Summary Abstract: This book presents a method of emotional release called the letting go or surrender technique, which involves allowing feelings to arise and pass without resistance rather than suppressing, expressing, or escaping them. Hawkins explains how this process affects thoughts and behavior and applies it to issues such as anxiety, anger, grief, addiction, physical illness, relationships, work, and spiritual practice. The work uses explanations, anecdotes, and case examples to illustrate the technique and its practical application.

Summary Abstract: On War (Vom Kriege) is an unfinished treatise by Prussian general Carl von Clausewitz, published posthumously in 1832. It advances a general theory of war, defining it as “the continuation of policy by other means” and describing a “remarkable trinity” of passion (the people), chance/probability (the army/commander), and reason/policy (the government). Clausewitz distinguishes ideal from real war and develops concepts such as friction, fog of war, center of gravity, and the culminating point of victory, while maintaining that the defensive is the stronger form of warfare.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: George Lipsitz argues that U.S. public policy and private practices have created a “possessive investment” in whiteness that systematically advantages white people in domains such as housing, education, employment, and the criminal legal system. He traces how ostensibly race-neutral decisions—from mortgage lending and taxation to policing and urban development—produce racialized benefits and harms that are reproduced across generations. An expanded anniversary edition adds new cases and policy developments that extend the analysis into the present.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The Vinaya Pitaka is the collection of monastic regulations in the Pali Canon, traditionally attributed to the teachings of Gautama Buddha and compiled by the early Sangha. It sets out the Patimokkha rules for monks and nuns with their origin stories, and details procedures for ordination, confession, offenses and penalties, and communal governance. The text is organized into the Suttavibhanga, the Khandhaka (Mahavagga and Cullavagga), and the Parivara.

Summary Abstract: Byung-Chul Han analyzes how the erosion of rituals in neoliberal, digital modernity dissolves shared meaning, community bonds, and temporal structure. He argues that symbolic, repetitive forms that once stabilized life have been displaced by events, consumption, and self-optimization, fostering isolation, affective disorders, and incessant communication without distance. The book examines consequences across art, politics, labor, and the body, distinguishing rituals from habits and routines and discussing forms like play and liturgy that once organized collective life.

Title of Work: Commodity Activism: Cultural Resistance in Neoliberal Times
Summary Abstract: Commodity Activism: Cultural Resistance in Neoliberal Times examines how political action is organized through market logics, branding, and consumption in the neoliberal era. Using case studies of celebrity humanitarianism, cause marketing, corporate social responsibility, and media campaigns, it analyzes how commodities, brands, and consumers become central to projects of social change. Summary Abstract: Published posthumously in 1963, Meetings with Remarkable Men is the second series of G. I. Gurdjieff’s All and Everything. Written as an autobiographical narrative, it recounts his youth and extensive travels through the Caucasus, Central Asia, and the Middle East in search of ancient knowledge, portraying the teachers and companions he calls “remarkable men.” The book culminates in the formation of the Seekers of Truth, laying the groundwork for his later teaching known as the Fourth Way.

Summary Abstract: Democratic Vistas (1871) is Walt Whitman’s extended prose essay on the prospects of American democracy in the post–Civil War era. Framed as a rebuttal to Thomas Carlyle’s “Shooting Niagara,” it assesses contemporary political corruption and materialism as obstacles to democratic development. Whitman contends that a robust, distinctly American literature, the poet’s cultural leadership, and a doctrine of “personalism” are necessary to cultivate character and realize the nation’s democratic ideals.

How Children Succeed argues that noncognitive skills—such as grit, self-control, curiosity, and conscientiousness—are crucial to educational and life outcomes, sometimes more than traditional cognitive measures. Drawing on psychology, economics, and neuroscience, Tough examines how early adversity and chronic stress affect brain development and executive function, and how stable, supportive relationships can mitigate toxic stress. Through case studies of schools and programs, including KIPP and a Brooklyn chess team, the book details interventions designed to cultivate character strengths and resilience in children.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Eli Finkel traces the evolution of American marriage from a pragmatic, institutional model to a companionate model and, since the late 20th century, to a self-expressive model that asks spouses to foster each other’s personal growth. Using social science evidence, he contends that modern marriages can achieve exceptional fulfillment when partners invest substantial time and deliberate effort, but often falter when expectations exceed available resources, with widening disparities by socioeconomic status. The book offers evidence-based strategies to improve marital quality, including aligning expectations with resources, “oxygen mask” and “load-lightening” approaches, structured self-expanding activities, and brief “love hacks” such as conflict reappraisal.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: This book synthesizes positive psychology research to explain determinants of happiness and how it can be systematically increased through intentional activities. It presents a framework distinguishing genetic set point, life circumstances, and voluntary practices, and examines processes like intentional practice and hedonic adaptation. The work outlines evidence-based strategies—such as gratitude, kindness, savoring, goal pursuit, optimism, strengthening relationships, adaptive coping, exercise, and mindfulness—and provides tools like a Person-Activity Fit Diagnostic with guidance for tailoring, tracking, and sustaining gains over time.

Summary Abstract: Freakonomics (2005) applies microeconomic analysis to unconventional subjects to examine how incentives and information asymmetries shape behavior. It investigates cases including correlations between legalized abortion and later crime declines, cheating among schoolteachers and sumo wrestlers, the business structure of drug gangs, real-estate agent incentives, and the effects of names and parenting on socioeconomic outcomes. Structured as a series of data-driven case studies, it uses empirical methods to test and describe these phenomena.
