Summary Abstract: The Nibelungenlied is a Middle High German epic (early 13th century) recounting the marriage of Siegfried and Kriemhild and the ensuing court intrigues among the Burgundians. After Siegfried helps King Gunther win Brunhild through deception, Gunther’s vassal Hagen murders Siegfried and seizes the Nibelung treasure. Seeking vengeance, Kriemhild marries Etzel (Attila) and lures her brothers and Hagen to his court in Hungary, where a catastrophic battle ends with the annihilation of the Burgundians and the deaths of Hagen and Kriemhild.

The Jefferson Bible, formally titled The Life and Morals of Jesus of Nazareth, is a compilation by Thomas Jefferson completed in 1820. Jefferson cut and arranged passages from the four canonical Gospels in Greek, Latin, French, and English to present a chronological account of Jesus’s life and ethical teachings. He omitted miracles, the Resurrection, and assertions of Jesus’s divinity to focus on moral philosophy. Prepared as a private project, it was not published during Jefferson’s lifetime.

Title of Work: Uncharted: How to Navigate the Future
Summary Abstract: Uncharted: How to Navigate the Future (2020) examines the limits of forecasting and algorithmic prediction in complex systems, contending that the future is inherently uncertain. Through case studies across business, healthcare, science, and public institutions, Heffernan identifies capacities that strengthen preparedness—experimentation, scenario planning, rehearsal, and relationship-building. She advocates shifting from prediction to practice by cultivating decentralized judgment, diverse teams, and collaborative networks to navigate ambiguity.

Summary Abstract: Underland: A Deep Time Journey (2019) is a nonfiction exploration of the worlds beneath Earth’s surface and humanity’s relationship to deep time. Robert Macfarlane descends into caves, catacombs, mines, glacial moulins, and a Finnish nuclear-waste repository across the UK, Europe, and Greenland to examine how the underland is used to bury, conceal, extract, and preserve. The book interweaves travel narrative with geology, archaeology, ecology, and cultural history, including subterranean networks like mycorrhizal fungi, to situate human activity within planetary timescales.

Summary Abstract: Hannah Arendt examines the modern tradition of revolution with a primary comparison of the American and French Revolutions, tracing how each addressed the problem of founding a new political order. She distinguishes liberation from tyranny (liberation) from the creation of durable public freedom through constitutional founding (foundation), contending that the French Revolution was overwhelmed by the “social question” while the American succeeded in instituting lasting political freedom. The book explores concepts of public happiness, authority, the problem of foundation, and council systems as alternatives for sustaining participatory political life.

Across eight essays, Faye traces her first major heartbreak and periods of addiction while analyzing the norms governing romance, sex, friendship, motherhood, self-worth, and spiritual life, drawing on cultural and philosophical references. Summary Abstract: Eduardo Gudynas analyzes the plural South American discourse of Buen Vivir/Vivir Bien as an alternative to development, rooted in indigenous concepts such as sumak kawsay and suma qamaña and oriented toward moving beyond Western modernity. He details its constitutional incorporation in Ecuador (2008) as a set of rights including the rights of nature and in Bolivia (2009) as ethical-moral principles linked to a plural economic model. The article identifies shared pillars—ethical valuation beyond utilitarianism, interculturality, recognition of nature’s intrinsic value, and dissolving the society–nature dualism—while mapping overlaps and tensions with post-development, degrowth, and socialist currents and outlining practical policy tools.

Title of Work: Open Veins of Latin America: Five Centuries of the Pillage of a Continent
Summary Abstract: Published in 1971, Eduardo Galeano’s book traces five centuries of Latin American history from European conquest through the 20th century, centering on the extraction of silver, sugar, rubber, coffee, bananas, and oil. It argues that colonial and later foreign economic structures—often operating with local elites—channeled wealth abroad and entrenched dependency and underdevelopment in the region. The work synthesizes historical case studies and economic mechanisms such as unequal exchange, debt, and state violence to explain persistent patterns of exploitation.

Title of Work: Churning the Earth: The Making of Global India
Summary Abstract: Churning the Earth examines the impacts of India’s post-1991 globalization, documenting imbalanced, externally oriented, and often jobless growth that has intensified inequality, displaced communities, and degraded ecosystems. Through chapters on poverty and inequality, ecological security, environmental governance, urban–rural dynamics, and “crony capitalism” and land conflicts, the authors trace how policy shifts and corporate–state alliances have reshaped livelihoods and resources. They conclude by profiling grassroots initiatives and proposing “radical ecological democracy” as an alternative framework for socially just and ecologically sustainable development.

Summary Abstract: Most Likely to Succeed: Preparing Our Kids for the Innovation Era (2015) examines the mismatch between traditional, test-driven schooling and the competencies required in an innovation-based economy. Title of Work: Finnish Lessons 2.0: What Can the World Learn from Educational Change in Finland?
Summary Abstract: This book examines the development of Finland’s comprehensive school system from the 1970s to the early 2010s and documents the policies and structures behind its high performance and equity. It details features such as universal comprehensive schooling, master’s-level teacher preparation, school and teacher autonomy, minimal standardized testing, early student support, and a culture of trust and collaboration. Using international evidence, including PISA results, it contrasts Finland’s approach with test-based accountability and market-oriented reforms and distills system-level lessons for other countries; the 2.0 edition updates data and cases and addresses changes and misconceptions since the first edition.

Title of Work: Change: Principles of Problem Formation and Problem Resolution
Summary Abstract: This work presents a systemic, cybernetic framework for how human problems are formed and maintained by recursive feedback, often via the very attempted solutions applied to them. It distinguishes first-order change (modifying behavior within existing rules) from second-order change (altering the system’s rules), emphasizing the latter for resolving entrenched difficulties. Applying communication theory to brief therapy, it details interventions such as reframing, disrupting interactional sequences, and paradoxical tasks to interrupt problem-maintaining patterns, illustrated with clinical cases.

Summary Abstract: In Brutalisme (2020), Achille Mbembe invokes the architectural aesthetic of brutalism to theorize a planetary order in which capital permeates all spheres of existence and digital computation directs social organization, generating a pathos of demolition and production. Title of Work: The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (Anniversary Ed.)
Summary Abstract: Michelle Alexander contends that mass incarceration in the United States, fueled largely by the War on Drugs, functions as a contemporary racial caste system that disproportionately ensnares Black Americans. She examines how policy choices, policing practices, prosecutorial discretion, and court doctrines framed in colorblind terms enable racially disparate arrests, convictions, and sentences. The book documents the lasting collateral consequences of a criminal record—disenfranchisement, exclusion from employment and housing, and restricted access to public benefits—and situates these outcomes within the historical continuum from slavery to Jim Crow, outlining avenues for systemic change.

A short work of fiction set in Willesden, northwest London, it follows Fatou, a young West African live-in housekeeper for the Derawal family. On her Mondays off she secretly uses the family’s guest passes to swim and befriends Andrew, a Ghanaian churchgoer, while the nearby Embassy of Cambodia—where a perpetual badminton game is visible—serves as a recurring backdrop. A confrontation over the passes results in Fatou’s dismissal, leaving her future uncertain.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Aristotle’s On Respiration investigates the purpose and modes of breathing in animals, arguing that respiration serves to cool the innate vital heat centered in the heart. He maintains that true respiration (the intake of air) belongs to blooded land animals with lungs, while aquatic animals cool their heat through gills and water rather than by breathing, and bloodless creatures possess analogous passages for cooling. The treatise links respiration with nutrition, temperature regulation, and the conditions of life and death across different environments.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: Search Inside Yourself (2012) by Chade-Meng Tan presents the mindfulness-based emotional intelligence curriculum developed at Google, organized into three components: attention training, self-knowledge and self-mastery, and creating useful mental habits such as empathy and compassion. Integrating mindfulness practices with findings from neuroscience and psychology, it provides step-by-step exercises (e.g., breathing and body scan meditations, journaling, visualization, active listening) and techniques for managing emotions, difficult conversations, and stress in professional settings.

Summary Abstract: The title "Costume in Motion" is a 2021 book by E. Shura Pollatsek, not a 2025 work by Eleanor Clayton. Eleanor Clayton’s 2025 publication is "Forbidden Territories: 100 Years of Surreal Landscapes". Without a verifiable source for a 2025 work by Clayton titled "Costume in Motion," a factual abstract cannot be provided.

Title of Work: My Childhood, My Apprenticeship and My Universities
Summary Abstract: Maxim Gorky’s autobiographical trilogy traces his development from a harsh childhood in his grandparents’ home in Nizhny Novgorod after his father’s death, through years of apprenticeship and itinerant labor along the Volga during which he educates himself through reading. The final volume covers his move to Kazan, where poverty prevents university study; he works menial jobs, engages with radical circles, and treats life experience as his “universities.” Together the volumes document the people and conditions of late–19th-century Russia that shaped his path toward becoming a writer.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A comprehensive collection of Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s poetry spanning his career, from early political sonnets and religious lyrics to later narrative, visionary, and conversational poems. It includes works such as The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, Kubla Khan, Christabel, and the conversation poems (The Eolian Harp, Frost at Midnight, This Lime-Tree Bower My Prison), tracing themes of imagination, nature, faith and doubt, guilt and redemption, and the supernatural across forms including ballad, ode, lyric, and blank verse.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: The World as I See It
Summary Abstract: The World as I See It (1949) is a collection of Albert Einstein’s essays, letters, and addresses articulating his worldview beyond technical physics. It surveys his reflections on the meaning of life, ethics, religion without dogma, education, and the social responsibility of scientists. Einstein also discusses pacifism and the need for international cooperation, civil liberties, and his support for Jewish cultural life and a homeland in Palestine.

Summary Abstract: Wuthering Heights (1847) by Emily Brontë is framed by Mr. Lockwood’s journal and the housekeeper Nelly Dean’s narrated history of events at Wuthering Heights and Thrushcross Grange on the Yorkshire moors. It recounts the bond between Heathcliff, an orphan taken in by the Earnshaws, and Catherine Earnshaw, and how Catherine’s marriage to Edgar Linton prompts Heathcliff to seek revenge on the Earnshaw and Linton families. The story spans two generations, culminating in Heathcliff’s death and the developing relationship between Catherine Linton and Hareton Earnshaw.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Dana, a Black woman in 1976 Los Angeles, is repeatedly and involuntarily transported to a pre–Civil War Maryland plantation whenever the life of Rufus Weylin, a white ancestor, is in danger. To preserve her family line, she must ensure Rufus’s survival through multiple visits, returning to the present only when her own life is threatened; on one trip her husband, Kevin, is pulled back with her and becomes stranded in the past for years. Her final return to 1976 results in the loss of her left arm, and afterward she and Kevin consult historical records to learn the fates of those on the Weylin plantation.

This collection compiles Bantu Stephen Biko’s court testimonies and public speeches from around 1973, articulating the principles of Black Consciousness and the imperative of black unity and self-definition. Biko examines apartheid’s psychological and structural oppression, critiques white liberal tutelage, and advocates autonomous black institutions and community organization. He also addresses the impact of banning orders and state repression on political activity and everyday civic life.

Summary Abstract: Life-Span Development (1983) by John Santrock surveys human development from conception through late adulthood. It integrates biological, cognitive, and socioemotional domains across age stages while presenting major developmental theories, research methods, and key milestones. The book emphasizes both normative patterns and individual differences within family, school, peer, and cultural contexts and links empirical findings to practical applications.

Summary Abstract: Harmonie Universelle (1636) by Marin Mersenne is a comprehensive treatise on music theory and acoustics. It presents quantitative relations between pitch and the properties of vibrating strings—length, tension, and mass—now known as Mersenne’s laws, and analyzes consonance, tuning, and temperament. The work also documents contemporary musical instruments, detailing their construction, classification, and playing techniques.

Summary Abstract: Originally published in 2005, A New Earth by Eckhart Tolle examines how identification with the ego underlies personal suffering and collective dysfunction. It introduces concepts such as the “pain-body” and unconscious patterns, and outlines practices of observing thought and cultivating present-moment awareness to dissolve egoic identification. The work frames awakening to one’s inner purpose as the basis for more conscious relationships, work, and society.

Title of Work: Creating Alternative Futures: The End of Economics
Summary Abstract: Creating Alternative Futures: The End of Economics (1978) critiques orthodox, growth-centered economics as inadequate for addressing technological change, environmental limits, and social needs. Henderson advances a systems and futures-oriented approach that integrates ecology, technology assessment, and the social indicators movement, calling for new measures of progress beyond GDP. She outlines alternative pathways—renewable energy, appropriate technology, decentralization, and participatory decision-making—to guide a transition toward sustainable, socially responsive economies.

Title of Work: A Short History of Nearly Everything
Summary Abstract: Bill Bryson surveys the development of scientific understanding from the Big Bang to the present, covering cosmology, geology, physics, chemistry, and biology. He recounts key discoveries and the work of notable scientists to explain Earth’s formation, the evolution of life, and the structure of the universe. The book synthesizes prevailing (as of 2003) explanations of phenomena such as plate tectonics, natural disasters, and the origins of species.

Title of Work: How Not to Age — New Edition
Summary Abstract: Dr. Michael Greger synthesizes peer-reviewed anti-aging research to explain how diet and lifestyle can modulate the biological mechanisms of aging and help prevent common age-related diseases. The book outlines eleven cellular aging pathways and highlights interventions such as boosting autophagy and reducing senescent “zombie” cells through compounds like spermidine and quercetin found in specific foods. Drawing on patterns from long-lived “blue zone” populations, it provides practical, evidence-based strategies to preserve physical and cognitive function over time.

Title of Work: Struggle to Be the Sun Again
Summary Abstract: Chung Hyun Kyung articulates the distinctive contributions of emerging Asian women’s theology to the meaning of the gospel and the challenges it poses to theology and the church. The book situates these theologies within Asian women’s historical and social contexts and their reflections on humanity. Summary Abstract: An anthology of classical Athenian speeches by various authors, Greek Political Oratory highlights the role of rhetoric in the Assembly and law courts of the 5th–4th centuries BCE. It presents deliberative and forensic orations by figures such as Demosthenes, Aeschines, Isocrates, and Lysias on issues including war, foreign policy, citizenship, and public accountability. Together the selections illuminate the institutions and practices of Athenian democracy and the persuasive techniques used to shape public decision-making.

Summary Abstract: Open Veins of Latin America (1971) by Eduardo Galeano is a non-fiction work that traces Latin America’s history from the colonial conquest to the 20th century through the lens of resource extraction and foreign control. It documents how silver, sugar, coffee, rubber, and oil were integrated into export economies and links these processes to patterns of dependency and underdevelopment in the region. The book combines historical narrative and political-economic analysis across multiple countries and commodities, tracing continuities from European imperial rule to U.S. and multinational influence.

Title of Work: Unterwegs zur Sprache (On the Way to Language)
Summary Abstract: Martin Heidegger’s On the Way to Language (1960) gathers lectures and essays that examine the essence of language and its relation to Being, thinking, and poetry. He develops the notions of Saying (Sage) and the event of appropriation (Ereignis), treating language as that which speaks and gathers rather than a mere human tool. The volume includes “A Dialogue on Language” (with a Japanese interlocutor) and “Language in the Poem” on Georg Trakl, alongside reflections such as “The Nature of Language” and “Language.”

Summary Abstract: Talcott Parsons’ The Social System (1951) presents a structural-functionalist account of society as an interdependent network of roles organized by shared norms and values that secure order and integration. It develops analytic tools such as pattern variables for role expectations and the four functional imperatives (AGIL: Adaptation, Goal Attainment, Integration, Latency), emphasizing socialization and internalization as mechanisms of stability. Parsons applies the framework to institutions like the family and medicine—introducing the “sick role”—and analyzes deviance and social control as processes that restore equilibrium.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: Medieval Misogyny and the Invention of Western Romantic Love
Summary Abstract: Bloch argues that Western romantic love did not liberate medieval culture from misogyny but recast its antifeminist logic in the form of idealizing women. Through analyses of patristic and medieval texts, he describes a Christian construction of gender in which the flesh is feminized, the feminine is aestheticized, and aesthetics are theologically condemned. Tracing a throughline of virginity from the Church Fathers to twelfth- and thirteenth-century courtly poets, he demonstrates continuity between early Christian antifeminism and later romantic ideals and explains the social, economic, and legal conditions behind this apparent inversion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Fritjof Capra’s 1975 book explores parallels between modern physics—quantum mechanics, relativity, and particle physics—and Eastern mysticism, including Hinduism, Buddhism, and Taoism. It traces developments in 20th-century physics (e.g., complementarity, uncertainty, and the interconnectedness of phenomena) and juxtaposes them with concepts like yin–yang, emptiness, and the Tao. The work argues for a holistic worldview in which insights from physics and contemplative traditions converge on a shared underlying reality.

Summary Abstract: A practical manual of haṭha yoga, the text is organized into four chapters covering postures (āsanas), breath control (prāṇāyāma) and purifications (ṣaṭkarmas), seals and locks (mudrās and bandhas), and meditative absorption (samādhi). It details techniques to purify the nāḍīs, regulate prāṇa through kumbhakas, and awaken kuṇḍalinī to facilitate rāja yoga. The work also prescribes dietary and behavioral disciplines and emphasizes instruction under a qualified guru.

Title of Work: America in the King Years Redux
Summary Abstract: America in the King Years Redux recounts the U.S. civil rights movement centered on Martin Luther King Jr. from 1954 to 1968, tracing pivotal campaigns from Montgomery and Birmingham through Selma to the passage of the Civil Rights and Voting Rights Acts and King’s assassination. It examines nonviolent strategy, internal movement debates, and the interactions among grassroots organizers, segregationist opposition, and local, state, and federal authorities.

Title of Work: La Guerra contra las Mujeres (“The War Against Women”)
Summary Abstract: Rita Segato’s La guerra contra las mujeres (2016) is a collection of essays that conceptualizes contemporary gender violence—especially in Latin America—as a war waged on women’s bodies and lives. She argues that femicide and sexual violence function as messages among men that produce and display power, rooted in the mandato de masculinidad, coloniality, and the political economies of neoliberalism, organized crime, and militarization, advancing the notion of a pedagogía de la crueldad that normalizes aggression. Through cases such as Ciudad Juárez, Segato traces the entanglement of state and para-state actors across public and private spheres and critiques punitive paradigms while outlining community-centered, de-patriarchalizing transformations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: For Fck’s Sake: Why Swearing is Shocking, Rude, and Fun
Summary Abstract: Rebecca Roache offers a philosophical analysis of swearing, arguing that profanity’s power to offend stems less from the words themselves than from unspoken inferences and the intentional conveyance of disrespect. She examines how context, relationships, and norms determine when swearing is objectionable; differentiates swears from slurs; addresses gendered terms; and analyzes regulation and sanitization practices such as asterisks and quotation. The book also outlines constructive functions of swearing—building social intimacy, aiding pain tolerance, and potentially curbing violence—and discusses the social value of offensiveness.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Kakawin Ramayana is an Old Javanese kakawin-meter adaptation of the Sanskrit Ramayana, composed by an anonymous poet in Central Java around the late 9th to early 10th century (c. 910 CE), and traditionally arranged in 26 cantos. It recounts Rama’s exile, Sita’s abduction by Ravana, the alliance with Sugriva and Hanuman’s mission, the siege of Lanka, and their return to Ayodhya. The poem’s first half closely follows the Sanskrit Bhaṭṭikāvya (Rāvaṇavadha), while later cantos diverge with distinct Javanese elaborations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: Why I Cook is a 2024 memoir-cookbook by chef Tom Colicchio that traces his path from a New Jersey childhood to award-winning New York kitchens and television work. Structured in 10 memoir chapters with 60 recipes, it pairs more than 40 years of personal reflections with the dishes that shaped his life and career. The book includes recipe photography and images from his childhood to contextualize the narratives and recipes.

Bitbol reviews six arguments challenging the claim that consciousness derives from a material basis, drawing on epistemology, phenomenology, neuropsychology, and the philosophy of quantum mechanics. He argues that attempts to prove consciousness is ontologically secondary fail and instead reveal its methodological and existential primacy, without endorsing an alternative metaphysical position. The work advocates a Varela-inspired neurophenomenological stance that redefines the line between assumptions and questions and seeks common ground between phenomenology and objective science to expand intersubjective agreement.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Disparities examines the concept of disparity by challenging contemporary “negative” philosophies (such as Malabou’s plasticity, Kristeva’s abjection, and Pippin’s self-consciousness) and proposing an alternative grounded in dialectical materialism. Adopting Badiou’s dictum that a true idea is one that divides, Žižek contends that philosophical engagement proceeds through division rather than dialogue. Organized into three parts—the disparity of truth (subject/object), beauty (ugly/abject), and the good (toward a materialist negative theology)—the book ranges across ontology, posthumanism, aesthetics, and negative theology.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Book 4 (395–388 BC) centers on the Corinthian War, showing how Persian satrap Pharnabazus used subsidies to unite Athens, Corinth, Argos, and Thebes against Sparta and prompting the recall of King Agesilaus II from his Ionian campaign. It narrates the Persian-Athenian naval victories under Conon—especially the Battle of Cnidus (394 BC)—and Persia’s funding of the rebuilding of Athens’ Long Walls.

Title of Work: Heartland: A Memoir of Working Hard and Being Broke in the Richest Country on Earth
Summary Abstract: Heartland: A Memoir of Working Hard and Being Broke in the Richest Country on Earth (2018) is Sarah Smarsh’s account of growing up in a working-poor family in rural Kansas. Tracing multiple generations of women in her family, she documents farm labor, low-wage work, domestic instability, and how class, gender, and policy shaped their lives. Framed as an address to an unborn daughter, the book examines barriers to mobility faced by the rural American working class.

Title of Work: How to Be an Artist: A Survival Guide for Making Art
Summary Abstract: Published in 2020, Jerry Saltz’s How to Be an Artist: A Survival Guide for Making Art is a practical manual on developing and sustaining a creative practice. It compiles concise rules, prompts, and exercises covering topics such as building discipline, finding a voice, working through creative blocks, and responding to criticism. The guidance draws on Saltz’s experience as an art critic and on examples from art history and contemporary artists.

Summary Abstract: De Jure Belli ac Pacis (1625) sets out a systematic account of the laws of war and peace grounded in natural law, divine law, and the law of nations. Grotius defines when war may be lawfully undertaken and the rules governing its conduct (jus ad bellum and jus in bello), including treatment of noncombatants, prisoners, property, truces, and peace settlements. He further analyzes sovereignty, jurisdiction, contracts and treaties, punishment, and obligations to establish legal principles governing relations among states and individuals.

Title of Work: The Jugurthine War and The Conspiracy of Catiline
Summary Abstract: This volume contains Sallust’s two historical monographs, The Jugurthine War and The Conspiracy of Catiline, covering conflicts in Numidia (112–105 BCE) and a failed coup in Rome (63 BCE). The Jugurthine War recounts Jugurtha’s contest for the Numidian throne, his bribery of Roman officials, the campaigns of Metellus and Marius, and Jugurtha’s capture via King Bocchus’s betrayal arranged by Sulla. The Conspiracy of Catiline narrates Catiline’s plot to seize power, its exposure by Consul Cicero, the Senate’s suppression and executions in Rome, and Catiline’s defeat and death at Pistoria, alongside Sallust’s reflections on Roman politics and moral decline.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Matière et mémoire: essai sur la relation du corps à l'esprit (Matter and Memory)
Summary Abstract: Matter and Memory (1896) examines the mind–body relationship through a theory of perception and memory. Bergson argues that perception is a selection for action, with the body as a center among images, and that the brain is an instrument for directing movement rather than a storehouse of representations. He distinguishes habit memory (embodied motor dispositions) from pure memory (the virtual conservation of the past), explaining how recollection actualizes into perception to guide behavior. Drawing on neurological cases, he argues that cerebral lesions impair motor mechanisms without abolishing pure memory, supporting the relative independence of mind from brain.

Title of Work: Farming While Black: Soul Fire Farm’s Practical Guide to Liberation on the Land
Summary Abstract: Farming While Black is a practical handbook by Leah Penniman that documents Soul Fire Farm’s methods to support Black and other marginalized growers in achieving land- and food-sovereignty. It offers step-by-step guidance on regenerative agriculture—farm planning, soil building, crop cultivation, seed saving, animal care, and farm business/marketing—along with resources for land access, cooperative models, and community education. The book situates these practices within the history and contributions of African-heritage agrarian traditions and includes curricula, worksheets, and case examples to support growers and organizers.

Summary Abstract: The Summer Book (1972) by Tove Jansson depicts a summer shared by six-year-old Sophia and her elderly grandmother on a small island in the Gulf of Finland. Structured as a series of vignettes, it follows their daily explorations and conversations about the island’s natural environment and the events of the season. The narrative also addresses Sophia’s mother’s recent death, with her father present mainly in the background.

Summary Abstract: Giuseppe Mazzini’s The Duties of Man (1860) outlines a civic and moral doctrine addressed primarily to workers, defining individuals’ duties to God, family, country, and humanity. It argues that rights arise from the fulfillment of duties and advocates Italian national unity, republican government, universal education, and the dignity of labor as collective obligations. The work emphasizes association and popular participation as means to build a just, unified nation.

Title of Work: Beat Zen, Square Zen, and Zen
Summary Abstract: Alan Watts contrasts “Beat Zen”—bohemian spontaneity—and “Square Zen”—institutional orthodoxy—with Zen as a practice of direct insight that transcends both. He argues these approaches frame Zen either as license or as moralism and clarifies the roles of discipline, spontaneity, meditation, and satori. The essay examines ego, non-attachment, and cultural misunderstandings in Zen’s transmission to the West.

Summary Abstract: Push presents a structured 30-day program in which Chalene Johnson leads readers through daily exercises to clarify priorities, set goals, and build sustainable habits. Central to the method is the identification of a single “Push Goal” that catalyzes progress on multiple related goals, which is then broken down into actionable steps. The plan integrates fitness and nutrition guidance with practical productivity tools such as to-do systems, tracking, and accountability.

Summary Abstract: Wind God and Thunder God (Fūjin Raijin-zu) is a pair of folding screens by Tawaraya Sōtatsu from the early Edo period (early 17th century). Executed in ink and color on gold-leaf paper, they depict the Shinto deities Fūjin (wind) and Raijin (thunder) against a gold ground. The work is associated with the Rinpa school and inspired later versions by artists including Ogata Kōrin and Sakai Hōitsu.

Title of Work: Panarchy: Understanding Transformations in Human and Natural Systems (Final Edition)
Summary Abstract: The book develops the concept of panarchy, explaining how complex human, natural, and coupled systems are structured as nested adaptive cycles of growth, accumulation, release, and renewal across scales of space and time. It synthesizes resilience and sustainability theory to identify leverage points and adaptive management strategies for influencing cycles of change. Case studies such as rangelands and the Florida Everglades link theory to practice, illustrating cross-scale dynamics and management challenges in social-ecological systems.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Hervé Le Tellier’s 2020 novel L’anomalie centers on an Air France flight from Paris to New York that passes through a violent storm and inexplicably duplicates, with one plane landing in March and an identical counterpart appearing about three months later. U.S. authorities sequester the second aircraft while scientists, intelligence agencies, and religious leaders grapple with the event’s implications, and passengers are forced to meet their own doubles. The narrative follows several travelers—including a contract killer, an architect and his partner, a pop star, and a writer whose manuscript eerily mirrors events—as their diverging lives unfold under global scrutiny.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: An Enquiry into the Origin of Honour
Summary Abstract: Mandeville’s 1732 treatise, cast as a dialogue, investigates the social origins and political function of honor as an artifice built on pride, shame, and reputation to regulate elites and sustain martial discipline. He distinguishes “male” honor (courage, willingness to fight, dueling) from “female” honor (chastity and sexual reputation) as complementary systems that govern conduct. The work also examines how Christian doctrine can be harnessed by rulers to promote obedience and courage, rendering Christianity “useful in war” despite its ethos of humility and charity.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: Magna Moralia is a two‑book treatise on ethics traditionally attributed to Aristotle, though its authorship is disputed. It offers a concise account of key Aristotelian themes, including the human good (eudaimonia), moral and intellectual virtues, choice and deliberation, continence and incontinence, justice, and friendship. The work substantially overlaps with and often epitomizes material found in the Nicomachean and Eudemian Ethics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: The Mirror and the Mask: Lacan in Russia

Summary Abstract: Brigitta and Other Tales collects four novellas by Adalbert Stifter—Abdias, Brigitta, The Forest Path, and Limestone. Summary Abstract: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill is the debut solo studio album by Lauryn Hill, released in 1998 by Ruffhouse and Columbia Records. Blending hip hop, R&B, soul, and reggae, it explores themes of love, heartbreak, identity, motherhood, and faith, and includes the singles “Doo Wop (That Thing),” “Ex-Factor,” and “Everything Is Everything.” The album won five Grammy Awards in 1999, including Album of the Year.

Title of Work: Chunqiu Fanlu (Luxuriant Dew of the Spring and Autumn Annals)
Summary Abstract: Chunqiu Fanlu (Luxuriant Dew of the Spring and Autumn Annals), traditionally attributed to the Western Han thinker Dong Zhongshu, is a collection of Gongyang-style essays interpreting the Spring and Autumn Annals. It integrates yin–yang and Five Phases correlative cosmology with the doctrine of Heaven–human resonance to explain portents and link cosmic order to moral governance, ritual, and law. The work advocates using the Annals as a normative guide for rulership, including adjudication (chunqiu jueyu), and the received text is widely considered composite with layers from different periods.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Title of Work: Ageless Soul: The Lifelong Journey Toward Meaning and Joy (or "Meaning and Purpose")
Summary Abstract: Thomas Moore presents aging as a lifelong spiritual and psychological journey, drawing on mythology, depth psychology, and clinical and monastic experience to explore how later life can deepen meaning and purpose. He addresses themes such as identity shifts, relationships and community, creativity and vocation, loss and illness, and mortality, and their effects on the soul. The book outlines practices—reflection, ritual, storytelling, and service—to help integrate the wisdom of aging into daily life.

Summary Abstract: My Brilliant Career (1901) by Miles Franklin is a first-person coming-of-age novel about Sybylla Melvyn, a teenager in rural New South Wales in the 1890s. Moving among her family’s farm at Possum Gully, her relatives’ property at Caddagat, and a governess post with the McSwats, she navigates poverty and social expectations while courted by neighbor Harold Beecham. Sybylla ultimately declines marriage to pursue independence and a literary career.

Title of Work: Living Untethered: Beyond the Human Predicament
Summary Abstract: Michael A. Singer outlines a method for moving beyond the “human predicament” by distinguishing the observing awareness from the mind’s thoughts and emotions. The book explains how to relax, accept, and release inner disturbances and conditioned patterns that drive reactivity. It presents practical guidance on surrender and sustained equanimity to live untethered from the personal narrative.

Summary Abstract: The Sickness Unto Death (1849), published under the pseudonym Anti-Climacus by Søren Kierkegaard, examines despair as the “sickness unto death” within a Christian framework of selfhood. It defines the self as a relation that relates itself to itself and to the power that established it (God), framing despair as a misrelation of the self. The book distinguishes forms of despair—unconscious despair, despair of not wanting to be oneself, and despair of wanting to be oneself—and identifies despair as sin. It presents faith, in which the self rests transparently in God, as the remedy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: Shōji Jissōgi (The Meaning of Sound, Sign, and Reality)
Summary Abstract: Shōji Jissōgi (The Meaning of Sound, Sign, and Reality) is a doctrinal essay by Kūkai (Kōbō Daishi) that formulates the esoteric Buddhist teaching of the non-duality of sound, letters/words, and reality. It maintains that phonetic sounds and written characters are direct manifestations of the Dharmakāya (Mahāvairocana), rendering language and cosmos coextensive. On this basis, the work explains the efficacy of mantra, mudra, and mandala, grounding Shingon ritual in a theory of language-as-reality.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Japanese / Korean – Shinto, Zen, Neo-Confucian Korean lineages","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: A Swiss pastor, his wife, and their four sons are shipwrecked and reach an uninhabited island, where they salvage supplies from their wrecked ship. Using available materials, they build shelters, domesticate animals, cultivate plants, and explore the island’s resources while the father instructs the boys in practical skills. After years of self-reliance, a visiting ship offers rescue, prompting the family to decide whether to leave or remain on the island.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience
Summary Abstract: Csikszentmihalyi defines “flow” as a state of deep absorption in which action and awareness merge, attention is fully focused, and people experience clear goals, immediate feedback, and a balance between challenge and skill. He details the phenomenology and conditions of flow—intense concentration, sense of control, loss of self-consciousness, and altered time perception—and explains how disruptions like anxiety and boredom arise when challenge-skill balance is off. The book examines how individuals can structure work, leisure, and relationships to elicit flow and contends that cultivating such autotelic experiences improves quality of life and psychological complexity.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Primary Subdomain(s): Positive Psychology & Human Potential,Cognitive & Affective Sciences

Summary Abstract: Parag Khanna’s 2021 book examines how climate change, demographic imbalances, technological shifts, and political instability are accelerating large-scale human migration this century. Using data and scenarios, it maps emerging habitable zones and mobility corridors, showing how aging societies and labor shortages will drive competition to attract migrants and reshape urbanization and infrastructure. The book outlines governance and policy approaches—such as skills-based immigration, resettlement planning, and adaptive citizenship—to manage these flows and build resilience.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Cloud of Unknowing and Other Works
Summary Abstract: A collection of late 14th-century English mystical texts, The Cloud of Unknowing and Other Works instructs readers in apophatic, contemplative prayer centered on loving intent rather than discursive thought. The title treatise teaches approaching God by placing all thoughts beneath a “cloud of forgetting” and consenting to a “cloud of unknowing.” The accompanying shorter works elaborate practical guidance for solitary contemplatives on method, humility, and spiritual discernment.

Title of Work: The Manuals of Buddhism: The Expositions of the Buddha-Dhamma
Summary Abstract: A compendium of English translations of Ledi Sayadaw’s dīpanī (“manuals”), this volume systematically expounds Theravāda Buddhist doctrine, prepared by the Union Buddha Sāsana Council’s English Editorial Board. It gathers treatises including Vipassanā-dīpanī, Paṭṭhānuddesa-dīpanī (Buddhist philosophy of relations), Bodhipakkhiyadīpanī (factors of enlightenment), Maggaṅga-dīpanī (path factors), Paramī-dīpanī (perfections), and Nibbāna-dīpanī. Topics span Abhidhamma analysis and sutta-based teachings on causality, meditation, ethics, and core doctrinal categories such as aggregates, sense bases, elements, and kamma–vipāka.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: Edited by Boris Groys and published by MIT Press in 2018, Russian Cosmism collects key texts—many translated into English for the first time—by the Russian Cosmist movement from before the Bolshevik Revolution through the 1920s–30s. It presents Cosmist proposals to abolish death, resurrect the dead, and enable movement in cosmic space; traces the lineage from Nikolai Fedorov to later figures; notes influence on Soviet art, politics, and technology; and documents suppression under Stalin, with contributions by Fedorov, Tsiolkovsky, Bogdanov, Chizhevsky, Svyatogor, Muravyev, Groys, Anton Vidokle, and Brian Kuan Wood.

Title of Work: Trans Bodies, Trans Selves: A Resource for the Transgender Community
Summary Abstract: Trans Bodies, Trans Selves is a comprehensive, community-authored resource for transgender and gender-nonconforming people, combining practical guidance and first-person narratives on physical and mental health, transition, legal and social issues, relationships, and culture. It provides accessible, evidence-informed information for trans readers, their families, and professionals. The 2015 edition includes an introduction by Laverne Cox and contributions from Janet Mock.

Title of Work: New Phenomenology: Embodied Feelings and Atmospheres
Summary Abstract: Hermann Schmitz presents the main theses of New Phenomenology, centering on embodied feelings and atmospheres as subjective facts that involve the felt body, the primitive present, and pre-personal self-consciousness. He articulates a theory of affective involvement and proposes a new solution to the problem of freedom. The book also advances a critique of Western reductionism and introjectivism, including a critique of the contemporary “age of irony”.

Title of Work: Red Skin, White Masks: Rejecting the Colonial Politics of Recognition
Summary Abstract: Glen Coulthard critiques liberal “politics of recognition” in settler colonial contexts, arguing that state-centered recognition often reproduces colonial domination and dispossession rather than overcoming it. Drawing on Frantz Fanon and Marxist analyses of primitive accumulation, he examines Canadian land claims, reconciliation, and multicultural policy to show how recognition can entrench state authority. He advances Indigenous resurgence grounded in land-based practices and “grounded normativity,” emphasizing self-recognition and collective self-determination as an alternative pathway to decolonization.

Title of Work: From the Fatherland, with Love (Violence Psychology)

Summary Abstract: Body and Soul examines the Black Panther Party’s health activism from 1966 to 1980, documenting its network of free health clinics, a 1971 sickle-cell anemia campaign, and efforts to contest medical discrimination. Drawing on archival research and interviews, Nelson situates these initiatives within a longer tradition of African American medical self-help and the Party’s political philosophy that framed health as a basic human right. The book links the Panthers’ community-based care and genetic screening work to broader debates about race, medicine, and access to care in the United States.

Title of Work: The Moment of Lift: How Empowering Women Changes the World
Summary Abstract: Melinda French Gates examines global barriers to women’s empowerment and how addressing them affects health, education, and economic outcomes. Drawing on work through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and accounts from women in multiple countries, she covers family planning, maternal and newborn health, girls’ education, unpaid care work, child marriage, and women’s economic participation. The book describes initiatives, partnerships, and evidence used to expand access and address structural constraints affecting women and girls.

Summary Abstract: A narrative history tracing how people have traversed, settled, fought over, engineered, and imagined the Alpine arc from antiquity to the present across France, Italy, Switzerland, Austria, Germany, and Slovenia. It recounts episodes such as Hannibal’s crossing, Roman and medieval routes, religious movements, nationalism and border-making, the World Wars, and the rise of alpinism, tunnels, and mass tourism. Structured around the author’s journey along major passes and valleys, it interweaves political, cultural, and economic history with the transformation of the Alps by infrastructure and tourism.

Title of Work: The Poor Christ of Bomba: Cameroonian Literature and Colonial Critique (Posthumous Critical Edition)
Summary Abstract: Set in 1930s colonial Cameroon, The Poor Christ of Bomba is a satirical novel told through the journal of Denis, a houseboy to Father Drumont, a Catholic missionary charged with building a parish and preparing village girls for Christian marriage. Through Denis’s observations of Bomba and the mission’s women’s camp, the story reveals the prolonged control of young women and that local churchmen have been using the girls for their own purposes. The narrative culminates in the priest’s realization that imposing conversion is futile upon people who already worshipped God in their own way.

Summary Abstract: Proust and Signs (1964) interprets Marcel Proust’s In Search of Lost Time as an apprenticeship in deciphering signs. Deleuze distinguishes series of signs—worldly (social), amorous, sensuous/material, and artistic—showing how their interpretation leads to the recognition of art as the domain where truth is revealed. He analyzes involuntary memory and experiences such as jealousy as modalities of signs that culminate in the narrator’s turn to writing in Time Regained.

Summary Abstract: Edited by Suzy Green and Stephen Palmer, Positive Psychology Coaching in Practice synthesizes current research and practical methods for integrating positive psychology into evidence-based coaching, contributed by an international group of authors. It surveys theories of wellbeing and flourishing, mindfulness in coaching, relevant neuroscience, character strengths, and applications such as Acceptance and Commitment Training, health and wellness coaching, resilience, positive leadership, and coaching through developmental transitions. Each chapter connects theory to practice with resources and case studies, and the volume concludes with perspectives on future directions for positive psychology coaching.

Summary Abstract: This 2017 collection assembles Jorge N. Ferrer’s essays that introduce and extend his participatory spirituality, proposing that humans co-create spiritual phenomena, worlds, and ultimates. Summary Abstract: This book presents an eight-week mindfulness training program derived from Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy, designed to disrupt cycles of stress, anxiety, and unhappiness. Summary Abstract: Dopamine Nation (2021) by psychiatrist Anna Lembke explores how the brain’s dopamine-driven reward system and the pleasure–pain balance fuel addiction in an era of abundant high-reward stimuli. Using neuroscience and clinical case studies, it shows how everyday behaviors—such as social media, gaming, pornography, food, and drugs—can escalate into compulsive overuse. The book outlines strategies for recovery, including a 30-day abstinence trial, self-binding and accountability measures, and engaging in purposeful activities to recalibrate reward pathways.

Title of Work: Maps of Meaning: The Architecture of Belief
Summary Abstract: Maps of Meaning develops a theory of how humans construct meaning by integrating psychology, neuroscience, mythology, religion, and philosophy. Title of Work: If Women Counted: A New Feminist Economics (Updated Edition)
Summary Abstract: Marilyn Waring analyzes how national income accounting—particularly GDP and the UN System of National Accounts—excludes unpaid domestic and care work and environmental depletion, rendering much of women’s labor and ecological value invisible. Using empirical analysis and international examples, she shows how these omissions distort economic indicators and policy priorities, and outlines approaches such as time-use studies and satellite accounts to recognize unpaid production. The 2018 updated edition adds reflections on subsequent changes in economic statistics and policy debates, underscoring the need to reform how economies measure value.

Summary Abstract: Set in 1882 Vienna, Irvin D. Yalom’s novel imagines meetings between Dr. Josef Breuer and Friedrich Nietzsche arranged by Lou Salomé. Breuer undertakes a discreet “talking cure” for Nietzsche’s migraines and despair, while Nietzsche challenges Breuer’s obsessive attachment to a former patient, forming a mutual therapeutic pact. A young Sigmund Freud appears on the periphery as their dialogues trace a speculative origin of psychotherapy.

Title of Work: Remembering in a World of Forgetting
Summary Abstract: William Stoddart’s 2008 volume compiles essays from the perennialist perspective that critique postmodern ideologies (“forgetting”) and call for a return to traditional religion, particularly its mystical dimensions (“remembering”). Structured in three parts, it treats errors of contemporary ideologies in “Forgetting,” outlines essential doctrinal beliefs in “Remembering (theory),” and presents practice through accounts of visits to Mt. Athos monasteries and an audience with the Jagadguru of Kanchipuram in “Remembering (practice)”. The book also includes previously unpublished articles and excerpts from Stoddart’s correspondence.

Summary Abstract: A Philosophy of Walking examines walking as a philosophical practice and everyday act that shapes thinking, self, and politics. Through studies of notable walkers including Rousseau, Nietzsche, Thoreau, and Kant, Gros traces how solitude, slowness, and freedom relate to movement and to their work. The book distinguishes forms of walking—strolling, hiking, pilgrimages, and protest marches—and analyzes their temporal, spatial, and social dimensions.

Summary Abstract: Black and Female: Essays is a collection by Tsitsi Dangarembga that examines the legacy of empire on her own life and on Black embodied African life. Interweaving memoir and political analysis, the essays recount her early separation from her parents, link personal rupture to histories of trafficking and enslavement, critique post-independence Zimbabwe’s treatment of women, and trace her efforts to build a career in theater, film, and literature.

Summary Abstract: Ilia Delio proposes a “new myth of relational holism” to reimagine the God–world relationship for a global, ecological era shaped by quantum physics, evolution, and pluralism. Guided by Carl Jung and Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, the book traverses science, scripture, theology, history, culture, and psychology to present a relational, integrative vision. It situates humanity between axial periods, seeking renewed connections to divinity through the mind–matter nexus and a holistic view of existence.

Summary Abstract: La Pesanteur et la grâce (1947) is a posthumous compilation of Simone Weil’s notebook fragments, selected and arranged by Gustave Thibon. It presents brief reflections on the contrast between “gravity” (natural necessity and psychological compulsion) and “grace” (supernatural gift), alongside themes such as décréation, attention, affliction (malheur), detachment, and love of God and neighbor. Organized thematically rather than as a continuous treatise, it analyzes the soul’s passage from necessity toward receptivity to grace.

Summary Abstract: College student Anastasia Steele interviews Seattle billionaire Christian Grey, and their attraction leads to a relationship framed by a non-disclosure agreement and a proposed BDSM contract. After an escalating punishment that exposes the extent of his preferences, Anastasia ends the relationship and leaves.

Title of Work: Care Work — Disability Justice & Queer Survival
Summary Abstract: Care Work is a collection of essays that examines the politics and practices of disability justice, centering the lives and leadership of sick and disabled queer, trans, Black, and brown communities. Drawing on the author’s years of cultural and activist work, it outlines models of “collective access” and community care and addresses topics including queer femme emotional labor, suicide in queer/trans communities, and the logistics of touring as a disabled artist of color. The work documents how disabled and queer networks create accessible spaces to find one another, build power, and support survival.

Summary Abstract: Ainulindalë recounts the creation of the universe Eä by Eru Ilúvatar through the Great Music sung by the Ainur. Melkor introduces discord into the themes, which Ilúvatar incorporates before revealing a vision that he then makes real; some Ainur enter this world as the Valar to shape it. The text establishes the origins of Arda and foretells the coming of the Children of Ilúvatar, Elves and Men.

Title of Work: The Book You Want Everyone You Love to Read
Summary Abstract: Psychotherapist Philippa Perry presents a guide to understanding, maintaining, and improving relationships across couples, families, friends, and colleagues. She explains how attachment patterns, defensive habits, and personal narratives shape communication and conflict, and outlines skills such as attentive listening, boundary-setting, emotional regulation, and rupture-and-repair. Summary Abstract: Things as They Are; or, The Adventures of Caleb Williams (1794) by William Godwin follows Caleb, a young secretary to aristocrat Ferdinando Falkland, who discovers evidence that Falkland murdered his rival Tyrrel. When Caleb seeks to expose the crime, Falkland orchestrates a theft charge that leads to Caleb’s imprisonment, escape, and pursuit by authorities and informers across England. The story culminates in a public confrontation between Caleb and Falkland that brings the concealed crime to light.

Title of Work: Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee: An Indian History of the American West
Summary Abstract: Dee Brown’s 1970 nonfiction history narrates the westward expansion of the United States from the 1860s to 1890 from the perspectives of Native American nations. Drawing on council records, speeches, and eyewitness accounts, it details U.S. treaties, military campaigns, and forced removals affecting tribes including the Navajo, Cheyenne, Lakota and other Sioux groups, Nez Perce, and Apache. It covers events such as the Sand Creek Massacre, the Long Walk, Red Cloud’s War, the Nez Perce flight, and concludes with the 1890 massacre at Wounded Knee.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous North American – First Nations, Native American traditions","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Death and Life of Great American Cities
Summary Abstract: Jacobs critiques mid-20th-century urban renewal and top-down, modernist planning that separated land uses and dispersed urban populations. She contends that urban vitality depends on mixed primary uses, short blocks, a diversity of building ages, and a dense concentration of people, enabling sidewalk life and “eyes on the street” that support safety and social interaction. The book advocates incremental, community-based planning and treats cities as problems of organized complexity, highlighting the importance of local economies and everyday street-level interactions.

Summary Abstract: Howard W. French examines how China’s imperial-era concepts—especially tianxia (“all under heaven”) and the tributary system—inform its contemporary pursuit of regional primacy and wider influence. Drawing on historical analysis and reporting across East and Southeast Asia, the book connects Ming and Qing legacies, such as maritime expeditions and frontier management, to current diplomacy, strategy, and territorial claims, notably in the South China Sea. It situates China’s relations with neighbors including Japan, Vietnam, and Korea within these continuities and delineates the stakes of ongoing U.S.-China competition.

Title of Work: Cooperative Alternatives to Capitalism in South Africa
Summary Abstract: This work examines worker cooperatives in South Africa as alternatives to capitalist enterprise, situating them within the global cooperative movement and emphasizing principles such as democratic ownership, one-member-one-vote, collective decision-making, and solidarity. It traces a historical trajectory from apartheid-era cooperative formations to post-apartheid policies, identifying a dual landscape of emerging Black cooperatives focused on local development and established, largely white cooperatives concentrated in agro-processing with substantial assets. Based on interviews, field visits, and literature, it argues that adopting an Afrikaner empowerment–style, business-first approach under Black Economic Empowerment has distorted cooperative development, undermining genuine cooperatives grounded in cooperative identity and values.

Summary Abstract: Why School?: Reclaiming Education for All of Us (2009) by Mike Rose collects essays that investigate the purposes and practices of American education from K–12 through community colleges. The book analyzes the effects of standards-based reform and high-stakes testing on teaching and opportunity while documenting the cognitive demands of blue-collar work.

Summary Abstract: The Art of War is an ancient Chinese book by Sun Tzu about how to plan and win conflicts while avoiding waste. Summary Abstract: Hippocrates argues that the “sacred disease” (epilepsy) is not divine but has natural causes rooted in the brain. He criticizes priests and purifiers for invoking the gods to mask ignorance and offers a physiological account centered on phlegm obstructing cerebral passages and disturbing function. The treatise situates the disease within patterned causes—age, heredity, and environment—and insists it is amenable to rational observation and treatment.

Title of Work: Mind in the Balance: Meditation in Science, Buddhism, and Christianity
Summary Abstract: B. Alan Wallace examines meditation through a dialogue among Buddhism, Christianity, and modern science and philosophy, highlighting convergences in their approaches to consciousness and the objective world. Summary Abstract: Antonio Damasio presents a biological account of consciousness, arguing that feelings—the mental experiences of the body’s homeostatic states—are the foundation of subjective awareness. He distinguishes mind, feeling, and consciousness, explaining how neural mappings of the body and environment transform life regulation into knowledge of self and world. The book traces an evolutionary path from simple organisms’ homeostasis to human consciousness, showing how language and culture elaborate, but are not required for, the core conscious state.

Cynthia Bourgeault investigates the imaginal realm—an energetic domain recognized in mystical traditions, invisible to the physical eye yet perceptible through the “eye of the heart.”
Blending personal experience with research, she explores its links to dreams, prophecy, and oracles, its role within Christian and other mystical traditions, and its bearing on an evolutionary, collective human purpose.
The book outlines how inner consciousness relates to events in the world and presents ways to cooperate with the imaginal realm’s guidance in daily life.

Title of Work: Debt, Development, and the Politics of Reconstruction in Sri Lanka
Summary Abstract: This work analyzes post-war reconstruction in Sri Lanka’s Jaffna District through a mixed-methods study—combining a village survey and ethnography in Pathemany/Bharathy Veethy with national and regional data—to examine land, rural incomes, debt, and caste dynamics. It argues that reconstruction after 2009 extended a second wave of neoliberal reforms and financialization, expanding credit and predatory lending that entrenched rural indebtedness and dispossession. The study documents the persistence and reconfiguration of caste exclusion in the post-war economy and highlights producer co-operatives as components of alternative reconstruction pathways, framing reconstruction as a fundamentally political question.

Summary Abstract: Kathryn Gin Lum examines how the category of the “heathen” has structured American understandings of religion, race, and nationhood across U.S. history. Title of Work: Tell Me How It Ends: An Essay in 40 Questions (pbk ed.)
Summary Abstract: A nonfiction essay, it is structured around the 40 questions on a U.S. immigration intake questionnaire, drawn from the author’s work as a volunteer interpreter for child migrants in New York. It follows unaccompanied children from Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, detailing their journeys, the legal processes they encounter in the United States, and the surge in arrivals beginning in 2014. The narrative interweaves case histories, procedural context, and background on drivers of migration such as gang violence, insecurity, and U.S. policy in the region.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Alexander R. Galloway presents one of the first extended English-language surveys of François Laruelle’s non-standard philosophy, treating the digital as a philosophical concept and juxtaposing Laruelle’s “One” with its binary counterpart, the “Zero”. Part I explicates Laruelle’s key ideas (e.g., the philosophical decision and the principle of sufficient philosophy) within continental debates, while Part II proposes a withdrawal from the “Standard Model” via engagements with computers, capitalism, art/utopia, ethics, and the generic. The book explores links among media, philosophy, and technology and characterizes Laruelle as a distinctly non-digital thinker.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: Therapeutic Care for Refugees: No Place Like Home
Summary Abstract: An edited volume in the Tavistock Clinic Series, Therapeutic Care for Refugees: No Place Like Home addresses the complexities of refugee mental health by integrating theory, research, and clinical and field applications within a psychotherapeutic framework. It balances recognition of refugees’ resilience with attention to psychological needs without pathologizing, delineates intersecting psychological, socio-political, legal, organizational, and ethical dimensions, and outlines therapeutic work with individuals, families, and groups while advocating therapeutic principles across all services. Drawing on work developed at the Tavistock Clinic in London, it was published in 2002.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Set on Otsego Lake (“the Glimmerglass”) in mid-18th-century New York, the novel follows young frontiersman Natty Bumppo (Deerslayer) and his Mohican companion Chingachgook as they confront Huron warriors while seeking to rescue Chingachgook’s betrothed, Wah-ta!-Wah (Hist). Drawn into the plight of the Hutter family at their floating “castle,” they endure sieges, captures, and exchanges that test Deerslayer’s strict code regarding honor and violence. The story concludes with Hist restored to Chingachgook and Deerslayer rejecting Judith Hutter’s hopes for marriage as he returns to the wilderness.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Indigenous North American – First Nations, Native American traditions","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: Becoming Wise: An Inquiry into the Mystery and Art of Living (10th Anniversary)
Summary Abstract: Becoming Wise (2016) by Krista Tippett distills insights from her years of interviews on the public radio/podcast project On Being into an exploration of how people make meaning and live well. Structured around five themes—words, flesh, love, faith, and hope—it synthesizes perspectives from science, the arts, religion, and civic life. Drawing on conversations and reportage, the book traces recurring practices and ideas that shape personal life and public culture.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Tarot for All Ages is a 78-card tarot deck with an accompanying booklet, designed as a fully functional deck to introduce younger and beginner readers (ages 11+) to tarot, and was published in 2021. It follows the traditional structure of 22 Major and 56 Minor Arcana and includes simple instructions for conducting readings.

On Logic is a treatise attributed to the Stoic philosopher Chrysippus, now lost and known only through later reports. It expounded the foundations of Stoic propositional logic, covering assertibles (axiōmata) and lekta, the five indemonstrable argument schemata, and the analysis of truth-functional conditionals and disjunctions within the Stoic program of dialectic.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
Summary Abstract: Cal Newport presents “digital minimalism,” a philosophy for intentionally aligning technology use with core values to support focus and meaningful activity. The book prescribes a 30-day “digital declutter” that removes optional technologies, followed by selective reintroduction using strict value-based criteria. It outlines practices to cultivate solitude and high-quality leisure, constrain social media and smartphone use, and redesign routines to reduce compulsive engagement driven by the attention economy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Black Elk Speaks: Being the Life Story of a Holy Man of the Oglala Sioux
Summary Abstract: An autobiographical narrative of Oglala Lakota holy man Black Elk, the work recounts his childhood and the defining Great Vision that shaped his spiritual role. He describes participation in and witness to major events of the late 19th century, including the Battle of the Little Bighorn, the Ghost Dance movement, and the Wounded Knee Massacre, while conveying Lakota ceremonies and cosmology. The account follows his life through U.S. expansion, reservation era changes, and travels with Buffalo Bill’s Wild West show.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous North American – First Nations, Native American traditions"

Summary Abstract: Caravan of No Despair is Mirabai Starr’s memoir of the aftermath of her teenage daughter’s sudden death and her journey through grief. Drawing on Christian mysticism, Buddhism, Sufism, and other interspiritual practices, she recounts how she navigated mourning, questioned inherited beliefs, and reshaped her life around service and teaching. The narrative interweaves personal loss with reflections on ritual, community, and contemplative disciplines as ways to live with grief.

Title of Work: Gettysburg Surgeons: Facing a Common Enemy

Summary Abstract: Poetic Reason (razón poética) is María Zambrano’s term for a philosophical method that integrates discursive reason with poetic intuition to access knowledge grounded in lived experience and the symbolic or sacred dimension. She developed this approach programmatically in Claros del bosque (1977), advancing her project of reconciling philosophy and poetry. Poetic Reason frames thinking as an existential path that often intersects with mysticism and revelation rather than purely systematic rationality.

Summary Abstract: Set in post-Soviet Kyiv, the novel follows Viktor, a struggling writer who adopts a penguin named Misha from a bankrupt zoo. Hired by a newspaper to write advance obituaries for prominent figures, he discovers the subjects begin dying, drawing him into the world of organized crime and corrupt officials. As danger mounts, Viktor tries to protect the penguin and a child left in his care while seeking a way out.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Why Grow Up? Subversive Thoughts for an Infantile Age
Summary Abstract: Susan Neiman argues that growing up is an ethical and intellectual achievement rather than a decline, drawing on Enlightenment thinkers like Kant and Rousseau to define maturity as sustaining ideals while confronting reality. She critiques cultural, educational, and economic forces that encourage perpetual adolescence. The book applies this framework to education, work, love, and politics to sketch practices for cultivating autonomy and hope.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Dianaworld: An Obsession is a cultural history and “exploded biography” of Diana, Princess of Wales, examining how her life and afterlife became a global myth and all-purpose cultural symbol. Edward White maps “Dianaworld” through group portraits of intimates, colleagues, and ordinary admirers to chart the obsessions and social forces that formed around her. Using interviews and unconventional sources—including the Mass Observation and Great Diary projects, professional lookalikes, and sex workers—the book reconstructs Diana’s milieu and assesses her enduring cultural impact.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Woman to Man (1949) is Judith Wright’s second poetry collection, following The Moving Image (1946). It gathers poems about fertility, conception, pregnancy, and the creative union between woman and man, alongside reflections on love and the Australian natural world. The title poem speaks from a woman’s perspective to her partner about the coming-into-being of a child, employing recurrent images of seed, blood, and growth.
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "Oceania – Australia, New Zealand, Polynesia, Micronesia, Melanesia",Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: Words of My Perfect Teacher (kunzang lama’i shelung)
Summary Abstract: Words of My Perfect Teacher (Kunzang Lama’i Shelung) by Patrul Rinpoche (1808–1887) is a 19th-century guide to the Longchen Nyingthig preliminary practices (ngöndro) of the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism. It sets out the four thoughts that turn the mind—precious human life, impermanence and death, karma, and the defects of samsara—and the extraordinary preliminaries: taking refuge and generating bodhicitta, Vajrasattva purification, mandala offering, and guru yoga. Drawing on scriptural citations and oral instructions, it details view, meditation, and conduct for practitioners within the Dzogchen tradition.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Tibetan / Himalayan – Tibetan Buddhism, Bön"

Title of Work: The Self-Authenticating Truth: Essays from The Aletheon
Author Full Name: Franklin Albert Jones (Bubba Free John, Da Free John, Adi Da Samraj)
Summary Abstract: The Self-Authenticating Truth: Essays from The Aletheon is a 110-page collection by Adi Da Samraj (Franklin Albert Jones), published by Dawn Horse Press in 2007, presenting selections from his larger scripture The Aletheon. The essays outline key elements of his Adidam teaching—especially the devotional guru–devotee way and the assertion of Reality Itself as the “Self-Authenticating Truth” or “Perfect Knowledge”—within a framework of “radical” devotion and recognition-responsive turning.
