Title of Work: Eternal Flame: The Authorized Biography of The Bangles
Summary Abstract: This authorized biography chronicles The Bangles from their 1981 formation through their rapid rise in the 1980s Los Angeles scene and MTV era, including major hits such as Manic Monday, Walk Like an Egyptian, and Hazy Shade of Winter. Focusing on the band’s first eight years, it uses exclusive access and interviews with founding members Debbi Peterson, Susanna Hoffs, and Vicki Peterson to chart touring, collaborations, and chart success alongside internal tensions and the pressures of sudden fame that led to their breakup. The book also documents the gendered barriers the band faced in a media and music industry often stacked against women artists.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: The Romance of the State: And the Fate of Dissent in the Tropics (Updated Edition)
Summary Abstract: This collection of essays examines the allure of the modern nation-state in India, analyzing its social, political, and cultural consequences and the fate of dissent. It addresses mainstream political ideas—including secularism, development, and terrorism—alongside practices of dissent, tracing how state-centered ideologies shape political culture.

Summary Abstract: Azuma argues that, following the collapse of grand narratives in postmodern Japan, otaku consumption shifts from stories to a database of character attributes (“moe elements”), privileging affect and character-centered engagement over plot coherence. He terms this shift an “animalization” of desire, where consumers browse and recombine simulacral elements from a shared database, a model used to explain contemporary media production and fandom. The essay situates otaku practices within broader postmodern cultural and economic logics of database-driven consumption.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Belonging: A Culture of Place (2009) is a collection of essays in which bell hooks examines questions of home, community, and belonging through a cyclical movement between country and city that culminates in a return to Kentucky. She addresses land and land ownership, the history and present of Black agrarian life and local organic food production, and how environmental sustainability intersects with race, class, real-estate racism, housing segregation, and racialized zoning.

Title of Work: Captivating Technology: Race, Carceral Technoscience, and Liberatory Imagination in Everyday Life
Summary Abstract: An edited collection by Ruha Benjamin, this book examines how carceral logics are embedded in contemporary science and technology, producing racialized surveillance, sorting, and control across institutions such as policing, healthcare, education, and welfare. Through case studies of tools like biometrics, predictive analytics, electronic monitoring, and databases, contributors trace how “carceral technoscience” extends beyond prisons into everyday life. The volume also documents abolitionist and community-driven design practices that cultivate liberatory imaginaries and alternative technological futures.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Sad Part Was is a 2017 short story collection by Thai author Prabda Yoon, translated from Thai by Mui Poopoksakul and published by Tilted Axis Press. Through its stories, the book portrays contemporary Bangkok life and the tensions between modern urban experience and traditional Thai ideas about relationships, family, school, and work. It employs postmodern techniques, including experiments with punctuation, metafictional framing, and references to pop culture and occasional sci‑fi motifs.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Biocentrism: How Life and Consciousness are the Keys to Understanding the True Nature of the Universe
Summary Abstract: The book advances biocentrism, the thesis that life and consciousness are fundamental and that reality arises from observers rather than existing independently. Drawing on interpretations of quantum mechanics, relativity, and cosmological fine-tuning, it argues that space and time are constructs of the mind and articulates seven principles of biocentrism. It explores implications for cosmology and the nature of death, proposing that perception shapes what we call the external world.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a Fck*
Summary Abstract: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck (2016) by Mark Manson is a self-help book that advocates prioritizing limited attention and caring only about values within one’s control. It argues that embracing life’s inevitable problems, accepting negative experiences, and taking responsibility are pathways to meaning rather than pursuing constant positivity. Manson outlines principles such as choosing better values, setting boundaries, confronting uncertainty and failure, and recognizing how suffering and mortality clarify what matters.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: The Book of Psalms (Tehillim) is a collection of 150 Hebrew poems and songs traditionally attributed to David and other authors, compiled across centuries from the monarchic to post-exilic periods and arranged into five books. It includes laments, hymns of praise, thanksgiving, royal, and wisdom psalms, characterized by parallelism and vivid imagery. Composed for worship in the First and Second Temples and later incorporated into synagogue and church liturgies, it remains central to Jewish and Christian prayer and music.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Middle East – Levant,Middle East – Mesopotamia,Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: Work on democratic transition, youth & participatory reform
Summary Abstract: Analyzing Egypt on the eve of the Arab uprisings, this work examines how youth-led initiatives and participatory reform efforts intersected with a semi-authoritarian system that permitted controlled liberalization while constraining genuine political inclusion. It argues that donor-backed civil society strategies were often co-opted or neutralized by the regime’s legal and administrative controls, limiting their capacity to catalyze democratic transition and underscoring the need for authentic channels of youth participation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: The Enlightenment of the Whole Body
Summary Abstract: A collection of talks and essays, The Enlightenment of the Whole Body presents Bubba Free John’s nondual teaching that enlightenment is a whole-bodily awakening to prior consciousness rather than a merely mental or otherworldly attainment. It sets out the process of “radical understanding” of the egoic self‑contraction, emphasizing whole‑bodily surrender to the Guru and disciplined life practices (including breath and bodily conductivity). The work critiques traditional modes of spiritual “seeking” and outlines stages of practice culminating in realization of the Heart, or inherent nonseparateness.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: Sketches by Boz (1836) is a collection of short descriptive pieces by Charles Dickens (writing as “Boz”) depicting everyday life, characters, and settings in early 19th-century London. Most sketches were first published in periodicals between 1833 and 1836 and are organized into the sections “Our Parish,” “Scenes,” “Characters,” and “Tales.” The 1836 edition appeared in two volumes and was illustrated by George Cruikshank.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Beautyful Ones Are Not Yet Born
Summary Abstract: Set in post-independence Ghana during the final years of Kwame Nkrumah’s rule and the 1966 coup, the novel follows an unnamed railway clerk who struggles to remain honest amid pervasive corruption. Pressured by his wife Oyo and drawn into the orbit of the affluent minister Joseph Koomson, he witnesses how patronage and graft shape daily life. After the coup, he helps Koomson escape and returns to his job, with the corrupt system around him unchanged.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Lectures from Colombo to Almora is a collection of public addresses delivered by Swami Vivekananda in 1897 during his return to India, tracing his journey from Colombo to the Himalayan town of Almora. The lectures present Vedanta and its practical application to personal and national life, emphasizing self-strength, service to the poor, education, women’s uplift, and unity beyond sect and caste. Vivekananda also outlines organized social service and monastic work that coalesced as the Ramakrishna Mission in 1897, and articulates India’s role in the harmony of religions.

Title of Work: The Arsonists' City: Arab-American Literature and Cultural Memory
Summary Abstract: Hala Alyan’s The Arsonists’ City (2021) follows the transnational Nasr family—Lebanese father Idris, Syrian mother Mazna, and their three adult children—who reunite in Beirut when Idris decides to sell the family’s ancestral home. Moving between the present and the parents’ pasts in Beirut and Damascus, the narrative uncovers long‑hidden secrets shaped by war, migration, and personal choices. The novel traces how these histories inform the siblings’ lives across the United States, illuminating diasporic identity and cultural memory.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Myself Must I Remake: The Life and Poetry of W.B. Yeats
Summary Abstract: Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak’s 1974 monograph analyzes the interrelation of W.B. Yeats’s life and poetry, using close readings across his career to show how biographical and historical contexts inform his verse. It traces the shift from early “Celtic Twilight” romanticism to the later austere style, emphasizing recurring motifs of self-remaking, nationalism, myth, and the occult. The study situates Yeats’s oeuvre amid Irish political upheavals and his intellectual pursuits (including A Vision), detailing how these forces shaped the development of his poetics.

Title of Work: The Power of Concentration — William Walker Atkinson (Theron Q. Dumont) (1918, Paris/Chicago)
Author Full Name: William Walker Atkinson (as Theron Q. Dumont)
Summary Abstract: The Power of Concentration is a self-improvement manual that teaches developing sustained attention and willpower through a progressive series of short lessons and daily exercises. It presents practical methods for directing thought, eliminating distractions, building self-control, and applying focused attention to work, study, habits, and personal aims. Published in 1918 in Paris and Chicago under the pseudonym Theron Q. Dumont (William Walker Atkinson), it advances concentration as the organizing principle of deliberate action.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Albert Camus’s 1942 philosophical essay examines the “absurd,” the clash between humanity’s search for meaning and an indifferent universe, and asks whether suicide is a logical response. He critiques “philosophical suicide” and outlines revolt, freedom, and passion as lucid responses to the absurd, drawing on analyses of figures such as Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Dostoevsky, and Kafka. The work culminates in the image of Sisyphus as an emblem of conscious perseverance in a meaningless world.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In
Summary Abstract: Getting to Yes presents a method of principled negotiation developed at the Harvard Negotiation Project for reaching agreements without relying on positional bargaining. It instructs negotiators to separate people from the problem, focus on interests rather than positions, invent options for mutual gain, and insist on objective criteria. The book introduces the concept of BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) and outlines approaches for addressing difficult tactics and communication barriers.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: Rehearsals for Dying: Digressions on Love and Cancer
Summary Abstract: Ariel Gore chronicles the four years following her wife Deena’s terminal diagnosis with metastatic breast cancer, intertwining their personal journey with accounts from others living with the disease. The book weaves caregiving, medical treatment, insurance, and pain with literary reflections and reportage on the history of breast cancer and the modern industry around screenings and therapies. It challenges prevailing awareness narratives to depict what it means to be diagnosed with, treat, and live—and die—with breast cancer in the twenty-first century.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Problem with Work: Feminism, Marxism, Antiwork Politics, and Postwork Imaginaries
Summary Abstract: Kathi Weeks analyzes the historical and ideological centrality of waged work in capitalist societies, integrating Marxist and feminist theory to critique the work ethic and the gendered organization of labor, including unpaid reproductive work. She develops an antiwork politics that treats work as a site of domination and revisits movements such as Wages for Housework to reconceptualize labor and political subjectivity. The book advances postwork imaginaries through “utopian demands” like shorter working hours and a universal basic income, aiming to decenter employment as the organizing principle of social life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: 1492 - El encubrimiento del otro: Hacia el origen del "mito de la modernidad"
Summary Abstract: Enrique Dussel argues that European modernity originates in the 1492 conquest of the Americas, which entails the “encubrimiento” (concealment) of the Indigenous Other rather than a purely internal European awakening. He reconstructs the “myth of modernity” as an ideological narrative that legitimates colonial domination as civilizing progress and helps constitute a Eurocentric center–periphery world-system. The work advances an ethics of liberation and the notion of transmodernity to ground intercultural dialogue from the exteriority of those oppressed by coloniality.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: An Upper East Side housewife becomes unsettled when people suggest that the protagonist of her novelist husband's smash new book was modeled on her. After finding a newspaper clipping about a missing woman in his study, she grows suspicious that he may be connected and starts searching for proof. As coincidences and rumors accumulate, she withdraws from daily routines and pursues her own inquiry into the disappearance and her husband's private life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: A palm-wine addict sets out to recover his deceased tapster in the Deads’ Town after the tapster falls and dies. Accompanied by his wife, he journeys through a Yoruba spirit-world, confronting supernatural beings, monstrous creatures, and perilous towns, surviving by charms and cunning. The episodic quest culminates in his arrival in the land of the dead after many trials.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "African Indigenous – Yoruba, Ifá, Akan, San, Bantu, Dogon"

Summary Abstract: Set in Paris at the dawn of the modern age, Prince Sebastian secretly becomes the glamorous Lady Crystallia at night while his parents search for him a bride. He hires seamstress Frances to design his dresses, and together they balance Crystallia’s growing fame with Sebastian’s need for secrecy and Frances’s ambition to make her name in fashion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Belong (2018) presents a framework for identifying your values and interests, auditing your current relationships, and intentionally building and sustaining a community. Drawing on the author’s experience founding the Daybreaker movement, it details how to design gatherings, define culture and rituals, welcome and engage members, and scale communities over time. The book includes exercises, checklists, and templates to guide planning and implementation.

Summary Abstract: In 1685, Irish physician Peter Blood is wrongly convicted of treason for treating a wounded rebel during the Monmouth Rebellion and transported in chains to slavery in Barbados. During a Spanish raid he and fellow convicts seize a ship, adopt the name Captain Blood, and wage a successful pirate campaign across the Caribbean while crossing paths with his former master Colonel Bishop and Bishop’s niece Arabella. After the Glorious Revolution, Blood aids England against the French, receives a royal pardon, and returns to lawful service.

Proslogion is a theological-philosophical meditation by Anselm of Canterbury composed c. 1077–1078, seeking understanding of God by reason (fides quaerens intellectum). It articulates the ontological argument by defining God as “that than which nothing greater can be conceived,” concluding that such a being exists in reality and necessarily. Subsequent chapters infer divine attributes—unity, eternity, omnipotence, goodness, and immutability—from this conception, and maintain that God cannot be thought not to exist.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: Anita Desai’s 1984 novel follows Deven, a small-town Hindi lecturer and devotee of Urdu poetry, who is persuaded to interview the aging Urdu poet Nur in Delhi. Deven’s plan to tape-record and preserve Nur’s verse entangles him in the poet’s complex household and a web of logistical, financial, and institutional obstacles that thwart the project. The narrative uses Deven’s compromised “custody” of Nur’s work to depict the decline of Urdu literary culture and the fraught politics between Hindi and Urdu in post-independence India.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh"

Summary Abstract: Twilight of the Idols, or How to Philosophize with a Hammer (1888), is Friedrich Nietzsche’s concise polemic summarizing his critique of Western philosophy, morality, and contemporary German culture. In aphoristic chapters such as “The Problem of Socrates,” “Reason in Philosophy,” “How the ‘True World’ Finally Became a Fable,” “Morality as Anti-Nature,” and “The Four Great Errors,” he challenges metaphysical dualisms, Christian morality, and doctrines like free will. The work articulates his program of a “revaluation of all values,” emphasizing life, instinct, and the critique of ascetic ideals.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Herbert Marcuse’s Eros and Civilization (1955) synthesizes Freud’s psychoanalytic theory with Marxian social critique to argue that advanced industrial society imposes “surplus-repression” via a “performance principle” beyond what is needed for basic social order. He contends that modern technological capacity could reduce necessary labor and enable a less repressive civilization where libidinal energies are redirected through non-alienated work, play, and aesthetic experience. The book reinterprets Eros, the death drive, sublimation, and the reality principle to outline historical conditions under which freedom and pleasure might be reconciled.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A wave of anomalous oceanic events—coordinated marine animal attacks, toxic blooms, and methane-hydrate destabilizations triggering disasters—erupts worldwide. Investigators determine the incidents are orchestrated by a collective, intelligent deep-sea lifeform responding to human exploitation. An international task force works to understand and communicate with the entity amid political and military pressures, forcing a reassessment of humanity’s relationship with the oceans.

Title of Work: The Art of Living: Wisdom for the New Millennium
Summary Abstract: This book compiles Sri Sri Ravi Shankar’s short discourses on applying timeless Indian spiritual principles to modern life. It covers managing the mind and emotions, stress, relationships, and ethics, emphasizing awareness, human values, and social responsibility. The work outlines simple daily practices—especially breathing and meditation—to cultivate steadiness and clarity in everyday situations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Title of Work: Reflections on a Mountain Lake: Teachings on Practical Buddhism
Summary Abstract: A collection of talks by Jetsunma Tenzin Palmo, this book presents practical instructions for integrating Tibetan Buddhist practice into everyday life. Topics include meditation and mindfulness, cultivating compassion and bodhicitta, working with emotions and obstacles, understanding karma, death, and impermanence, and reflections on women and monasticism in Buddhism.

Title of Work: Move Your DNA: Restore Your Health Through Natural Movement
Summary Abstract: Katy Bowman explains how modern environments constrain movement diversity and volume, altering mechanical loads on the body down to the cellular level. She distinguishes exercise from varied everyday movement and links load diversity to musculoskeletal, metabolic, and pelvic floor health. The book presents biomechanical principles and practical guidelines—integrating walking, squatting, hanging, and carrying; modifying footwear and furniture use; and reconfiguring routines—to reintroduce natural movement throughout the day. It includes corrective exercises and programs aimed at restoring alignment and movement capacity.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy (Final Edition)
Summary Abstract: Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy collects 23 essays in which art critic Dave Hickey examines how art and popular culture operate in everyday American life and within a democratic context. Ranging across jazz, rock-and-roll, basketball, professional wrestling, magic, psychedelia, gambling, “little stores,” automotive design, television, and cartoons, the pieces include profiles of Liberace, Hank Williams, Chet Baker, Andy Warhol, Johnny Mercer, Norman Rockwell, Siegfried & Roy, and the wrestler Lady Godiva. The collection emphasizes how cultural life in a democracy can function through the whims of affection and the commerce of opinion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Primary Subdomain(s): Aesthetics & Philosophy of Art,Visual Arts & Architecture

Title of Work: The Acts of King Arthur and His Noble Knights
Summary Abstract: The Acts of King Arthur and His Noble Knights is John Steinbeck’s unfinished modern English retelling of episodes from Sir Thomas Malory’s Le Morte d’Arthur, published posthumously in 1976. It covers Arthur’s ascension, the founding of the Round Table, and early adventures of Arthur and his knights.

Title of Work: A History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps
Summary Abstract: A History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps is a project by Peter Adamson, begun in 2010, that presents a chronological survey of philosophy designed to include lesser-known figures and traditions. It is primarily delivered as a podcast series covering ancient Greek and Roman thought, late antiquity, medieval Latin and the Islamic world, and later periods. Portions of the series have been adapted into companion books published by Oxford University Press.

This selected volume presents just over a hundred poems by Brendan Kennelly, edited by Terence Brown and Michael Longley from across his body of work.

Summary Abstract: Published in 1671, John Milton’s volume contains Paradise Regained and Samson Agonistes. Paradise Regained, a four-book sequel to Paradise Lost, narrates Christ’s forty-day temptation in the wilderness and his refusal of Satan’s offers, affirming obedience to God. Samson Agonistes, a tragic closet drama modeled on Greek tragedy, portrays the blinded Samson in Philistine captivity culminating in his pulling down the temple of Dagon and dying with his foes.

Summary Abstract: Revolution is the 2017 English translation of Emmanuel Macron’s book presenting his biography and political program ahead of his 2017 presidential campaign. It recounts his path through education, investment banking, and government, the creation of En Marche!, and his departure from the Hollande administration. The book outlines proposals on labor‑market flexibility, entrepreneurship, education and vocational training, modernization of social protections, and deeper European integration.

Summary Abstract: Oppression et Liberté is a posthumous 1955 collection of Simone Weil’s political and philosophical essays examining the causes and mechanisms of social oppression in modern industrial society. It critically analyzes Marxism and the roles of bureaucracy, technology, and economic necessity, showing how impersonal structures of force constrain individuals and communities. The volume also outlines conditions for genuine liberty beyond party politics and centralization, focusing on limits, responsibility, and concrete human needs.

Summary Abstract: The Analects (Lunyu) is a classical Chinese text collecting sayings, dialogues, and teachings attributed to Confucius and his disciples, compiled after his lifetime. Organized into twenty books, it addresses ethical self-cultivation and social order through concepts such as ren (humaneness), li (ritual propriety), yi (rightness), and xiao (filial piety). It delineates the qualities of the junzi (exemplary person), emphasizes education and self-discipline, and outlines principles of moral governance.

Title of Work: Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy
Summary Abstract: Cathy O’Neil examines how opaque, large-scale algorithms—“weapons of math destruction”—in education, criminal justice, finance, employment, and policing operate with little accountability. She defines these systems by their opacity, scale, and capacity for harm, showing how flawed proxies and feedback loops amplify bias, burden the poor, and erode democratic processes. Through case studies such as teacher evaluations, credit scoring, targeted advertising, and recidivism risk models, the book details mechanisms of unfair outcomes and proposes remedies like transparency, auditing, and regulation.

Working to Restore (2023) by Esha Chhabra surveys enterprises around the world that apply regenerative and circular approaches to address environmental and social challenges. Using case studies across agriculture, apparel, energy, and waste, it documents models that rebuild soil health, conserve resources, reduce pollution, and support workers and communities. The book outlines shared practices—such as designing out waste, using renewable inputs, localizing supply chains, and ensuring fair labor—as a framework for restorative business.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Marginalian is an online publication by Maria Popova founded in 2006 that explores ideas across literature, philosophy, art, and science. Originally launched as Brain Pickings, it was renamed The Marginalian in 2021. It features essays and curated readings drawing on books, archives, and historical figures.

Summary Abstract: Kenkairon (Treatise on the Bodhisattva Precepts) is an 818 treatise by Saichō arguing for a Mahayana ordination platform on Mount Hiei that would confer only the bodhisattva precepts, based primarily on the Brahma Net Sutra (Fanwang jing), independent of the Nara schools’ Vinaya system. Compiling extensive scriptural citations, it contends that the bodhisattva precepts are sufficient and superior for monastic discipline in the Mahayana and that traditional Vinaya ordination is unnecessary for bodhisattvas. The work also outlines Tendai training regulations, including a twelve-year retreat on Mount Hiei, and petitions the court for authorization of this new system.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Japanese / Korean – Shinto, Zen, Neo-Confucian Korean lineages","Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: Delacroix’s Journal is a posthumously published diary compiled from his notebooks spanning 1822–1863, issued in 1893. It records his daily studio practice, experiments with color and composition, and observations on the Paris art world and contemporaries. The entries also document his travels (notably the 1832 Moroccan journey), reading in literature and music, and preparations for major paintings and public commissions.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: John Markoff’s 2015 book traces the history of AI and robotics, contrasting the pursuit of autonomous machines with the intelligence-augmentation tradition that enhances human capabilities. Through episodes from mid-20th-century cybernetics to Silicon Valley labs and DARPA’s Grand Challenges, it profiles researchers, institutions, and systems in robotics, self-driving cars, and machine learning. The work examines how these technical paths shape societal outcomes in areas such as labor, security, and privacy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Archive Fever: Uses of the Document in Contemporary Art (Final Work)
Summary Abstract: Curated by Okwui Enwezor in 2008, Archive Fever: Uses of the Document in Contemporary Art examines how contemporary artists appropriate, stage, and interrogate archival materials and documentary practices. Drawing on Jacques Derrida’s concept of the archive, it surveys photographic, filmic, and mixed‑media works that reconstruct histories, memory, and identity through found images, records, and counter‑archives. The project maps artists’ strategies of collecting, classifying, and recontextualizing documents to address the politics of evidence and institutional memory.

Title of Work: Novacene: The Coming Age of Hyperintelligence (Final Work)
Summary Abstract: James Lovelock proposes that the Anthropocene will give way to the Novacene, an epoch in which self‑designed, non‑biological, hyperintelligent entities emerge from human technology and rapidly surpass human cognition. Extending his Gaia hypothesis, he argues these beings will act to preserve a stable, life‑supporting climate because their own operation depends on a well‑regulated planet, leading to a form of planetary co‑evolution with humans. The book integrates Gaia theory, thermodynamics and information theory, astrobiology, and energy policy (including advocacy of nuclear power) to outline the coming transition and its implications for humanity.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: An epistolary novel, it presents letters from the young artist Werther to his friend Wilhelm, recounting his life after moving to the rural village of Wahlheim in 1771–1772. Werther falls in love with Charlotte (Lotte), who is engaged and later married to Albert, and his unrequited attachment intensifies despite attempts to distance himself. He ultimately borrows Albert’s pistols and dies by suicide, after which an editor’s notes conclude the narrative.

Dear Dickhead (Cher connard) is a 2022 epistolary novel by Virginie Despentes comprising a correspondence between Oscar, a novelist embroiled in a sexual-harassment scandal, and Rebecca Latté, an actress from his past. Their exchange, triggered by online insults, widens to include Zoé Katana—Oscar’s former press attaché and accuser—tracing the #MeToo fallout and the corrosive dynamics of social networks. The novel also depicts addiction and detox as the characters navigate the personal and public consequences of their actions.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: The Holy Trinity and the Law of Three
Summary Abstract: Cynthia Bourgeault explores the Christian doctrine of the Trinity as a dynamic process and correlates it with G. I. Gurdjieff’s Law of Three, which posits affirming, denying, and reconciling forces at work in all phenomena. She uses this triadic lens to reinterpret biblical and early Christian teachings and to describe how creation and transformation unfold. The book integrates Christian contemplative tradition with insights from the Gurdjieff work to outline practical implications for spiritual practice.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Summary Abstract: Howl and Other Poems (1956) is a City Lights Pocket Poets collection by Allen Ginsberg, anchored by the long poem Howl (three sections plus “Footnote to Howl”) dedicated to Carl Solomon. The poems depict postwar American urban life and counterculture, addressing madness, sexuality, spirituality, drug use, and critiques of social conformity and capitalism in long-lined free verse and catalogs. The volume also includes “America,” “Sunflower Sutra,” “A Supermarket in California,” and other shorter works.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Published in 1964, Léopold Sédar Senghor’s On African Socialism articulates a conception of “African socialism” rooted in communal traditions and the philosophy of Négritude, distinguishing it from Marxist class struggle and European materialism. It proposes state-guided planning, cooperatives, and a mixed economy to confront postcolonial underdevelopment while centering culture, education, and African humanism. Senghor links these policies to a broader vision of intercultural dialogue and a “civilization of the universal,” situating African modernization within a shared global project.

Title of Work: Essays 1958-1962 on Atomic Physics and Human Knowledge

Summary Abstract: American Notes for General Circulation is a non-fiction travel narrative of Charles Dickens’s 1842 tour of the United States and Canada. Drawing on visits to Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Washington, Cincinnati, Niagara Falls, Montreal, and Quebec, it records observations of transportation, urban life, and institutions such as prisons (notably Eastern State Penitentiary), factories (including the Lowell mills), and legislatures. The work also addresses contemporary issues including slavery, the prison system, journalism and the press, and international copyright.

Summary Abstract: The Tower is a 1928 poetry collection by W. B. Yeats, titled for Thoor Ballylee, the Norman tower he purchased and restored in 1917. It was his first major volume after his 1923 Nobel Prize and gathers previously published poems, including “Sailing to Byzantium,” “Leda and the Swan,” “Among School Children,” “Meditations in Time of Civil War,” and “Nineteen Hundred and Nineteen”.

Summary Abstract: Sand and Foam (1926) is Kahlil Gibran’s collection of brief aphorisms, epigrams, and parables written in English. Through succinct, metaphorical statements, it explores themes of love, freedom, faith, selfhood, nature, and the individual’s relation to society. The work arranges standalone lines of prose and verse into a sequence of spiritual-philosophical reflections rather than a continuous narrative.

Summary Abstract: After unexpectedly inheriting a wealthy estate, Halla faces coercion from her late benefactor’s relatives, who plan to force her into marriage to seize the property. In desperation, she draws a magical sword that releases Sarkis, a warrior bound to the blade, who becomes her protector. Together they flee toward the Order of the White Rat to secure her legal claim, contending with pursuers and the dangers tied to the sword’s curse along the way.

Summary Abstract: Peter Zeihan argues that the United States’ unique geography—extensive navigable rivers, protected coastlines, abundant arable land, and resource endowments—along with favorable demographics and the shale revolution, positions it for enduring primacy. He contends that as the U.S. withdraws from its Bretton Woods-era role of guaranteeing global security and trade flows, the postwar order will fragment and many regions will face heightened instability and supply-chain risk. The book assesses countries and regions through geography, demography, energy, and transport networks to forecast likely winners and losers in the coming decades.

Summary Abstract: Tony Judt examines the post-1945 rise of social-democratic policies in Europe and North America and their role in expanding welfare, education, and public infrastructure. He critiques the late-20th-century shift toward deregulation, privatization, and tax cuts, arguing it has heightened inequality and weakened social trust. The book proposes a renewed social-democratic program centered on public goods, progressive taxation, and collective responsibility.

Title of Work: A Cowrie of Hope: Zambian Literature and Social Aesthetics
Summary Abstract: A Cowrie of Hope (2000) by Binwell Sinyangwe follows a rural Zambian widow struggling to secure her daughter’s secondary school fees amid poverty and predatory market practices. After being cheated of the proceeds from her harvest, she travels to the city to recover the money while confronting corruption and gendered exploitation. A cowrie shell she carries functions as a protective talisman and symbol of perseverance, as the narrative depicts social and economic inequities in contemporary Zambia.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: This book traces how 19th-century Scandinavian folk high schools and the tradition of Bildung fostered personal development and civic capacity, enabling Denmark, Norway, and Sweden to move from agrarian poverty to industrial prosperity and stable democracies. It details the rise and diffusion of these institutions and associated cultural reforms, highlighting their role in nurturing citizens and strengthening democratic participation across the Nordic countries.

Title of Work: Successful Marketing Strategies for Nonprofit Organizations
Summary Abstract: A practical handbook for nonprofit managers, this book presents step-by-step methods to analyze markets and build comprehensive, mission-aligned marketing plans. It details strategies to support fundraising, promote services, enhance organizational visibility, and reach both service users and donors, illustrated with case studies and actionable tools. Published by Wiley in 1995 (1st ed., 320 pp.), it targets organizations of all sizes seeking to launch or strengthen marketing programs.

Title of Work: Shui Hu Zhuan (Water Margin / Outlaws of the Marsh)
Summary Abstract: Set in the late Northern Song, the novel follows 108 outlaws—known as the Stars of Destiny—who, driven to rebellion by official corruption, gather at Liangshan Marsh under leaders including Song Jiang. It traces their origins, oath of brotherhood, and collective exploits as they build an autonomous force. After receiving imperial amnesty, they are deployed against the Liao and the rebel Fang La, with many members dying and the band ultimately dispersing.

Summary Abstract: Lowen presents a bioenergetic account of depression as a disturbance of bodily energy, characterized by chronic muscular tension, restricted breathing, diminished motility, and flattened affect. He links depressive character structures to early relational patterns and somatic “armor” that shape posture, movement, and expression, illustrating these dynamics with clinical case material. The work details bioenergetic analysis and exercises—grounding, deeper respiration, and expressive techniques—to release muscular defenses and restore vitality, positing bodily contact as the biological basis of feelings of reality and faith.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Abraham Joshua Heschel analyzes the biblical prophets of ancient Israel, examining their historical setting, message, and the nature of prophetic consciousness. He advances the concept of divine pathos—God’s active, emotional involvement with humanity—as the basis for the prophets’ denunciations of injustice and idolatry and their calls to covenantal fidelity. The work surveys the rhetoric, ethical imperatives, and theological themes of figures such as Amos, Hosea, Isaiah, and Jeremiah, and contrasts Israelite prophecy with other ancient Near Eastern religious phenomena.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mesopotamian / Ancient Near Eastern – Sumerian, Babylonian, Assyrian"

Summary Abstract: Psychology: Perspectives and Connections is an introductory textbook that surveys the major areas of psychology through multiple scientific perspectives while emphasizing critical thinking, scientific literacy, and real-world application. Topics include research methods; biological bases of behavior; sensation and perception; development; consciousness; learning and memory; language, thought, intelligence, and creativity; motivation and emotion; stress and health; personality; social behavior; psychological disorders; and treatments. Each chapter challenges assumptions and connects findings across subfields to help students evaluate and apply psychological science.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Men Explain Things to Me is a 2014 essay collection by Rebecca Solnit that examines how gendered power dynamics silence women and connect to broader patterns of misogyny and violence. Anchored by the titular essay recounting an incident in which a man condescendingly explains to Solnit a book she wrote, the collection helped popularize the phenomenon later termed “mansplaining.” Across its essays, Solnit links everyday dismissal of women’s voices to domestic violence and sexual assault, as well as to cultural and political structures that shape inequality.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: La perception du changement (The Perception of Change)
Summary Abstract: This work examines how ordinary perception and conceptual analysis spatialize time into discrete states, obscuring the continuous flow Bergson calls duration. He argues that genuine change and movement cannot be reconstructed from a sequence of immobile positions and must be apprehended through intuition, which grasps qualitative continuity and interpenetration of states. Bergson contrasts analytical intellect with intuitive knowledge and illustrates his thesis with examples from motion, consciousness, and memory.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Primary Subdomain(s): Metaphysics & Ontology,"Philosophy of Mind, Science, Language"

Author Full Name: Abu Yusuf Ya'qub ibn Ishaq al-Kindi
Summary Abstract: On Definitions and Descriptions (Fi hudud al-ashya’ wa rusumihā) is a mid-9th-century treatise by Abu Yusuf Ya‘qub ibn Ishaq al-Kindi that compiles concise entries defining (hudud) and describing (rusum) core philosophical and scientific terms. Presented as a glossary, it covers concepts such as intellect, soul, matter, form, substance and accident, cause, time, motion, and place, among others. Drawing on Aristotelian and late antique sources, the work clarifies technical vocabulary across logic, metaphysics, natural philosophy, mathematics, and ethics while distinguishing between definition and description.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"
Primary Subdomain(s): Epistemology & Logic,"Philosophy of Mind, Science, Language"

Summary Abstract: This book examines the place of learned magic in medieval European culture through twenty illuminated manuscripts, spanning contexts from the Carolingian Empire to Renaissance Italy and Tudor England. It analyzes works such as an astronomical compendium made for Charlemagne’s son, the Sworn Book of Honorius, and the Picatrix to show how rulers, religious figures, and scholars sought to summon spirits, predict the future, and prolong life. The study situates magic alongside science and religion and traces shifting attitudes that shaped intellectual life and manuscript art.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: Inciting Joy is a 2022 collection of essays by Ross Gay that examines how joy emerges from caring for one another and recognizing our interdependence, especially amid hardship. Addressing injustice, political polarization, and environmental destruction, the book frames joy as a practice that can cultivate expansive solidarity and help us endure. Through everyday experiences and memories, Gay studies what brings people together and how attending to shared loves can build connection.

Title of Work: The Body Has a Mind of Its Own
Summary Abstract: This book explains how the brain builds and updates body maps—covering touch, movement, posture, and peripersonal space—that underlie perception, action, and the sense of self. Using neuroscience studies and clinical cases such as phantom limbs, hemispatial neglect, and the rubber hand illusion, it shows how these maps change with learning, tools, injury, and sensory feedback. It outlines implications for rehabilitation, pain management, athletic training, and the design of prosthetics and human-technology interfaces.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Necessary Trouble: Americans in Revolt (2016) is journalist Sarah Jaffe’s reportage on the surge of U.S. grassroots movements after the 2008 financial crisis. Based on on-the-ground reporting and interviews, it examines campaigns such as Occupy Wall Street, Black Lives Matter, the Fight for $15, Moral Mondays, and debt activism, focusing on their origins, strategies, and participants. The book traces how workers, students, and community organizers mobilized against austerity, inequality, and racial injustice across regions and sectors.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Michael Eysenck's Psychology: A Student's Handbook (2000) is an introductory textbook surveying the major domains of psychology, including biological, cognitive, developmental, social, and individual differences. It explains core theories and empirical findings and outlines research methods and basic statistical approaches used in psychological science. Topics covered include perception, attention, memory, language, learning, emotion, intelligence, personality, and psychological disorders.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: A concise historical survey of Islam from the life of the Prophet Muhammad and the formation of the first Muslim community through the early caliphates and the Sunni–Shi‘i split. It traces the expansion of Islamic civilization, the development of religious and legal institutions, and the rise of Sufism, alongside the trajectories of the Umayyad, Abbasid, Ottoman, Safavid, and Mughal empires. The book examines the impact of European expansion and colonialism and follows reformist, nationalist, and Islamist movements into the late twentieth century, including changing relations with the West.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: The Tibetan Book of the Dead (Bardo Thodol)
Summary Abstract: The Tibetan Book of the Dead (Bardo Thodol), traditionally attributed to Padmasambhava and revealed as a terma by the 14th‑century Nyingma master Karma Lingpa (c. 1350), is a Tibetan Buddhist guide intended to be read to the dying and the deceased. It outlines the stages of the bardo—the intervals between death and rebirth—describing the dawning of the Clear Light, encounters with peaceful and wrathful deities, and the processes leading to rebirth. The text provides instructions for recognizing the nature of mind and attaining liberation or securing a favorable rebirth during these transitional states.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Tibetan / Himalayan – Tibetan Buddhism, Bön","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Title of Work: Women Without Men (new edition & film resurgence)
Summary Abstract: Women Without Men (1989) by Shahrnush Parsipur interlaces the stories of five Iranian women—Mahdokht, Munis, Faezeh, Zarrin, and Farrokhlaqa—who flee oppressive circumstances in Tehran and converge at a garden estate in Karaj. Blending everyday life with magical realism, it follows their attempts to create autonomous lives as events of death, resurrection, and metamorphosis unfold. Set against the political turbulence of early 1950s Iran, the narrative uses their temporary sanctuary to reflect broader social constraints on women.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Persian / Zoroastrian – Zoroastrianism, Mazdean traditions","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: 13th: Race, Justice, and Mass Incarceration in America
Summary Abstract: 13th (2016), directed by Ava DuVernay, examines how the Thirteenth Amendment’s exception clause facilitated the criminalization of Black Americans and the expansion of mass incarceration in the United States. Using archival footage and interviews with scholars, activists, and policymakers, it traces a line from Reconstruction and Jim Crow through the War on Drugs and “tough on crime” legislation to the rise of the prison-industrial complex. The film analyzes how policy, media, and corporate interests—including privatized prisons and lobbying groups—shaped the modern carceral system, and presents contemporary cases and movements to illustrate these dynamics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Other Primary Domains: "Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy",Systems Thinking & Complexity

Title of Work: Dreams of the Heart: Women's Leadership and Nicaraguan Democracy
Summary Abstract: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro’s memoir recounts her unexpected rise from private life to become Nicaragua’s first female president, culminating in her 1990 electoral victory over Daniel Ortega and a peaceful transition of power. She narrates the country’s passage from war to democracy and the challenges of governing in the postwar period, offering a first-person perspective as a woman leading a national democratic transition.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Other Primary Domains: Leadership & Management Sciences,"Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Summary Abstract: This work recounts the author’s childhood in India, his search for and discipleship under Sri Yukteswar, and training in Kriya Yoga within the Lahiri Mahasaya–Mahavatar Babaji lineage. It describes encounters with Indian and Western spiritual figures, accounts of yogic practices and phenomena, and the founding of the Self-Realization Fellowship. The narrative also covers the author’s 1920 voyage to the United States, subsequent years of teaching and lecturing, and reflections on integrating yoga with modern life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Americas - North,Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: Reading North Korea: An Ethnological Inquiry
Summary Abstract: Reading North Korea: An Ethnological Inquiry examines DPRK culture by treating 1970s–1980s North Korean literary works as ethnographic sources to analyze how rituals and language fuse the personal, social, and political. Focusing on the themes of love, war, and self, Ryang shows how these texts articulate an ideology that sustains a “perpetual ritual state” centered on Kim Il Sung.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Hizō Hōyaku (The Precious Key to the Secret Treasury)
Summary Abstract: Hizō Hōyaku (The Precious Key to the Secret Treasury), composed by Kūkai (Kōbō Daishi) in 830, is a concise exposition of Shingon esoteric Buddhism. It systematizes Buddhist doctrines via the Ten Stages of the Development of the Mind, contrasting exoteric and esoteric teachings and articulating the Three Mysteries of body, speech, and mind. The text presents realization through mantra, mudra, and mandala in union with the dharma-body Mahāvairocana, positioning Shingon as the culminating teaching.

Title of Work: Death and the Right Hand (Centennial Critical Edition)
Summary Abstract: Robert Hertz analyzes death as a collectively organized social event, focusing on phased mortuary rites—especially secondary burial—to show how communities manage impurity, grief, and the reintegration of the deceased’s person into the social order. He pairs this with a study of the cross-cultural preeminence of the right hand, demonstrating how right/left polarity structures religious classifications of purity and pollution, auspiciousness and taboo, and the regulation of bodies and actions. Based on comparative ethnography within a Durkheimian framework, the work links bodily symbolism to ritual practice and social structure.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Europe – Western,"Southeast Asia – Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Philippines, Cambodia, Burma","Oceania – Australia, New Zealand, Polynesia, Micronesia, Melanesia",Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: The End of the Myth: From the Frontier to the Border Wall in the Mind of America
Summary Abstract: Greg Grandin analyzes how the American frontier—both as territory and national myth—worked as a “safety valve” that redirected domestic conflicts outward through expansion, imperial wars, and global markets. He traces the waning of this myth across the 20th and early 21st centuries and argues that, as expansion met its limits, U.S. politics turned inward toward militarized borders and exclusion, symbolized by the call for a border wall. Using political, economic, and intellectual history from Andrew Jackson through the Cold War and globalization, the book presents the border as the frontier’s successor in the American imagination.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Electrify presents a plan to decarbonize energy use by replacing fossil-fueled machines—cars, furnaces, water heaters, and stoves—with electric alternatives powered by clean generation. It describes how household purchases (EVs, heat pumps, induction cooking, rooftop solar), combined with grid upgrades and utility-scale renewables, can reduce emissions across transportation and buildings. The book outlines policy and financing strategies and deployment timelines to coordinate this transition in the United States.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Other Primary Domains: Ecology & Deep Ecology,"Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Title of Work: Confucian Thought: Selfhood as Creative Transformation
Summary Abstract: Confucian Thought: Selfhood as Creative Transformation (1985) is a collection of Tu Weiming’s essays that offers a sustained examination of Confucian humanism and the Confucian conception of personhood as “selfhood as creative transformation.” The volume addresses themes including the moral universal; continuity of being and Chinese visions of nature; learning to be human and the value of the human; ren in the Analects; Mencian views of the human and aesthetics; selfhood and otherness (e.g., the father–son relationship); and Neo-Confucian religiosity and ontology. Integrating philosophical, historical, anthropological, sociological, and psychological perspectives, it investigates enduring Confucian themes within a contemporary scholarly framework.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Americas - North,Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Gabriel Kolko’s 1963 study argues that during the U.S. Progressive Era (1900–1916), large corporations promoted federal regulation to stabilize markets and curb competition, resulting in a “triumph of conservatism.” Using case studies in sectors such as railroads, meatpacking, banking, and manufacturing, he contends that measures like the ICC, Pure Food and Drug Act, Federal Reserve System, and Federal Trade Commission largely reflected corporate preferences. The book reinterprets Progressivism as political capitalism, in which business used the state to consolidate control over the economy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, guests assemble for a wedding where old grudges and hidden connections simmer beneath the festivities. The story unfolds through alternating viewpoints—the bride, a bridesmaid, the wedding planner, the best man, and a plus-one—as past secrets gradually come to light. During the storm-lashed reception a body is discovered, and the narrative reveals how intertwined motives lead to murder.

Pale Blue Dot: A Vision of the Human Future in Space (1994) expands on the 1990 Voyager 1 “Pale Blue Dot” photograph to examine what planetary missions have revealed about the solar system and Earth’s place in it. Carl Sagan surveys the science and history of robotic exploration (e.g., Voyager, Viking, Galileo, Magellan) and outlines prospects for human spaceflight, including Mars exploration and terraforming concepts, planetary protection, and planetary defense. He also considers the search for extraterrestrial life and the technological and policy pathways toward a long-term spacefaring future.

A Search for Common Ground (2021) is a book-length dialogue in which education scholars Pedro A. Noguera and Frederick M. Hess, from differing ideological perspectives, examine key controversies in K–12 schooling. Structured as a series of exchanges, it explores topics including school choice and charter schools, accountability and testing, teachers and unions, equity and school funding, race and discipline, civics education, and the roles of families and government. The authors delineate areas of agreement and disagreement and identify where constructive collaboration is possible across political lines.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Other Primary Domains: "Society, Politics, Law & Economics","Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy"

Title of Work: The Quaking of America: An Embodied Guide to Navigating Our Nation’s Upheaval and Racial Reckoning
Summary Abstract: Resmaa Menakem presents a somatic framework for understanding how racialized trauma and the legacy of white-body supremacy are held in individual and collective nervous systems amid U.S. upheaval. The book outlines “somatic abolitionism” and offers body-based practices, exercises, and protocols to build resilience, work with “clean pain,” and interrupt reflexive harm. Drawing on trauma science and U.S. history, it provides step-by-step guidance for individuals, families, communities, and institutions to prepare for and navigate conflict and potential civil disorder.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Other Primary Domains: "Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy","Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Title of Work: Religion and the Order of Nature
Summary Abstract: Nasr examines how major religious traditions, especially Islam but also Christianity, Hinduism, and others, conceive nature as a sacred order governed by metaphysical principles. He traces the Western shift from a sacralized cosmology to a mechanistic, desacralized science and links this transition to the modern environmental crisis. The book calls for recovering traditional wisdom and establishing a “sacred science” that reunites metaphysics, ethics, and ecology in humanity’s relationship with the natural world.

Summary Abstract: Selected Prose (Penguin Classics, 1993) collects Heinrich Heine’s prose in English translation, edited by Ritchie Robertson, beginning with meditative travel writings from journeys to Lucca, Venice, and the Harz Mountains. The volume also includes essays and autobiographical pieces addressing the history of religion in Germany, Heine’s Jewish heritage, and his early childhood.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Set in the pre–Civil War South, the novel follows Huck Finn as he escapes his abusive father and joins Jim, an enslaved man seeking freedom, on a raft down the Mississippi River. Their journey brings encounters with feuding families, con men, and other hazards that test their resourcefulness. As they travel, Huck wrestles with the conflict between the laws and social norms supporting slavery and his growing commitment to help Jim.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A corpus of colonial-era Yucatec Maya manuscripts written in Latin script, the Books of Chilam Balam were compiled around 1700 by anonymous Maya scribes in towns such as Chumayel, Tizimín, and Mani. They collect prophecies attributed to the priest Chilam Balam, historical annals, calendrical and katun-cycle computations, astrology, ritual instructions, medical recipes, and Christian catechetical materials. The manuscripts blend pre-Hispanic traditions with Spanish colonial influences and preserve a wide range of Maya intellectual and religious knowledge.

On Justice is a lost Stoic treatise by Chrysippus (3rd century BCE), known only from later testimonies and fragments. It treats justice as a cardinal virtue grounded in oikeiosis and universal law (right reason), emphasizing human sociability and duties toward others. The work situates justice within the unity of the virtues and the cosmopolitan community of rational beings, linking lawful conduct to living in accordance with nature.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: After returning from service in the French army, Tom begins a relationship with Léna, his cousin’s girlfriend, and their bond forms around the wreck of the ship La Fleur du Corail as both experience dreams that connect them to ancestral histories. Their story intersects with figures including Old Tom, Lila (a survivor of childhood abuse), and Éva the Healer, and it unfolds within Kanak cultural life and the struggle for New Caledonia’s independence. First published in 2005, the novel appeared in English in 2011 as The Wreck, translated by Deborah Walker-Morrison and Raylene L. Ramsay.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous Australian / Pacific – Aboriginal Dreaming, Polynesian, Maori, Hawaiian, Micronesian, Melanesian","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Eihei Kōroku (Eihei's Extensive Record) is a ten-fascicle compilation of Dōgen Kigen’s later teachings, compiled posthumously by his disciples, notably Koun Ejō, around 1255. Written primarily in literary Chinese (kanbun), it gathers formal Dharma hall sermons (jōdō) delivered at Eiheiji together with informal talks (jishu), memorial addresses, remarks on classical cases, and Chinese poetry (kanshi). The contents document teachings given mainly between 1247 and 1253, offering a chronological record of Dōgen’s final years.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Japanese / Korean – Shinto, Zen, Neo-Confucian Korean lineages","Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: Ageless Aging (2024) presents a holistic, science-based plan to help women extend healthspan, brainspan, and lifespan by leveraging scientific, medical, psychological, and spiritual tools as they age. Using longevity data—such as a 50-year-old woman’s average 35 additional years and women comprising 80% of centenarians—it highlights the gap between longer lives and many years spent with compounding health issues. The book provides actionable guidance for taking control of aging, reflecting research that 70–90% of health and longevity is influenced by modifiable factors rather than genetics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Opening the Door of Your Heart
Summary Abstract: Opening the Door of Your Heart (2004) by Ajahn Brahm is a collection of short Buddhist stories and parables drawn from his monastic experience and teaching. The vignettes present applications of Theravada Buddhist principles—mindfulness, compassion, forgiveness, patience, and letting go—to everyday challenges, relationships, suffering, and meditation practice. It includes personal anecdotes such as “Two Bad Bricks” to convey ethical and contemplative lessons, and has also been published in some regions as Who Ordered This Truckload of Dung?.

Title of Work: The Purple Violet of Oshaantu (20th Anniversary Edition)
Summary Abstract: Set in a rural village in northern Namibia, The Purple Violet of Oshaantu is narrated by Mee Ali, who recounts her friendship with her neighbor Kauna. After the sudden death of Kauna’s husband, Shange, the funeral rituals and family disputes reveal gendered power imbalances, domestic violence, and property-grabbing customs. The novel follows how Kauna navigates widowhood and community expectations with Mee Ali’s support.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "African Indigenous – Yoruba, Ifá, Akan, San, Bantu, Dogon","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Al-Qanun fi al-Tibb (The Canon of Medicine), completed by Avicenna in 1025, is a systematic medical encyclopedia synthesizing Greco-Roman (Hippocratic and Galenic), Persian, and Arabic medical knowledge. Structured in five books, it covers general principles and physiology; simple drugs (materia medica); diseases of specific organs; systemic diseases and public health topics (e.g., fevers, toxicology, hygiene); and compound remedies and pharmacopoeia. It integrates etiology, diagnosis, prognosis, and therapeutic rules, including procedures for testing medicines. The Canon functioned as a standard medical textbook across the Islamic world and in European universities for centuries, into the early modern period.

Summary Abstract: The Pocket Ken Wilber is a concise anthology of Ken Wilber’s writings that introduces his Integral (AQAL) framework. It outlines core elements—quadrants, levels/stages, lines, states, and types—and synthesizes insights from psychology, philosophy, science, and Eastern and Western spiritual traditions. The selections describe how integral theory maps individual and collective development and suggest applications of an integral approach to personal growth and cultural analysis.
