Title of Work: The Value of Everything & Mission Economy
Summary Abstract: Mariana Mazzucato examines how modern economies conflate value creation with value extraction, calling for clearer distinctions in national accounting and recognition of the state’s role in shaping and co-creating markets in The Value of Everything. Extending this, Mission Economy proposes mission-oriented innovation policy—modeled on the Apollo program—where governments set bold, outcome-focused goals and orchestrate public–private collaboration to address challenges such as climate change and health. Across both works, she details instruments like conditionalities on public funding, new metrics for public value, and risk–reward sharing to align innovation and investment with public purpose.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Place of Publication:
- The Value of Everything: London, UK
- Mission Economy: London, UK

Summary Abstract: Edited by Clarence Brown and published by Viking in 1985, this anthology presents English translations of major twentieth-century Russian literature across genres. It includes stories by Chekhov, Gorky, Bunin, Zamyatin, Babel, Nabokov, Solzhenitsyn, and Voinovich; excerpts from Bely’s Petersburg, Bulgakov’s The Master and Margarita, and Pasternak’s Dr. Zhivago; the complete text of Olesha’s Envy; and poems by Blok, Akhmatova, and Mandelstam. The volume includes an introduction and notes by Brown.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: The Wind Whistling in the Cranes
Summary Abstract: After Regina Leandro flees the hospital and is found dead at the entrance to an old cannery in Valmares, her granddaughter Milene is left to arrange the funeral. The cannery, now inhabited by the Cape Verdean Mata family, welcomes Milene, and she develops a relationship with Ana Mata’s grandson Antonio, a crane operator and father of two. Meanwhile, Milene’s affluent Leandro relatives seek to protect their reputation and sell the beach-adjacent factory site, heightening tensions between the families over the property and Milene’s relationship.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A thematic compilation of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway shareholder letters, this volume organizes his writings into sections on corporate governance, investing principles, valuation, mergers and acquisitions, and accounting. It sets out his owner-oriented approach to value investing, emphasizing intrinsic value, capital allocation, economic moats, and sound managerial incentives. The work also explains his views on board stewardship, acquisition discipline, risk, and the gap between reported earnings and underlying economic reality.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Andreas Reckwitz argues that late-modern societies have shifted from a logic of generality and standardization to a regime of singularities, where goods, persons, experiences, and places are valued as unique and authentic. He shows how this singularization underpins cultural capitalism, digital platforms, and urban attention economies, and reconfigures class structure into a new middle class, an old middle class, a precariat, and an elite. The book analyzes how singularities are produced and valued through curation, staging, and ratings, and examines resulting ambivalences such as intensified inequality, exhaustion, and backlash in the form of right‑wing populism. It also outlines corresponding subjectivities—creative, optimizing, and disappointed—shaped by these dynamics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Crazywise is a 2017 documentary by Phil Borges that examines how different cultures interpret and respond to psychological crises. The film follows several young people in the United States experiencing extreme mental states and contrasts Western psychiatric practices with traditional and Indigenous healing approaches that frame such experiences as potential spiritual initiation. Through interviews and case histories, it documents alternative support models and cultural contexts around psychosis and distress.

Courting the Wild Twin (2020) presents Martin Shaw’s retellings and analyses of two ancient European fairy tales centered on a “wild twin” within each person. The book characterizes this wild twin as an estranged, exiled aspect of the self and examines practices of recalling it to consciousness. Through mythic storytelling, Shaw frames this engagement as a way to orient one’s relationship to contemporary life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Celtic / Northern European / Slavic – Druidic, Norse, Germanic paganism, Slavic folk traditions","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: Transcend: Nine Steps to Living Well Forever
Summary Abstract: Transcend: Nine Steps to Living Well Forever (2009) by Ray Kurzweil and Terry Grossman outlines a longevity program organized around the acronym TRANSCEND: Talk with your doctor, Relaxation, Assessment, Nutrition, Supplements, Calorie restriction, Exercise, New technologies, and Detoxification. It details lifestyle, medical, and supplementation strategies and the tracking of biomarkers to reduce disease risk and extend healthspan. The book presents these steps as a bridge to forthcoming biotechnologies and related advances that could enable radical life extension.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A psychological thriller about Christine Lucas, a woman with anterograde amnesia who awakens each day with no memory of her adult life. With the help of a neurologist, she keeps a secret journal to piece together her past and notices contradictions in what her supposed husband tells her. Her investigation uncovers a sustained deception by a man posing as her husband, leading to a dangerous confrontation and the first signs of recovering her memories.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Rickshaw Boy depicts Xiangzi, a rural migrant in Republican-era Beijing, whose ambition is to save enough through rickshaw pulling to own his own vehicle. After he finally buys one, it is seized by soldiers; later savings are extorted, and he is coerced into marrying Huniu, the rickshaw boss’s daughter, who dies in childbirth. Repeated losses and exploitation erode his means and resolve, and Xiangzi descends into destitution and apathy.

Title of Work: A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful
Summary Abstract: Edmund Burke’s treatise investigates the psychological and physiological origins of the aesthetic categories “sublime” and “beautiful,” grounding them in human sensations, passions, and bodily responses. He characterizes the sublime by terror, vastness, obscurity, and power linked to self-preservation and a pleasurable sense of astonishment, while the beautiful arises from smallness, smoothness, delicacy, and clarity associated with social affection. Through examples from nature, art, and literature, Burke analyzes how sensory qualities and emotional mechanisms produce these distinct experiences and discusses taste as rooted in common human principles.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Other Primary Domains: "Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy","Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Summary Abstract: I’m unable to locate any reliable record of a work titled “Gravity and Grace in Movement” by Hubert Godard, so I cannot produce a factual abstract. Without verifiable publication or content details, summarizing this specific work would risk inaccuracy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: L'Afrique humiliée (2008) by Aminata Dramane Traoré examines how globalized capitalism and European migration controls contribute to Africa’s humiliation through mechanisms of domination, pauperization, and exclusion, with perilous journeys and deportations as emblematic outcomes. It critiques the internalized binary that opposes a “Europe of values and progress” to an “Africa of darkness and misfortune,” urging recognition of the structural forces at work. The book advocates human-centered futures grounded in African languages, cultural reference points, and social values, and includes a preface by Cheikh Hamidou Kane.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Other Primary Domains: "Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy","Culture, Language & Anthropology"

Author Full Name: Valmiki (attrib.) translation by Robert P. Goldman et al.
Summary Abstract: The Ramayana is an ancient Sanskrit epic traditionally attributed to Valmiki, recounting the life of Prince Rama across seven books. Exiled from Ayodhya, Rama’s wife Sita is abducted by the demon king Ravana, prompting Rama, his brother Lakshmana, and the monkey hero Hanuman to ally with the vanara army, bridge to Lanka, and defeat Ravana to recover her. The epic concludes with Rama’s return and coronation, Sita’s ordeals to prove her chastity, and the later birth and recognition of their sons, who recite the poem.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh","Southeast Asia – Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Philippines, Cambodia, Burma","Himalayan – Tibet, Bhutan, Nepal"

Summary Abstract: A novelized retelling of the biblical prophet Elijah, The Fifth Mountain follows his flight from Israel during the reign of Ahab and Jezebel in the 9th century BCE. Exiled to Phoenicia, he lodges with a widow and her son and becomes entwined with the fate of their city amid persecution, war, and catastrophe. The story traces his struggle between obedience to divine command and personal choice, culminating in the continuation of his prophetic mission back toward Israel.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: Qatar National Vision 2030: Leadership for the Future
Author Full Name: Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani
Summary Abstract: Qatar National Vision 2030, launched in 2008 under the leadership of then-Heir Apparent Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, sets a long-term framework to transform Qatar into an advanced, sustainable state by 2030. It defines four pillars—human, social, economic, and environmental development—and addresses five core challenges balancing modernization with tradition, present with future needs, managed growth with uncontrolled expansion, expatriate labor dynamics, and environmental management. The vision outlines outcomes for education, health, workforce participation, social cohesion, economic diversification and responsible hydrocarbon use, and environmental protection, and serves as the foundation for subsequent national strategies and implementation plans.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: Learned Helplessness: A Theory for the Age of Personal Control (w/ Steven Maier)
Summary Abstract: This work synthesizes animal and human research on learned helplessness, showing that exposure to uncontrollable events fosters expectations of response–outcome independence that impair motivation, learning, and emotional functioning. It reformulates the theory for an era emphasizing personal control by highlighting perceived controllability and individual differences in attributional/explanatory style (internal–external, stable–unstable, global–specific) as mediators of helplessness. The authors link helplessness to depression, review “immunization” effects of prior control, and outline interventions that increase perceived control and restructure pessimistic explanations across domains such as education, work, and health.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Political Fictions is Joan Didion’s 2001 collection of essays on U.S. politics, reissued posthumously. Drawn largely from her work for The New York Review of Books, it traces how campaign consultants, party organizations, and the media constructed the narratives of national politics from the late 1980s through the 2000 presidential election, including the Clinton impeachment. The volume focuses on the professional political class and the mechanics of contemporary electoral politics.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Bowling Alone (2000) by Robert D. Putnam analyzes the long-term decline of social capital in the United States, documenting decreases in membership in civic organizations, voter turnout, social trust, and informal socializing despite stable or rising individual leisure activities. Drawing on survey data and organizational records, the book attributes this decline to factors including generational change, television and later electronic media, suburbanization, and time pressures. It links reduced connectedness to effects on democratic participation, community capacity, health outcomes, and economic performance, and presents strategies to rebuild civic engagement.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Way of Contemplation: Encountering God Today
Summary Abstract: This work presents a contemporary introduction to Christian contemplation as an encounter with God, situating the practice within the Christian mystical tradition while engaging insights from Zen Buddhism. Jäger outlines the contemplative path for modern readers, emphasizing silence and meditative prayer, and addresses obstacles and misconceptions that arise along the way. Originally published in German as “Kontemplation: Gottesbegegnung heute,” it appeared in English as “The Way to Contemplation: Encountering God Today.”
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Japanese / Korean – Shinto, Zen, Neo-Confucian Korean lineages"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Europe – Western,"East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: A Thousand Names for Joy: Living in Harmony with the Way Things Are (2007) presents Byron Katie’s self-inquiry process, “The Work,” in 81 brief chapters aligned with verses of the Tao Te Ching. Co-authored with Stephen Mitchell, it pairs selected Taoist passages with dialogues, anecdotes, and case examples that apply the four questions and “turnarounds” to everyday situations. The book interweaves biographical episodes and transcripts of interactions with students to demonstrate the method’s use across varied contexts.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Americas - North,"East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Set in early 20th-century Mexico during the Revolution, the novel follows Tita de la Garza, the youngest daughter bound by a family tradition to remain unmarried and care for her mother, Mama Elena. When Tita’s beloved Pedro marries her sister Rosaura, Tita’s emotions infuse the dishes she cooks, producing tangible effects on those who eat them, as her relationships with Pedro and Dr. John Brown develop. Structured as twelve monthly, recipe-framed chapters narrated by a descendant, the story ends with the breaking of the family tradition when Esperanza marries and with Tita and Pedro’s final, tragic consummation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous Mesoamerican – Aztec, Maya, Olmec, Toltec ","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: What to Expect the Second Year
Summary Abstract: What to Expect the Second Year (2011) by Heidi Murkoff is a parenting guide to the toddler period from 12 to 24 months. It describes physical, cognitive, emotional, and language development milestones and offers guidance on nutrition, sleep, safety, toilet training, and behavior management. The book addresses common illnesses and health concerns, when to call the pediatrician, and ways to support learning and play throughout the second year.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: I Was Never the First Lady
Summary Abstract:
First published in Spanish in 2008, this novel follows Nadia Guerra, a Havana artist in the early 21st century, who searches for the mother who abandoned her and Cuba decades earlier.
Funded by artist grants, Nadia travels through Europe and ultimately finds her mother in Russia, then brings her back to Havana.
The narrative also includes Nadia taking up her mother’s unfinished manuscript about revolutionary Celia Sánchez and deciding to complete it.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Behold the Spirit (1947) is Alan Watts’s examination of Christian mysticism, presented as “a study in the necessity of mystical religion.” It traces biblical, patristic, and liturgical themes to argue that the doctrines of Incarnation and the sacraments ground direct experience of God beyond doctrinal assent or moralism. The book proposes renewing Christian life through contemplative practice and sacramental participation centered on immediate spiritual experience.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: Aware: The Science and Practice of Presence
Summary Abstract: Daniel J. Siegel introduces the Wheel of Awareness, a step-by-step meditation framework that trains three pillars: focused attention, open awareness, and kind intention. The book synthesizes neuroscience, psychology, and contemplative traditions to explain how attention and awareness relate to consciousness and neural integration, linking mind, brain, and relationships. It provides practical exercises and guided scripts and reviews research on the potential benefits of cultivating presence.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Title of Work: A Short History of the World
Summary Abstract: H. G. Wells summarizes world history from cosmic and geological origins through the emergence of life and human evolution to historical civilizations. The book traces prehistoric societies, the rise and interaction of civilizations, the spread of religions and ideas, and developments in science, technology, and political organization. It extends into the modern era, covering global exploration, industrialization, and the First World War, concluding with the postwar situation as of 1922.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: George P. Hansen’s 2001 book analyzes how the trickster figure from anthropology and folklore helps explain recurring patterns around paranormal phenomena and parapsychology. Using concepts of liminality, boundary-crossing, taboo, secrecy, and deception, he examines psychical research and related anomalous domains, as well as the skepticism and institutional dynamics that surround them. Hansen argues that trickster dynamics contribute to the elusiveness of effects, controversies, and the marginal status of these subjects within science, integrating perspectives from anthropology, sociology, psychology, and religious studies.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: White-Jacket (1850) is Herman Melville’s first-person narrative of a sailor nicknamed White-Jacket during a U.S. frigate cruise aboard the Neversink, depicting shipboard life, duties, hierarchies, and hazards. Based on Melville’s 1843–44 service on the USS United States, it describes naval discipline, including the practice of flogging. It was published the same year Congress abolished flogging in the U.S. Navy (1850).

Eric Klinenberg examines “social infrastructure”—libraries, parks, schools, sidewalks, and other shared spaces and institutions—and how their presence and quality shape public health, safety, economic opportunity, and civic life. Using case studies from the U.S. and abroad, he documents how investing in these places reduces isolation, strengthens trust and cooperation, and enhances resilience to crises such as extreme weather. The book traces the phrase “palaces for the people” to Andrew Carnegie’s vision for public libraries and outlines policy approaches for rebuilding social infrastructure to address inequality and polarization.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Arsène Lupin, Gentleman-Thief (1907) is a collection of short stories by Maurice Leblanc featuring the French gentleman burglar and master of disguise Arsène Lupin. The narratives follow his arrest, imprisonment, escape, and a series of high-profile thefts, with episodes such as The Queen’s Necklace and The Black Pearl. Lupin repeatedly confronts Inspector Ganimard and Herlock Sholmes, a thinly veiled Sherlock Holmes pastiche.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Influence: Science and Practice (2009) presents Robert B. Cialdini’s synthesis of experimental and field research on compliance and persuasion. The text organizes influence tactics around six principles—reciprocity, commitment and consistency, social proof, liking, authority, and scarcity—and illustrates them with studies and real-world cases. It analyzes how these mechanisms operate in contexts such as marketing, sales, politics, and fundraising, and provides empirically grounded strategies for recognizing and resisting undue influence.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Peter S. Beagle’s 1968 fantasy novel follows a unicorn who learns she may be the last of her kind and leaves her forest to find the others. Joined by Schmendrick the Magician and Molly Grue, she is transformed into a human, Lady Amalthea, to escape the Red Bull and enters the realm of King Haggard. They discover Haggard used the Red Bull to drive the unicorns into the sea; after confronting it, the unicorns are freed and she returns to her true form.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Celtic / Northern European / Slavic – Druidic, Norse, Germanic paganism, Slavic folk traditions"

Title of Work: The Interpretation of Cultures (50th Anniversary Edition)
Summary Abstract: The Interpretation of Cultures is a collection of essays in which Clifford Geertz develops an interpretive, semiotic conception of culture as webs of meaning and advances thick description as a methodological strategy for anthropological analysis. He examines how symbols, rituals, and narratives organize social life, treating religion as a system of symbols that establishes powerful moods and motivations. Case studies include his ethnography of the Balinese cockfight and analyses of ritual, ideology, and common sense.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Americas - North,"Southeast Asia – Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Philippines, Cambodia, Burma",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: The Aleph and Other Stories (1949) is a collection of short fiction by Jorge Luis Borges. The pieces address metaphysical and literary problems such as infinity, time, identity, memory, and interpretation across varied settings. In the title story, a narrator encounters an Aleph—a point in space that contains all points—that grants a simultaneous vision of the entire universe; other tales examine subjects including divine writing, obsession, revenge, and theology.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: An epistolary work published in 1721, The Persian Letters presents correspondence by two Persian travelers, Usbek and Rica, who describe and analyze the customs, religion, politics, and social life they encounter in France. Interleaved letters from Usbek’s harem in Persia depict the strains of despotism and the conflicts among wives and eunuchs during his absence. The narrative culminates in a revolt in the seraglio and Roxane’s final letter before her suicide.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Songs of the Soul (Songs of the Soul)
Summary Abstract: Songs of the Soul is a collection of English-language mystical and devotional poems by Paramahansa Yogananda focused on the soul’s longing for God, meditation, and divine union. Using nature imagery and yogic concepts, the poems explore themes including divine love, the guru-disciple relationship, inner struggle, and Self-realization. The 1980 edition presents these pieces as a compact volume of Yogananda’s spiritual verse.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Americas - North,Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: The China Study (2005) presents findings from the China–Cornell–Oxford Project and related research examining diet, lifestyle, and disease patterns in rural China alongside comparisons with Western populations. It reports epidemiological associations and experimental results linking higher consumption of animal-based foods—especially animal protein—to increased risks of chronic illnesses such as heart disease, certain cancers, and type 2 diabetes, while associating whole-food, plant-based diets with lower risk. The book also critiques nutrition science and policy and advances dietary guidelines centered on minimally processed plant foods.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Americas - North,Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Aryabhatiya, composed by Aryabhata in 499 CE, is a Sanskrit versified treatise summarizing mathematics and astronomy. It comprises four sections—Gitikapada, Ganitapada, Kalakriyapada, and Golapada—covering arithmetic, algebra, extraction of square and cube roots, the kuttaka method for linear indeterminate equations, plane and spherical trigonometry with a sine table, and computational astronomy. The work presents parameters and procedures for calendrical reckoning and planetary motions, including a value for pi (~3.1416), the length of the year, and the Earth’s axial rotation to explain daily celestial motion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Middle East – Mesopotamia

Summary Abstract: Set in post-independence Kenya, the novel follows four protagonists—Munira, Karega, Abdulla, and Wanja—in the drought-stricken village of Ilmorog, who lead a trek to Nairobi to petition for aid. Years later, Ilmorog is redeveloped into a commercial hub dominated by outside interests, drawing the protagonists into conflicts with local elites and the state. After three businessmen—Kimeria, Chui, and Mzigo—die in a fire at Wanja’s establishment, a police investigation unravels the characters’ intertwined histories; Munira confesses to starting the blaze, Karega is detained for labor activism, and Wanja and Abdulla survive as Ilmorog is transformed.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: There Is Nothing for You Here (Paperback)
Summary Abstract: Fiona Hill’s memoir traces her journey from a working-class upbringing in deindustrialized northern England to becoming a U.S. national security official and Russia expert. It details her education and career across the UK, Russia, and the United States, including service on the National Security Council and testimony in the 2019 impeachment inquiry. Interweaving personal narrative with analysis, the book examines how economic dislocation and declining social mobility in the UK, U.S., and Russia have fostered populism and political instability.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Published in 1961, The City in History traces the development of urban settlements from prehistoric villages through the ancient polis and medieval town to the industrial metropolis and suburban sprawl, linking shifts in urban form to changes in technology, economy, and social institutions. Mumford analyzes city functions and spatial structures—defense, ritual, exchange, administration, and dwelling—and how industrialization and automobility reshaped urban life and landscape. He concludes by outlining principles for decentralized, regionally planned urban development influenced by ecological and garden-city ideas.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Little Book of Atheist Spirituality
Summary Abstract: André Comte-Sponville examines whether a rich spiritual life—marked by wonder, love, fidelity, and serenity—can exist without belief in God or organized religion. Drawing on Western philosophers (e.g., Montaigne, Spinoza, Nietzsche) and Buddhist thought, he distinguishes spirituality from faith, considers the “absolute” as immanent reality, and evaluates arguments about God’s existence. He develops a secular ethic rooted in human finitude and values, contending that meaning, morality, and contemplative practice are possible without theism.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Europe – Western,"South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: Abhidhamma Studies: Buddhist Explorations of Consciousness and Time
Summary Abstract: A collection of essays presenting the Theravada Abhidhamma analysis of mind and experience, focusing on consciousness (citta), associated mental factors (cetasikas), and the momentary process of cognition. It outlines Abhidhamma methodology and conditional relations (paccaya), examines the treatment of time and change, and explains how cognitive events arise and cease in sequences. Drawing on canonical Abhidhamma and commentarial sources, Nyanaponika Thera systematically explicates these topics within the Theravada tradition.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh","Southeast Asia – Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Philippines, Cambodia, Burma",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Georg Simmel’s 1900 work analyzes the nature, origins, and functions of money, developing a theory of value in which objects become valuable through the distances and sacrifices overcome in exchange. He examines money as a universal means that abstracts and quantifies value, reshaping social relations by increasing calculability, impersonal interaction, and individual autonomy. The book traces the cultural consequences of the money economy, including intensified social differentiation and the growing dominance of objective culture over subjective culture.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The poetic preamble to the Behistun Inscription, composed for Darius I of Persia around 520–518 BCE, introduces the monument’s purpose and authority. It invokes Ahura Mazda, proclaims Darius’s genealogy and titles as king of kings, and asserts divine sanction for his rule. Establishing the theme of Truth versus the Lie, it condemns revolt and frames the subsequent narrative of suppressing impostors and uprisings across the empire.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Persian / Zoroastrian – Zoroastrianism, Mazdean traditions"

Title of Work: The Seven-Day Weekend: Changing the Way Work Works
Summary Abstract: The book details Ricardo Semler’s redesign of Semco’s management model, emphasizing radical decentralization, workplace democracy, and transparency. It documents practices including self-managed teams, open-book management, profit sharing, flexible schedules and locations, and employee participation in decisions about supervisors, projects, and compensation. Using cases and internal processes, it describes how these practices were implemented and the structures that sustained them.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Embers: One Ojibway’s Meditations (2016) by Richard Wagamese is a nonfiction collection of short reflections and teachings grounded in Ojibway/Anishinaabe spirituality and the author’s experiences. Organized as standalone meditations, the pieces address themes of healing, humility, gratitude, forgiveness, and connection to land and community, intended for brief, daily contemplation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous North American – First Nations, Native American traditions"

Title of Work: Radical Compassion: Learning to Love Yourself and Your World with the Practice of RAIN—Updated Edition
Summary Abstract: Radical Compassion presents Tara Brach’s RAIN framework—Recognize, Allow, Investigate, Nurture—as a step-by-step mindfulness method for working with difficult emotions. Drawing on Buddhist psychology, clinical practice, and case examples, it explains how RAIN can address shame and fear, support healing from trauma, and foster compassion in relationships and communities. The 2019 updated edition offers revised guidance and practical exercises for integrating RAIN into daily life.

Title of Work: Comme des Garçons: Art of the In-Between
Summary Abstract: Rei Kawakubo/Comme des Garçons: Art of the In-Between was the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute exhibition in 2017, featuring approximately 140 examples of Kawakubo’s womenswear from the early 1980s through 2017. Structured around thematic dichotomies such as Fashion/Anti-Fashion, Clothes/Not Clothes, Object/Subject, and Self/Other, it presented her investigations of liminal states in dress. It was the Costume Institute’s first monographic show on a living designer since its 1983 Yves Saint Laurent exhibition.

Summary Abstract: “7 Seconds” is a 1994 single by Senegalese singer Youssou N’Dour featuring Swedish singer Neneh Cherry, co-written with Cameron McVey and Jonny Dollar. Sung in Wolof, French, and English, it reflects on the first moments of a newborn’s life and the persistence of prejudice. The track became an international hit and appears on N’Dour’s album The Guide (Wommat).
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Four Quartets is a sequence of four interlinked poems—“Burnt Norton,” “East Coker,” “The Dry Salvages,” and “Little Gidding”—published together in 1943. The poems meditate on time and eternity, memory and history, and spiritual quest, drawing on Christian theology and philosophical reflection, and organize imagery around place and the elements (air, earth, water, fire). They reference contemporary events, including the Second World War and the Blitz in “Little Gidding,” and recur to motifs such as seasonal cycles, sea journeys, and the “still point.”

Summary Abstract: The Combahee River Collective Statement (1977) presents the history and politics of a Black feminist lesbian socialist collective formed in Boston in 1974 and named for Harriet Tubman’s 1863 Combahee River raid. It defines identity politics and analyzes the interlocking nature of racial, gender, class, and sexual oppression, asserting that Black women’s liberation requires dismantling all such systems. The statement critiques racism in the women’s movement and sexism in Black liberation, details organizing challenges, and outlines strategies including consciousness-raising, autonomous Black feminist organizing, coalition work, and campaigns around reproductive rights, healthcare, labor, and anti-heterosexism.

Title of Work: When: The Scientific Secrets of Perfect Timing
Summary Abstract: Daniel H. Pink synthesizes research from chronobiology, psychology, and economics to show how temporal patterns shape performance, decision-making, and health. He examines circadian peaks and troughs, the impact of beginnings, midpoints, and endings, the benefits of restorative breaks, and how synchronization enables effective collaboration. The book offers evidence-based guidance on aligning tasks, schedules, and group work with these timing principles.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Primary Subdomain(s): Positive Psychology & Human Potential,Cognitive & Affective Sciences

Summary Abstract: Heart Berries — 2025 Edition is Terese Marie Mailhot’s memoir recounting her upbringing in the Seabird Island community, her mother’s life and death, and the lasting impacts of abuse and colonial violence. Framed by episodes of hospitalization and recovery, it examines mental health, intimate relationships, and motherhood. The narrative traces how she assembles identity and authorship from fragmented memory and intergenerational trauma.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indigenous North American – First Nations, Native American traditions","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: A nonfiction account of the Oxford English Dictionary’s creation, the book centers on editor James A. H. Murray and Dr. William Chester Minor, a prolific volunteer contributor. Minor, an American Civil War veteran and former U.S. Army surgeon, was confined to Broadmoor Criminal Lunatic Asylum after being found not guilty by reason of insanity for a 1872 killing in London. Drawing on correspondence and records, it documents how Minor supplied thousands of illustrative quotations that advanced the OED’s compilation and how Murray later visited him at Broadmoor.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: From My Life: Poetry and Truth
Summary Abstract: From My Life: Poetry and Truth (Aus meinem Leben: Dichtung und Wahrheit) is Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s autobiography, issued in parts between 1811 and 1833. It covers his life from his 1749 birth in Frankfurt through his studies in Leipzig and Strasbourg, his early Sturm und Drang period, and concludes with his 1775 invitation to Weimar. Goethe recounts his family and education, friendships (notably with Johann Gottfried Herder), the Sesenheim episode with Friederike Brion, and the origins of works such as Götz von Berlichingen and The Sorrows of Young Werther, while considering the interplay of factual memory and literary shaping.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: A secret U.S. military experiment called Project NOAH infects inmates with a virus that escapes, unleashing vampire-like “virals” and collapsing civilization. A uniquely altered child, Amy Bellafonte, survives the outbreak with unusual resilience and becomes central to humanity’s fate. Decades later, in a fortified survivor colony, Amy’s arrival catalyzes a small group’s journey to seek answers and a way to fight the virals.

Title of Work: Political Consultation in the New Era: CPPCC Leadership

Title of Work: Philosophie der Arithmetik: Psychologische und logische Untersuchungen (Philosophy of Arithmetic: Psychological and Logical Investigations)
Summary Abstract: Husserl analyzes the genesis of arithmetic concepts through descriptive-psychological investigations, explaining numbers as arising from acts of collecting, unifying, and counting discrete items. He distinguishes intuitive (authentic) number presentations from symbolic representations that enable operations with large numbers and examines how signs and language mediate calculation. The work links these analyses to logical clarifications of unity, plurality, and cardinality to articulate the basic notions underlying arithmetic.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Primary Subdomain(s): Epistemology & Logic,"Philosophy of Mind, Science, Language"

Title of Work: Omnicide: Mania, Fatality, and the Future‑In‑Delirium
Summary Abstract: This book assembles a fragmentary catalog of “manias” (e.g., Augomania, Heliomania, Dromomania, Catoptromania, Colossomania, Monomania) to examine how obsessive fixation can escalate into an annihilatory orientation termed omnicide. Drawing on the writings of major modern Middle Eastern poets and authors (including Forugh Farrokhzad and Sadeq Hedayat), it explores obsession, delirium, and extremism through these themed entries. Published in 2019 in the Urbanomic x Sequence Press series, the paperback edition is 476 pages (ISBN 978-0-9975674-6-5).
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Persian / Zoroastrian – Zoroastrianism, Mazdean traditions"

Summary Abstract: Bitch! Dyke! Faghag! Whore! is a performance work created and performed by Penny Arcade that premiered in 1990. Combining monologues, satire, go-go dancing, and audience participation, it stages personal and social narratives around sexuality. The piece addresses censorship, queer identity, and sex work in the context of the early-1990s culture wars and AIDS era, and has been performed internationally.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: This work presents the Odù Ifá corpus, the canonical body of Yoruba Ifá divination literature comprising 256 odù, each containing numerous verses (èṣè Ifá). Compiled from oral chants by generations of Ifá Babaláwo chant composers, it documents the texts used in divination consultations. The collection preserves narratives, proverbs, and ritual prescriptions associated with each odù and outlines their interpretive application in practice.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "African Indigenous – Yoruba, Ifá, Akan, San, Bantu, Dogon"

Summary Abstract: The Garden of Earthly Delights is a large oil-on-oak triptych by Hieronymus Bosch, painted circa 1490–1505 and now housed in the Museo del Prado, Madrid. Its left panel shows the Garden of Eden with God presenting Eve to Adam, the central panel depicts crowds engaging in earthly pleasures amid bizarre flora and fauna, and the right panel portrays Hell with scenes of punishment. When closed, the exterior wings display a grisaille image of the Creation of the World.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Title of Work: Earth in Mind: On Education, Environment, and the Human Prospect
Summary Abstract: Earth in Mind is a collection of essays examining how modern education contributes to environmental degradation by separating knowledge from ethics, place, and ecological context. Orr argues for making ecological literacy a central purpose of education, emphasizing systems thinking, responsibility, and a sense of place. The book links educational reform to broader issues of culture, economics, politics, and design, and proposes curricular and institutional changes to cultivate sustainable practices and citizenship.

Title of Work: The Boy, the Mole, the Fox, and the Horse
Summary Abstract: Published in 2019, The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse is an illustrated book by Charlie Mackesy that follows a boy who meets three animal companions on a journey. Through spare dialogue and hand-lettered aphorisms paired with ink-and-watercolor drawings, the characters share reflections on friendship, kindness, vulnerability, and courage. The work is structured as episodic vignettes rather than a linear plot, focusing on connection and self-acceptance.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Cory Doctorow’s Enshittification (2025) defines “enshittification” as the lifecycle by which digital platforms initially prioritize users, then redirect value to business customers, and ultimately extract value for themselves, precipitating decline. Through case studies such as Facebook, the book explains how network effects, switching costs, and surveillance-driven advertising entrench lock-in and enable this shift. It outlines policy and technical remedies to “disenshittify” the internet and details how specific decisions led to the current state; the book is published by MCD and went on sale October 7, 2025.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Ignore It! — Behavior Change for Parents
Summary Abstract: Ignore It! outlines a behavioral parenting method in which parents strategically withdraw attention from minor, attention-seeking misbehavior to reduce its frequency and increase parenting satisfaction. It provides guidance on when to selectively look the other way and how to reinforce appropriate behaviors across everyday situations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract:
This work presents a comprehensive overview of Thailand’s economic transformation and political development, drawing on sources in both Thai and English.
It traces the transition from a rice-based agrarian economy to an industrializing economy and analyzes how state institutions, business groups, the military, and the monarchy shaped policy and power.
The focus is on the post–World War II decades, linking economic change with social forces and the evolution of political regimes.

Summary Abstract: Paul Ricoeur’s Oneself as Another (1990) offers a hermeneutic-phenomenological analysis of selfhood that distinguishes idem-identity (sameness) from ipse-identity (selfhood) and introduces narrative identity as the mediation of personal permanence over time. Through studies of language, action, and attestation, it presents the self as a capable agent who can speak, act, narrate, and assume responsibility. The work culminates in a “little ethics” that moves from selfhood to solicitude for the other and to justice, showing how self-understanding is constituted in relation to alterity.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: Set in the Northern Song dynasty, Jin Ping Mei follows the rise and fall of the wealthy merchant-official Ximen Qing and the complex dynamics of his polygynous household. It begins with Pan Jinlian’s adulterous affair with Ximen and the poisoning of her husband Wu Dalang, then traces the intrigues, graft, and commercial and sexual entanglements that fuel Ximen’s ascent. The narrative culminates in Ximen’s death from overindulgence and the subsequent collapse of his household.

The Book of Thoth (Egyptian Tarot) is Aleister Crowley’s comprehensive exposition of the Thoth Tarot, created in collaboration with Lady Frieda Harris and published in 1944. It sets out the theoretical framework of the Tarot within Thelema, Hermetic Qabalah, astrology, and alchemy, and explains the symbolism, titles, and correspondences of every card in the Major and Minor Arcana. The book also outlines methods of divination and practical guidance for using the deck.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Egyptian (Ancient) – Pharaonic, Hermopolitan, Theban traditions"

Summary Abstract: After a body from the Thames is misidentified as heir John Harmon, the dust-heap fortune passes to the Boffins, while the living Harmon returns in disguise as Boffin’s secretary, John Rokesmith (also Julius Handford), and courts Bella Wilfer as Boffin feigns miserliness to test her. A parallel plot follows Lizzie Hexam, pursued by barrister Eugene Wrayburn and schoolmaster Bradley Headstone; Headstone assaults Wrayburn and later drowns with blackmailer Rogue Riderhood. In the end Harmon reveals his identity, marries Bella, and reclaims his inheritance, while Wrayburn recovers and marries Lizzie.

The Hour of the Star (1977) is a novella by Clarice Lispector narrated by Rodrigo S.M., who tells and analyzes the life of Macabéa, a poor young typist who migrated from Brazil’s Northeast to Rio de Janeiro. It traces her marginal existence, a brief relationship with the worker Olímpico who leaves her for a co-worker, and her visit to a fortune-teller who predicts happiness. Shortly afterward, Macabéa is struck by a car and dies, an event framed by the narrator’s ongoing meta-narrative about authorship and representation.

Title of Work: The Heart's Shout: The Liberating Wisdom of Da Avabhasa
Author Full Name: Franklin Albert Jones (Bubba Free John, Da Free John, Adi Da Samraj)
Summary Abstract: The Heart's Shout: The Liberating Wisdom of Da Avabhasa (1993) is a compilation of talks and writings by Franklin Albert Jones—later known as Adi Da Samraj—presenting his Reality-Teaching under the name Da Avabhasa. It gathers discourses from 1977 to 1993 and includes devotee accounts of his face-to-face instruction.

Summary Abstract: Published posthumously by Gallimard in 1951, La Condition ouvrière collects Simone Weil’s writings on industrial labor drawn from her 1934–1935 factory work and later observations in French plants. It comprises the Journal d’usine, letters (to unionists, engineers, and others), reports from the 1936 strikes, and essays such as La rationalisation and Principes d’un projet pour un régime intérieur nouveau, examining factory organization, mechanization, speed, wages, and management-labor relations. The volume combines detailed logs of tasks and piece-rate systems with proposals for workplace governance and reflections on conditions for non-servile work.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Zeus forbids the gods to interfere and, after weighing the fates, grants the day’s advantage to the Trojans. Hector drives the Achaeans back toward their fortifications; Diomedes and Nestor are checked by Zeus’s thunderbolts, and the archer Teucer briefly holds the line until Hector disables him with a stone. By nightfall Hera and Athena are compelled to desist, and the Trojans bivouac with watchfires, vowing to press on and burn the ships at dawn.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Reign of Error: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to America’s Public Schools
Summary Abstract: Diane Ravitch examines the “corporate reform” agenda—charter expansion, vouchers, school closures, and test-driven accountability—and argues these privatization strategies lack evidentiary support and undermine public education. Drawing on data about standardized testing, teacher evaluation, and international comparisons, she challenges the narrative of a systemic public-school “crisis.” The book proposes alternatives centered on equitable funding, high-quality early childhood education, reduced class sizes, a broad curriculum (including the arts), wraparound social services, and strengthening the teaching profession within a public system.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The World As It Is: A Memoir of the Obama White House
Summary Abstract: This memoir by Ben Rhodes, President Barack Obama’s deputy national security adviser for strategic communications, chronicles his eight years in the administration and its foreign policy process. It details Rhodes’s involvement in initiatives including the U.S. opening to Cuba and the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement, as well as responses to events such as the Arab Spring, the Syrian conflict, the rise of ISIS, and relations with Russia. The book also covers speechwriting, back-channel diplomacy, internal debates, and the 2016 election and presidential transition.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

It also features his didactic medical poem Urjuzah fi al-Tibb, a versified compendium of the medical science of his time.

Summary Abstract: This 30th Anniversary edition presents Coleman Barks’s English renderings of Jalal al-Din Rumi’s thirteenth-century poetry in a single-volume selection drawn from the ghazals of the Divan-e Shams and the six books of the Masnavi/Mathnawi. The revised and expanded reissue includes a new introduction by Barks and more than 80 never-before-published poems. First published in 1995, the 2025 edition marks the 30th year since the collection’s debut.

Summary Abstract: This work surveys sem-ena-werq (wax-and-gold) poetic cycles composed by Ethiopian qene poets (“wax-poets”) circa 1700, during the Zemene Mesafint (Era of Princes). It describes the genre’s layered double-meaning technique and its roles in liturgical instruction, moral teaching, and veiled sociopolitical commentary. The study situates these compositions within church-school performance traditions and courtly patronage of the period.

Summary Abstract: Lunheng (Balanced Inquiries) is a 1st-century CE collection of essays by Eastern Han scholar Wang Chong that critically examines received doctrines and popular beliefs. It treats subjects such as omens, apocrypha, divination, ghosts, cosmology, and natural phenomena, presenting naturalistic explanations grounded in observation and argument. The work also addresses issues in ethics, politics, and knowledge.

Title of Work: The Roots of Vedānta: Selections from Śaṅkara's Writings

Summary Abstract: The Transmission of Doubt is a 1984 collection of talks and essays by Da Free John on the transcendence of scientific materialism through “radical understanding.” Compiled and edited with an introduction and commentary by Georg Feuerstein, it was published in Clearlake, California by Dawn Horse Press and totals 484 pages. Subjects include transcendentalism, the relationship between religion and science (post-1946), and spiritual life.

Title of Work: Energy Medicine: Balancing Your Body's Energies for Optimal Health, Joy, and Vitality
Summary Abstract: Donna Eden presents a system of “energy medicine” that conceptualizes health as influenced by interrelated subtle energy systems, including meridians, chakras, the aura, and the five rhythms. Drawing on applied kinesiology and traditions such as acupuncture, she provides step-by-step self-care routines—like tracing meridians, tapping acupoints, and daily balancing practices—intended to assess and harmonize these energies. The book includes techniques for energy testing and protocols aimed at addressing stress, pain, fatigue, and emotional imbalance.

Title of Work: Education & Human Dignity in a Changing Tunisia
Summary Abstract: Belhassine examines a 2017 Transitional Justice Barometer study urging reform of Tunisian history curricula to counter official neglect of dissident histories and better reflect the recent past. Drawing on qualitative interviews with secondary history and civics teachers, the study distinguishes history from memory and identifies omissions in textbooks, including marginalized regional narratives and the dominance of Bourguiba’s figure. It recommends shifting from rote dictation to participatory, multimedia pedagogy and broadening content beyond politics, with teachers linking transitional justice to correcting the historical record and promoting social cohesion.

Summary Abstract: An anthology of ancient Greek and Roman literary theory, this volume collects Plato’s Ion (with his critique of poets in the Republic), Aristotle’s Poetics, Horace’s Art of Poetry (Ars Poetica), and Longinus’s On the Sublime.The texts address the nature and function of literature, discussing topics such as poetic inspiration, mimesis and tragedy, decorum, and sublimity.These works established much of the terminology and key questions that structured later Western literary criticism.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Al-Adhawiyya fi al-Ma'ad (The Adhawiyya on Return)
Summary Abstract:
Avicenna’s Epistle al-Adhawiyya fi al-Maʿād outlines his eschatology: it defines maʿād as the state reached at death, surveys and rejects erroneous views of the hereafter, and argues for the immateriality of the human self and its necessary survival after death.  
It classifies types of humans with their postmortem destinies and examines the question of bodily resurrection.  
The work also develops a hermeneutic of revelation: prophetic law addresses the multitude through imaginal and figurative discourse for ethical guidance, while precise metaphysical truths are established by reason rather than the literal sense of scripture, alongside a critique of kalām theology.

Summary Abstract: A Socratic dialogue, The Republic examines the nature of justice in the individual and the city by constructing an ideal polis ruled by philosopher-kings. It outlines a tripartite class structure corresponding to a tripartite soul, advances the theory of Forms culminating in the Form of the Good, and uses the Sun, Line, and Cave analogies to explain knowledge and education. The work traces a sequence of political constitutions from aristocracy to timocracy, oligarchy, democracy, and tyranny, prescribes education and communal arrangements for the guardian class, and concludes with the Myth of Er on the soul’s fate after death.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: Season of Migration to the North (50th Anniversary Edition)
Summary Abstract: An unnamed Sudanese narrator returns to his Nile village after studying in Europe and meets fellow villager Mustafa Sa’eed. Mustafa recounts his earlier life in London, including relationships with several women, his marriage to Jean Morris whom he kills, and the ensuing murder trial; he later disappears in the Nile, leaving a widow, Hosna, and two sons. The narrator assumes responsibility for Mustafa’s family and papers as village pressures force Hosna to marry Wad Rayyes, leading to Hosna killing Wad Rayyes and herself, and the story concludes with the narrator’s near-drowning in the river.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Aphanipoiesis and the Conditions of Learning
Summary Abstract: Bateson introduces the neologism “aphanipoiesis” to describe the unseen coalescence of multiple interdependent processes in living systems that bring forth vitality, deriving from Greek roots meaning “unseen” and “to bring forth.” She situates this concept alongside abductive reasoning (Bateson, Peirce) and anticipatory systems, describing how living systems’ mutual responsiveness precedes and conditions what can later be named as change or emergence. The work highlights that hypotheses and learning are shaped by pre-habituated anticipatory patterns and transcontextual mutual learning, which together constitute the conditions under which new perceptions and meanings become possible.

Title of Work: The Way of St Benedict: A Rule of Life for the 21st Century
Summary Abstract: Rowan Williams examines St Benedict’s sixth-century Rule, tracing its enduring influence on Benedictine communities and its wider impact on civic, artistic, intellectual, and institutional life, and its continued relevance for contemporary readers. Structured in two parts, the book addresses monastic virtues and stability, monks and mission in England, ecumenical hopes, the future of Europe, early medieval monastic reform, and Abbot Cuthbert Butler’s account of mysticism. Published in 2020 by Bloomsbury, it is 160 pages.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: The Upside of Irrationality (2010) by Dan Ariely examines how systematic biases and nonrational motivations shape decisions at work and at home, drawing on laboratory and field experiments. It reports findings such as the performance costs of very large incentives, the tendency to overvalue one’s own creations, the influence of revenge and adaptation, and the effects of empathy gaps and distance on caring. The book explains when and why irrational behavior can yield both drawbacks and unexpected benefits in organizational and personal contexts.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Karen Attiah recounts Jamal Khashoggi’s final year as a Washington Post columnist and the events surrounding his disappearance and murder. The book details his self-exile, his collaboration with Attiah to publish the Post’s first syndicated Arabic column, and his efforts to explain Saudi Arabia to a global audience. It also examines Saudi Arabia’s influence across Washington, Wall Street, and Silicon Valley, and situates Khashoggi’s case within broader pressures on journalism and activism in the Arab world.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Abortion Stories: American Literature Before Roe v. Wade
Summary Abstract: Abortion Stories: American Literature Before Roe v. Wade is a 2025 Penguin Classics anthology edited and introduced by Karen Weingarten, with a foreword by Rebecca Traister and an afterword by Renee Bracey Sherman. It collects stories, poems, essays, and memoirs about abortion published before 1973, including works by Langston Hughes, Gwendolyn Brooks, Edgar Allan Poe, Eugene O’Neill, and Shirley Chisholm, alongside firsthand accounts from providers and seekers. Spanning themes of love, death, medicine, motherhood, enslavement, and emancipation, the volume presents diverse literary representations of abortion in the United States prior to Roe.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Light in the Dark/Luz en lo Oscuro: Rewriting Identity, Spirituality, Reality (Posthumous Edition)
Summary Abstract: Posthumously assembled and edited by AnaLouise Keating, this book gathers Gloria Anzaldúa’s late writings that elaborate her theories of nepantla and conocimiento, spiritual activism, and the Coyolxauhqui imperative. Blending English and Spanish and combining autohistoria-teoría with poetry and essay, Anzaldúa reframes identity, subjectivity, and reality through Indigenous, Chicana, and queer epistemologies to address fragmentation, healing, and transformation. It advances concepts such as nos/otras and new tribalism to map processes of personal and collective change grounded in borderlands consciousness.

Title of Work: Why Religion Is Good for American Democracy
Summary Abstract: Robert Wuthnow contends that American religion benefits democracy chiefly through pluralistic contention among diverse groups, which stimulates debate about democratic principles rather than imposing unifying values. Examining cases from the Great Depression, World War II, the civil rights movement, welfare reform, immigrant-rights and economic-justice campaigns, and responses to COVID-19, he shows how religious advocacy and counteradvocacy sharpen discussions of authoritarianism, liberty of conscience, freedom of assembly, human dignity, citizens’ rights, equality, and public health. He highlights key principles of democratic governance and delineates what religion can and cannot achieve in sustaining them.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: I Do What I Do (2017) by Raghuram G. Rajan compiles his speeches and writings from his tenure as Governor of the Reserve Bank of India (2013–2016). It covers India’s monetary policy and inflation targeting framework, exchange-rate and capital-flow management, banking-sector stress and balance-sheet clean-up, financial inclusion, and broader growth–stability issues. The pieces are accompanied by contextual notes that situate them within events such as the 2013 taper tantrum and subsequent policy reforms.

Title of Work: What You Should Know About Politics... But Don't
Summary Abstract: Jessamyn Conrad’s 2008 book What You Should Know About Politics... But Don’t is a nonpartisan guide that breaks down major U.S. political issues and explains who stands for what and why. Organized issue by issue, it covers elections, the economy, foreign policy, the military, civil liberties, health care, energy, the environment, culture-war topics, socioeconomic policy, homeland security, education, and trade. The first edition was published by Arcade Publishing in August 2008 (336 pages; ISBN 1559708832).
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Sixteen Satires is a collection of sixteen poems in dactylic hexameter by the Roman poet Juvenal, compiled in five books and commonly dated to the early second century CE (around 110). The poems portray social life in imperial Rome and treat topics such as corruption, client–patron relations, wealth and luxury, sexuality and marriage, urban hardships, provincial versus urban values, and the nature of human wishes. Notable satires include Satire 3 (Umbricius leaving Rome), Satire 6 (on women and marriage), Satire 10 (on misguided human desires and the phrase “bread and circuses”), and the fragmentary Satire 16 on soldiers’ legal privileges.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: Herodotus’s Histories investigates the origins and course of the Greco-Persian Wars, tracing the rise of the Persian Empire and its conflicts with the Greek city-states. It interweaves accounts of rulers such as Croesus, Cyrus, Cambyses, Darius, and Xerxes with narratives of key battles including Marathon, Thermopylae, Salamis, Plataea, and Mycale. The work also records geographical and ethnographic observations on peoples and customs across regions such as Egypt, Lydia, Scythia, and Asia Minor.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: At seventeen, Arun emerges from a fire without memories or identity and is taken in by Janani, soon discovering he can sense and manipulate other minds. Isolated by this telepathic insight and existing outside conventional boundaries of man/woman and mind/body, he encounters Rahul Moghe, another like him whose power exceeds his own. Warned of Rahul’s danger, Arun flees, beginning a search that may reveal the mystery of his past.

Title of Work: Traité de la Réintégration des Êtres
Summary Abstract: Martines de Pasqually’s Traité de la Réintégration des Êtres (c. 1770) sets out a Christian theosophical cosmogony in which God emanates spiritual beings, some of whom prevaricate, prompting God to create the material cosmos as a place of exile and correction. It presents Adam as a mediating figure tasked with working for the reintegration of fallen spirits, but whose own fall through disobedience deprives him of his original powers. The treatise outlines the path of reintegration—through repentance, prayer, observance, and theurgic operations—culminating in the work of the “Repairer” (Jesus Christ), by which beings return to their primordial divine order.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Title of Work: It Would Be Night in Caracas
Summary Abstract: Set in Caracas, the novel follows Adelaida Falcón, who buries her mother and soon after has her apartment taken over by armed groups amid Venezuela’s unrest. She discovers her neighbor Aurora dead and learns Aurora had dual Venezuelan-Spanish citizenship and was preparing to emigrate, prompting Adelaida to assume her identity to obtain documents. The narrative follows her efforts to secure passage to Spain while navigating shortages and violence in the city.

Summary Abstract: Material Men is a 2015 dance work by choreographer Shobana Jeyasingh, commissioned by Southbank Centre and premiered in a double bill with Strange Blooms at Queen Elizabeth Hall before touring UK venues. It is a duet for two performers of the Indian diaspora that juxtaposes classical South Asian dance and hip hop to examine rhythm, location, and shared histories. The work features a newly commissioned score by Elena Kats-Chernin performed live by The Smith Quartet with additional sound design by Leafcutter John, and was originally danced by Shailesh Bahoran and Sooraj Subramaniam.

Title of Work: Sishu Zhangju Jizhu (Collected Commentaries on the Four Books)
Summary Abstract: Completed around 1190, Sishu Zhangju Jizhu is Zhu Xi’s annotated edition of the Four Books—the Great Learning, Doctrine of the Mean, Analects, and Mencius. It establishes a chapter-and-verse structure (zhangju) and compiles collected notes (jizhu), including Zhu Xi’s redaction and reordering of the Great Learning and Doctrine of the Mean as texts extracted from the Book of Rites. Reflecting the Cheng-Zhu Neo-Confucian interpretation, it was officially adopted in the Yuan dynasty as the standard for the civil service examinations and remained the basis through the Ming and Qing.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: Renegades: Born in the USA (2021) is an illustrated volume of conversations between Barack Obama and Bruce Springsteen—drawn from and expanding their Higher Ground podcast—about their personal histories, creative work, and the American experience. It features more than 350 photographs and archival materials, including new material from the podcast sessions, Obama’s annotated speeches, Springsteen’s handwritten lyrics, and discussions of family, race, masculinity, politics, and the gap between the American Dream and reality.

Summary Abstract: Greg Grandin traces how the American frontier myth functioned as a safety valve, channeling social conflict into outward expansion that legitimized Indigenous dispossession, slavery’s spread, the Mexican–American War, and later overseas empire. As territorial and geopolitical frontiers closed, he shows U.S. politics turning inward toward border militarization, mass incarceration, and nativist movements epitomized by demands for a southern border wall. Spanning the early republic through NAFTA and contemporary immigration policy, the book argues the border—rather than the frontier—has become the central organizing symbol of American power.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Uncommon Wisdom: Fault Lines in the Foundations of Atheism examines the rise of militant atheism and argues that modern science is incomplete due to unresolved problems of meaning rooted in the problem of universals. It posits that reality includes a hierarchy of abstract ideas in addition to material objects, drawing on Vedic philosophy to present God as a primordial idea from which others arise. The book proposes an epistemology in which truth is discovered through faith and verified by reason and experiment, and critiques reductionism, materialism, determinism, evolutionism, and relativism.

Summary Abstract: Beyond Theology (1964) is Alan Watts’s examination of Christianity’s relevance in a modern, multicultural context, questioning whether traditional forms can endure. Watts deconstructs Christian theology using concepts from psychology, linguistics, science, and Eastern philosophy, while tracing Christianity’s influence on Western culture. He ultimately points toward a nondualistic spirituality that emphasizes direct experience beyond ritual, myth, doctrine, and theology.
