Summary Abstract: Harriet Beecher Stowe’s 1852 novel follows Uncle Tom, an enslaved man sold by a Kentucky planter to pay debts, whose path leads to New Orleans under Augustine St. Clare and then to Simon Legree’s plantation, where Tom ultimately dies. A parallel plot traces Eliza’s escape with her son across the Ohio River to avoid being sold, aided by antislavery networks. Through intersecting narratives, the book depicts slavery’s impact on families, commerce, law, and religion in the United States.

Summary Abstract: Yascha Mounk examines the dual threats to liberal democracy, distinguishing between “illiberal democracy” (majoritarian rule without rights) and “undemocratic liberalism” (rights-based governance with weak popular control). He traces the rise of populism in the U.S. and Europe and analyzes drivers such as economic stagnation, inequality, demographic change, and the restructuring of the public sphere by social media. The book surveys contemporary case studies to show how liberal norms and institutions are being undermined. It concludes with proposals to renew liberal democracy by making government more responsive while safeguarding individual rights and the rule of law.

Summary Abstract: Black Square is a 1915 painting by Kazimir Malevich consisting of a black square set against a white ground. It debuted at the Last Futurist Exhibition of Paintings 0,10 in Petrograd in 1915, where it was hung high across a corner like an icon. The work introduced Malevich’s Suprematism, a movement based on basic geometric forms and non-objective composition.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Truth (or The Overthrow) is a lost treatise by the sophist Protagoras (c. 450 BCE), known from fragments and later reports. It advanced the “man is the measure of all things” doctrine, holding that the truth of perceptions and beliefs is relative to each perceiver. The work’s relativist epistemology is preserved chiefly through critiques and discussions in later authors, especially Plato’s Theaetetus.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Summary Abstract: Medieval Writings on Female Spirituality is a 2002 Penguin Classics anthology edited by Elizabeth Spearing that collects biographies, letters, poems, visions, and revelations by or about medieval women, tracing developments in piety and the link between female spirituality and the body. Contents include Hildegard of Bingen, Christina of Markyate, Hadewijch, Christine the Astonishing, Mary of Oignies, Elizabeth of Spaalbeek, Marguerite Porete, Bridget of Sweden, Julian of Norwich, an anonymous Revelation of Purgatory, and excerpts from The Book of Margery Kempe; the volume features an introduction and notes by Spearing. Published May 28, 2002, the paperback edition runs 320 pages.

Summary Abstract: Mistrust: Why Losing Faith in Institutions Provides the Tools to Transform Them (2021) examines the rise of mistrust in governments, media, corporations, and other institutions and its implications for representative democracy. Drawing on movements from the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street to cryptocurrency advocates and #MeToo, Zuckerman analyzes how people seek change when elections and protests feel ineffective. He outlines four levers—law, markets, code, and norms—and a focus on civic efficacy as frameworks for transforming, bypassing, or rebuilding institutions.

Drawing on rural fieldwork from 2000–2017, the 356-page book is organized into ten sections: Drought and Hunger; Poverty; School Meals; Health Care; Child Development and Elementary Education; Employment Guarantee; Food Security and the Public Distribution System; Corporate Power and Technology; War and Peace; and Top-up. The essays analyze how government policies and inaction shape development, rights, equality, and economic outcomes in India.

Title of Work: The Internet Is Not the Answer
Summary Abstract: Andrew Keen’s 2015 book argues that the internet has failed to deliver its utopian promise, instead concentrating wealth and power in a few platforms, displacing jobs, and deepening economic inequality. Using case studies such as Kodak vs. Instagram and the disruption of music, journalism, and retail, it details how data-driven, advertising-supported services monetize users, erode privacy, and undermine creative livelihoods. The book traces the shift from early cyber-utopian ideals to surveillance- and data-centric business models and proposes regulatory and civic remedies to mitigate these harms.

Summary Abstract: Rafa: My Story (2011) is Rafael Nadal’s memoir recounting his upbringing in Mallorca, the influence of his family and coach Toni Nadal, and his rise from junior prodigy to multiple Grand Slam champion. He details training methods, routines, injuries, and the psychological and tactical approach behind his game, including accounts of landmark matches such as the 2008 Wimbledon final and his 2010 U.S. Open run to complete the career Grand Slam. The book also covers his relationships with key rivals, notably Roger Federer, and the support team around him.

Summary Abstract: Astra Taylor’s The Age of Insecurity (2023) argues that insecurity is a manufactured condition rooted in contemporary capitalism and political choices rather than an individual shortcoming. Drawing on history, political economy, and reportage, the book traces how insecurity is produced and exploited across work, housing, health care, borders, technology, and the climate crisis to concentrate power. It concludes by outlining collective and policy strategies—such as robust public goods, social insurance, and labor organizing—to build shared security.

Summary Abstract: The Transparency Society (2012) analyzes transparency as a dominant norm in digital, neoliberal societies, arguing that the imperative to disclose turns social relations into information flows and marketable data. Han contends that transparency operates through voluntary self-exposure and pervasive data surveillance, shifting power from disciplinary structures to a society of exhibition governed by metrics. He argues this imperative erodes privacy, trust, shame, and otherness—conditions for intimacy and politics—thereby flattening the public sphere and promoting conformity and self-exploitation.

Summary Abstract: Donna Haraway examines how humans and other species co-constitute one another through everyday “contact zones,” advancing the concepts of companion species and “becoming-with.” Drawing on cases from dog training, laboratory animals (including transgenic OncoMouse), agriculture, and microbiology, she analyzes how practices of care, killing, labor, and technoscience shape multispecies worlds. The book develops an ethic of “response-ability,” challenging human exceptionalism by emphasizing situated, accountable interspecies relations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Oresteia: Agamemnon, The Libation Bearers, The Eumenides
Summary Abstract: Aeschylus’s Oresteia (458 BCE) is a tragic trilogy comprising Agamemnon, The Libation Bearers, and The Eumenides. It depicts the House of Atreus: Clytemnestra murders Agamemnon on his return from Troy; their son Orestes, with Electra, kills Clytemnestra and Aegisthus and is pursued by the Furies. In Athens, Athena establishes the Areopagus court, Orestes is acquitted, and the Furies are transformed into the Eumenides, signaling a shift from blood vengeance to civic justice.

Title of Work: Skunk Works: A Personal Memoir of My Years at Lockheed
Summary Abstract: Skunk Works is Ben Rich’s memoir of leading Lockheed’s advanced development division, chronicling the design and clandestine programs behind the U-2, SR-71 Blackbird, and F-117 Nighthawk. It details collaborations with the CIA and U.S. Air Force through the Cold War, the emergence of stealth technology from the Have Blue demonstrator to combat use in Operation Desert Storm. The book also outlines Skunk Works’ management methods, rapid development practices, and the technical trade-offs of low-observable aircraft.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Other Primary Domains: Leadership & Management Sciences,"Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Summary Abstract: On War is a theoretical treatise that defines war as a continuation of politics by other means and examines the primacy of political objectives in conflict. Clausewitz distinguishes idealized “absolute war” from real war and highlights friction, uncertainty (“fog of war”), and moral forces that shape outcomes. He introduces key strategic concepts including the remarkable trinity (violence, chance, and reason), the center of gravity, the culminating point of the attack, and argues that defense is the stronger form of warfare.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The Savage Landscape is a book by Cal Flyn examining our relationship to wilderness, journeying into forests, mountains, and deserts to explore what nature does in our absence. Structured across ten chapters, each based on visits to some of the world’s wildest places, it asks what constitutes wilderness and how such landscapes might be appreciated or preserved. It incorporates human stories from these environments, including ascetics in deserts, shepherds facing wolves, missionaries in jungles, and lamas meditating beneath high peaks. Scheduled from William Collins for 7 May 2026, it is 336 pages.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Unequal Childhoods examines how social class shapes child-rearing practices and children’s experiences with schools and other institutions, using in-depth ethnographic observations and interviews with Black and white families across middle-, working-class, and poor backgrounds. Lareau identifies two predominant logics—concerted cultivation among middle-class parents and the accomplishment of natural growth among working-class and poor parents—that structure language use, daily schedules, and parent–institution interactions. These patterns produce systematic differences in children’s ability to navigate institutional settings. The 2025 New Preface Edition includes a new preface to the original study.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: On Time and Water (2019) is a nonfiction book by Icelandic author Andri Snær Magnason that blends reportage, interviews, memoir, and myth to examine contemporary climate change through human and geological timescales. Centered on water in its many forms—glaciers, rivers, seas, and the atmosphere—it connects scientific research on melting ice, sea-level rise, and ocean acidification with the author’s family stories and Icelandic cultural history. The book frames century-scale projections within the span of a few human lifetimes to describe anticipated changes to Earth’s water systems.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The Dawn Horse Testament (1985) by Da Free John sets out his comprehensive “Way of the Heart,” presenting the seven stages of life and a path of spiritual practice centered on recognition of the Divine via devotion to the Guru. It codifies right-life disciplines—devotional worship, study, meditation, service, moral precepts, dietary and sexual conduct, and yogic “conductivity” of the Spirit-Current. The text describes progressive practice culminating in the “Perfect Practice” and the phases he names transfiguration, transformation, and translation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Summary Abstract: The People Vs Tech (2018) argues that social media, big data, and algorithmic systems are destabilizing liberal democracy by amplifying polarization and disinformation, enabling surveillance and micro‑targeted political manipulation, and concentrating power in a handful of dominant platforms. Jamie Bartlett explains how these technologies erode core democratic institutions and norms through opaque algorithms, data monopolies, and platform incentives, illustrated by recent political events and scandals. He concludes with proposals for regulation, data rights, competition policy, design changes, and civic education to realign technology with democratic governance.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Three Ecologies presents Guattari’s “ecosophy,” linking environmental ecology, social relations, and human subjectivity (mental ecology) as mutually implicated domains. It argues that Integrated World Capitalism generates interconnected environmental, social, and psychic degradations, demanding transversal, micropolitical interventions across these levels. The work proposes practices of resingularization and new collective assemblages—in media, urbanism, and education—to transform modes of life and semiotic regimes.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Mountain Dwelling is a poem by the Tang dynasty poet Wang Wei that depicts a reclusive home in the mountains. Through concise images of surrounding woods, water, and shifting light, it outlines a quiet routine and the site’s seclusion. The poem focuses on solitude and the immediacy of nature rather than social life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: Pihkala synthesizes interdisciplinary research and anxiety theory to analyze definitions and forms of eco-anxiety and climate anxiety, integrating empirical findings across psychology, sociology, and environmental humanities. He identifies uncertainty, unpredictability, and uncontrollability as core drivers; concludes most manifestations are non-clinical; and examines related constructs such as ecological grief, solastalgia, ecological trauma, and the shaping role of social dynamics. The article links eco-anxiety to fear, worry, and existential anxiety, and distinguishes paralyzing responses from “practical anxiety” that motivates information-seeking and behavioral reassessment, with implications for healthcare and public discourse.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Anuvyakhyana is a Sanskrit sub-commentary by Madhva on his Brahma-sutra-bhashya, written to clarify and expand his interpretations of the Brahma Sutras. It systematically presents Dvaita Vedanta, articulating doctrines such as the fivefold difference (pancha-bheda) and the supremacy of Vishnu while critiquing rival schools like Advaita and Vishishtadvaita. The work integrates hermeneutics and epistemology to defend real difference among God, souls, and matter and outlines the path and nature of liberation within a hierarchy of souls.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: I cannot locate an authoritative record of a 2021 work titled “Shanghai’s Reform Experience: Urban Leadership and Development” by Han Zheng, so the content cannot be verified. Without verifiable source material from the work, a factual abstract cannot be provided.

Summary Abstract: The book contends that the “E‑Myth” is the mistaken belief that most small business founders are entrepreneurs, when many are technicians experiencing an entrepreneurial seizure. It outlines three essential roles—Entrepreneur, Manager, Technician—and a life cycle of Infancy, Adolescence, and Maturity to explain common small-business pitfalls. Gerber prescribes building a franchise‑prototype business by systematizing work—“working on” rather than “in” the business—via a Business Development Program defining a Primary Aim, Strategic Objective, and organizational, management, people, marketing, and systems strategies.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: De Natura Deorum (On the Nature of the Gods)
Summary Abstract: Composed in 45 BCE, Cicero’s De Natura Deorum is a philosophical dialogue in three books that investigates the existence and nature of the gods. Book 1 presents and critiques Epicurean theology; Book 2 expounds the Stoic doctrine of divine providence and teleology; Book 3 offers an Academic Skeptic rebuttal to both positions. Through dialectical debate, it examines issues such as divine providence, the problem of evil, cosmology, and the grounds of religious practice, without reaching a definitive conclusion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"

Title of Work: The Blue White Red (Identity Psychology Edition)
Summary Abstract: When the flamboyant returnee Moki comes back from France, Massala-Massala leaves his village to chase the Parisian dream, only to be drawn into the precarious underworld of undocumented immigrants; after a botched scheme selling metro passes bought with a stolen checkbook, he is jailed and deported. The novel depicts the gap between postcolonial aspirations of success in the former colonial center and the often harsh realities facing African migrants in France.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Cuban Counterpoint: Tobacco and Sugar (New Critical Edition)
Summary Abstract: Fernando Ortiz examines how Cuba’s tobacco and sugar industries structured the island’s economic, social, and cultural development from the colonial era into the twentieth century. By juxtaposing tobacco’s predominantly smallholder, artisanal production with sugar’s plantation-based, capital- and slave-labor–intensive system, he analyzes labor regimes, migration, race relations, technology, and Cuba’s integration into global markets. The work introduces the concept of “transculturation” to explain the formation of Cuban culture through interactions among Indigenous, African, and European elements under slavery and colonial rule.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Barlaam and Josaphat: A Christian Tale of the Buddha
Summary Abstract: An Old French verse hagiography composed by Gui de Cambrai around 1220, Barlaam and Josaphat adapts the life of the Buddha into a Christian saint’s legend. It tells of Josaphat, an Indian prince secluded by his pagan father after a prophecy, who discovers suffering and impermanence, meets the monk Barlaam, and converts through a series of didactic parables. Josaphat evangelizes his realm, brings about his father’s conversion and abdication, and eventually renounces the throne to live an ascetic life. The work functions as a moralizing romance promoting Christian renunciation and salvation through faith and ascetic practice.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: The Hidden Light of Objects (2014) is Mai Al-Nakib’s debut collection of linked short stories set primarily in Kuwait and across the Middle East. The stories follow ordinary lives across decades before and after the 1990–91 Gulf War, tracing the effects of conflict, migration, and social change on families and youth. Recurring objects serve as mnemonic anchors that connect characters and timelines, revealing how personal and collective histories intersect.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Boots on the Ground: Modern Land Warfare from Iraq to Ukraine
Summary Abstract: Leigh Neville surveys the evolution of modern land warfare since the early 2000s, using case studies from Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, Yemen, and Ukraine to analyze how technology, tactics, and organization have changed on the ground. The book examines key components of contemporary combat—including artillery, infantry fighting vehicles, combat engineering, special operations, and the “grey zone” of cyber and information operations—highlighting the battlefield impact of drones and networked systems seen in Ukraine. It also assesses NATO armies and special forces preparedness for potential conflicts with state adversaries such as Russia, Iran, or China, while emphasizing the enduring centrality of trained infantry in future wars.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Women & Power — Illustrated 2025 Ed. presents Mary Beard’s account of how women’s voices and authority have been constrained in Western culture, developed from her lectures “The Public Voice of Women” and “Women in Power.” Drawing on examples from classical literature and myth through contemporary politics, it examines the policing of female speech, the coding of power as male, and recurring symbols such as Medusa that shape perceptions of female authority. This illustrated edition pairs the text with images that contextualize its arguments and historical references.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: To Build a Free China: A Citizen’s Journey
Summary Abstract: Xu Zhiyong’s memoir chronicles his work as a lawyer and activist in China’s rights movement, including founding the New Citizens Movement and campaigning for legal reform, free expression, and civic participation amid repeated detentions. It recounts cases and initiatives such as the Sun Zhigang incident, the Southern Metropolis Daily case, and the activities of Gongmeng (Open Constitution Initiative), and includes his 2013 court statement “For Freedom, Justice, and Love”. Published in 2017, the book is translated by Joshua Rosenzweig and Yaxue Cao, with an introduction by Andrew J. Nathan.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "East Asia – China, Japan, Korea, Mongolia",Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: Why the Germans Do It Better: Notes from a Grown-Up Country
Summary Abstract: John Kampfner surveys Germany’s post-1945 transformation and contemporary political culture, focusing on federalism, coalition governance, the social market economy, and the country’s approach to historical memory. Through reportage and case studies, he examines the Mittelstand and vocational training, migration and integration, energy policy, and responses to crises including the Eurozone turmoil, the 2015 refugee influx, and early stages of COVID-19. The book also outlines structural challenges—demographic change, populism, and export dependency—and situates Germany’s role within the European Union and transatlantic relations.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise & the Brain (25th Anniv.)
Summary Abstract: Spark surveys scientific evidence that aerobic exercise induces structural and functional changes in the brain, enhancing learning, memory, mood, and stress regulation. Ratey synthesizes research on exercise as prevention and adjunct treatment for conditions including depression, ADHD, addiction, menopause, and Alzheimer’s. Case studies—such as the Naperville, Illinois school district’s fitness program associated with top science test performance—illustrate real-world academic and cognitive outcomes.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Traveller is a 2011 studio album by sitarist Anoushka Shankar, released by Deutsche Grammophon. Conceived as a musical journey linking Indian classical music and Spanish flamenco, it explores the historical route of Romani migration from the Indian subcontinent to Andalusia through original compositions and traditional forms. Produced by Javier Limón, it integrates sitar and Indian percussion with flamenco guitar, palmas, and vocals.

Summary Abstract: The Analects is a collection of sayings and conversations of Confucius and his disciples, compiled in the centuries after his death. Organized into twenty books, it addresses ethical cultivation and social order through concepts such as ren (humaneness), li (ritual propriety), yi (righteousness), xiao (filial piety), and the ideal of the junzi (exemplary person). The text outlines principles of personal conduct, education, and governance by moral example, including the rectification of names and rule through virtue rather than punishment.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism"

Summary Abstract: Running with Scissors is Augusten Burroughs’s 2002 memoir recounting his adolescence after his parents’ separation, when his mother places him in the care of her psychiatrist, Dr. Finch. Living in the psychiatrist’s household among family members and patients, he experiences little formal schooling and begins a relationship with an older patient, Neil Bookman. The narrative follows his efforts to support himself and ultimately leave the household to live independently.

Summary Abstract:
Psychology in Seattle is a podcast and YouTube channel hosted by Dr. Kirk Honda, PsyD, LMFT, that provides educational content on psychology, psychotherapy, and culture.
Launched in 2008, it publishes frequent episodes on topics ranging from psychological theory to analyses of popular culture; in 2019 it operated across both audio and video platforms.

Summary Abstract: Posthumously published in 1796 and edited by John, Lord Sheffield, Edward Gibbon’s Memoirs of My Life recounts his childhood, education, brief residence at Oxford, conversion to Roman Catholicism and subsequent reversion to Protestantism, and his years in Lausanne. Gibbon narrates his service in the Hampshire militia, European travels (including the 1764 visit to Rome that prompted the plan for The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire), and his career as a historian, Member of Parliament, and Commissioner of the Board of Trade. The work outlines the conception, research, and composition of Decline and Fall and concludes with his later life and return to Lausanne.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: Bandura advances a social learning account of aggression, arguing that aggressive patterns are chiefly acquired through observational learning (modeling) and maintained by reinforcement, outcome expectancies, and self-regulatory processes. He analyzes conditions that instigate, disinhibit, and regulate aggression—including family, peer, and mass media models, cueing, arousal, and reward contingencies—drawing on laboratory and field evidence such as modeling experiments. The work also delineates methods for reducing aggression by altering reinforcement structures, changing available models and cues, and training nonaggressive alternative responses.

Duino Elegies is a cycle of ten German-language elegies by Rainer Maria Rilke, begun in 1912 at Duino Castle and completed in 1922. The poems address angelic figures and other archetypes to examine human existence—mortality, love, suffering, alienation, and the transience of beauty. They juxtapose earthly life with an unreachable angelic realm and reflect on the role of art and memory in shaping meaning from impermanence.

Intersectionality (2016) presents intersectionality as an analytic framework for understanding how multiple axes of power—such as race, gender, class, sexuality, and nation—mutually construct one another to shape social inequalities and lived experiences. It traces the concept’s intellectual genealogy in Black feminist thought, clarifies key terms and debates, and outlines methodological and political implications. The work surveys applications across disciplines and arenas including law, policy, activism, and transnational contexts, presenting intersectionality as both theory and praxis.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Illusions II: The Adventures of a Reluctant Student (2014) is Richard Bach’s sequel to Illusions (1977), narrated in his own voice. It recounts his near-fatal August 2012 plane crash and months of hospitalization, during which he interacts with the “imaginary” characters from his earlier work and draws on them for inspiration in his recovery.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Michael Pollan traces the history and science of psychedelics and the recent renaissance in research on substances such as LSD and psilocybin. He covers the mid-century rise and 1960s backlash that curtailed studies, then details contemporary clinical work on treating depression, addiction, anxiety, and end-of-life distress. The book discusses proposed neural mechanisms, including effects on the brain’s default mode network and experiences of ego dissolution, and incorporates the author’s accounts of supervised sessions.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Underground: The Tokyo Gas Attack and the Japanese Psyche
Summary Abstract: Haruki Murakami’s nonfiction work presents an oral history of the 1995 Tokyo subway sarin attack by Aum Shinrikyō through interviews with survivors, families, and subway workers, reconstructing the events and their human impact. The testimonies detail symptoms, medical and logistical responses, and lasting effects on everyday lives. A subsequent set of interviews with current and former Aum members records the group’s beliefs and members’ motivations, placing the attacks in a broader social and psychological context in Japan.

It assembles short, self-contained verses that illustrate the range of topics and aesthetic moods in the subhashita tradition of classical Sanskrit literature.

Title of Work: I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life
Summary Abstract: Ed Yong examines the microbial communities that inhabit humans and other animals, detailing how symbiotic bacteria, archaea, viruses, and fungi shape development, immunity, digestion, and behavior. Using case studies across species, the book explains ecological principles that govern microbiome assembly and stability, and how disturbances from antibiotics, diet, or sanitation can alter these systems. It also outlines emerging methods to study and deliberately modify microbiomes for applications in medicine, agriculture, and conservation.

Summary Abstract: The Book of Embraces (1989) is a collection of very short texts by Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano that blends parable, anecdote, dream, and autobiographical fragments into a mosaic form. Its vignettes draw on Latin American histories and everyday life to address memory, love, political repression, exile, and freedom. Among its sequences are passages confronting death and mortality, and the work was first published in Spanish as El libro de los abrazos in 1989.

Title of Work: The Fundamental Wisdom of the Middle Way
Summary Abstract: The Fundamental Wisdom of the Middle Way (Mūlamadhyamakakārikā), composed by Nāgārjuna circa 150 CE, presents Madhyamaka by arguing that all phenomena are empty of intrinsic nature because they arise dependently. Across 27 chapters of verses using reductio arguments and the tetralemma, it critically examines causation, motion, the aggregates, sense faculties, time, the self, and nirvāṇa. It articulates the two truths—conventional and ultimate—and defines emptiness as the Middle Way that avoids the extremes of eternalism and nihilism.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Title of Work: The Politics of Trauma: Somatics, Healing, and Social Justice
Summary Abstract: This book examines trauma as both an individual and collective phenomenon, linking its origins and impacts to systems of oppression, violence, and inequity. Drawing on somatic theory and practice, Haines explains the neurobiological and embodied patterns of trauma, including historical and intergenerational transmission, and how they shape behavior, relationships, and institutions. She offers frameworks and practices for building safety, resilience, and accountability in individuals, organizations, and social movements to support healing and sustainable social change.

Summary Abstract: Psychology (1986) by David G. Myers is an introductory textbook that surveys the scientific study of behavior and mental processes. It covers core topics including research methods, biological bases of behavior, sensation and perception, learning, memory, cognition, intelligence, development, motivation and emotion, stress and health, personality, psychological disorders and their treatment, and social psychology. The work presents major theories, classic and contemporary findings, and applications of psychology across these domains.

Summary Abstract: Louis Creed, a physician, moves with his family to rural Maine, where a neighbor shows them a local pet cemetery and a hidden burial ground beyond that can resurrect the dead. After the family cat is killed and returns changed, a later family tragedy compels Louis to use the burial ground again. The resurrected do not come back the same, leading to catastrophic consequences.

Title of Work: The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas
Summary Abstract: During World War II, nine-year-old Bruno moves with his family to a house beside a Nazi concentration camp when his father becomes its commandant. He befriends Shmuel, a Jewish boy imprisoned on the other side of the fence, and meets him in secret. Attempting to help Shmuel find his missing father, Bruno crawls under the fence in camp clothing; the boys are swept into a roundup and die together in a gas chamber.

States of Dependency examines how U.S. welfare programs, particularly Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC), developed from 1935 to 1972 and how recipients, administrators, and lawyers reframed public assistance as a site of legal rights. Using administrative and legal history, Karen Tani traces federal–state conflicts over welfare administration and the emergence of procedural protections for beneficiaries, including in cases such as Goldberg v. Kelly. The book argues that welfare rights claims and administrative practices reshaped American governance by redefining obligations among the federal government, states, and citizens.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Norman Vincent Peale’s The Power of Positive Thinking (1952) presents a step-by-step program for cultivating confidence and overcoming difficulties through a positive mental attitude grounded in Christian faith. It outlines techniques such as prayer, scripture-based affirmations, visualization, and autosuggestion to address worry, fear, and self-doubt and to pursue personal and professional goals. The guidance is conveyed through formulas, anecdotes, and case histories drawn from Peale’s pastoral counseling.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Buddha’s Brain: The Practical Neuroscience of Happiness, Love, and Wisdom
Summary Abstract: Buddha’s Brain synthesizes neuroscience and psychology with Buddhist contemplative practices to explain how mental training can alter neural structure and function through neuroplasticity. It outlines the brain’s threat, reward, and attachment systems, the negativity bias, and the roles of regions such as the prefrontal cortex, amygdala, and insula in emotion, attention, and regulation. The book provides practical exercises—mindfulness, relaxation, compassion/loving-kindness, and “taking in the good”—to convert beneficial states into lasting traits that support calm, resilience, empathy, and wisdom.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Senchaku Hongan Nembutsu Shu (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow) is Hōnen’s principal doctrinal treatise, composed in 1198, that sets forth exclusive recitation of Amitābha’s name (nembutsu) as the practice specially selected by Amida’s Primal Vow for certain rebirth in the Pure Land, particularly in the degenerate age of the Dharma (mappō). Hōnen compiles and interprets passages from the three Pure Land sutras and Chinese Pure Land masters such as Shandao, Tanluan, and Daochuo to argue for reliance on Amida’s other-power over self-power practices.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Japanese / Korean – Shinto, Zen, Neo-Confucian Korean lineages","Sinic – Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism","Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: De Sutter examines a contemporary “age of anesthesia” in which emotions are regulated and pacified via the ubiquitous use of psychotropic substances—antidepressants, sleeping pills, stimulants—so that everyday life resembles a pharmacy. He links the rise of anesthesia to industrial capitalism and argues that sedation domesticates excitation, especially its political potential, aligning subjects with systemic demands. Framing pharmacological affect-management as a core technology of capitalism, the book analyzes how this governance of feelings produces compliant social behavior.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: A Promised Land (2020) is the first volume of Barack Obama’s presidential memoirs, covering his early political rise, the 2008 campaign, and the initial years of his presidency. It recounts major decisions on the financial crisis response, the auto industry rescue, passage of the Affordable Care Act, and foreign-policy challenges including Afghanistan and the Middle East. The volume concludes with the 2011 operation that killed Osama bin Laden.

Title of Work: The Real North Korea: Complex Systems of Control and Survival
Summary Abstract: Andrei Lankov analyzes North Korea’s historical and institutional development, detailing mechanisms of control such as songbun social classification, surveillance, propaganda, and coercion, and how the 1990s famine spurred marketization that reshaped daily life and state-society relations. He examines the regime’s survival strategies—including limited tolerance of markets, border and information control, illicit revenue generation, and nuclear and missile programs—as rational tools for deterrence and resource extraction. The book also surveys relations with South Korea, the United States, and China, and outlines possible future scenarios alongside the constraints facing external policy approaches.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Laugh Now Series (2002) by Banksy depicts monkeys wearing sandwich-board signs that read “Laugh now, but one day we’ll be in charge.” The motif originated as a 2002 commission for a Brighton nightclub and has been produced as stenciled paintings and limited-edition screenprints.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: I could not locate verifiable information about a 2020 work titled “Par laimi” by Ilmārs Šlāpins. Without reliable details on its publication and content, I cannot produce a factual abstract.

Set in the near future, the novel follows engineer Vannevar Morgan’s attempt to build a space elevator on the equatorial island of Taprobane, tethering a mountain summit to geostationary orbit with ultralight filaments. He faces scientific, political, and religious opposition, notably from a centuries-old monastery occupying the ideal anchor point, as well as the hazards of planetary-scale engineering. Interleaving episodes from the island’s ancient past with the modern project, the story traces the societal and technological consequences of opening routine access between Earth and space.
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Europe – Western,Global / Transcultural

Title of Work: My Transition Hours: A Memoir of Leadership and Democracy
Summary Abstract: A political memoir by former Nigerian president Goodluck Jonathan, the book traces his rise from Bayelsa State politics to the presidency and reflects on his administration from 2010 to 2015. It covers governance challenges such as economic management, electoral reform, and the Boko Haram insurgency, and recounts the 2015 election. Central to the narrative is his decision to concede defeat to Muhammadu Buhari and oversee Nigeria’s first peaceful transfer of power between rival political parties.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Integral Psychology (2000) presents Ken Wilber’s integral (AQAL) framework as a model of human psychological development that synthesizes numerous Western and Eastern theories. It delineates stages (prepersonal, personal, transpersonal), multiple developmental lines, states of consciousness, and types within four quadrants (individual/collective × interior/exterior), and connects these constructs to psychopathology and psychotherapy. The book includes comparative charts that map a spectrum of consciousness for research and clinical application.

Title of Work: Hebrews to Negroes: Wake Up Black America
Summary Abstract: Ronald Dalton Jr.’s 2015 book argues that African Americans are descendants of the ancient Israelites and that this history has been obscured. It combines biblical interpretation, historical narratives, linguistics, and genetics to present an alternative account of Black identity, the African diaspora, and the transatlantic slave trade. The work critiques mainstream religious and historical scholarship and advances claims about the identity of contemporary Jews and the transmission of historical knowledge.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","African Diasporic – Vodun, Santería, Candomblé, Rastafari"

Title of Work: The Practice and Theory of Individual Psychology
Summary Abstract: Adler presents the principles and methods of Individual Psychology, explaining behavior as goal-directed compensation for feelings of inferiority and oriented by social interest. He details how early childhood experiences, family constellation and birth order shape a person’s style of life, discusses organ inferiority and safeguarding tendencies, and interprets neurosis and symptoms as mistaken solutions to life tasks. The book outlines clinical techniques—including analysis of early recollections, dreams, and private logic, and the use of encouragement—and applies the approach to education, prevention, and community life.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The Lucifer Effect (2007) by psychologist Philip Zimbardo examines how situational and systemic forces can lead ordinary people to commit harmful acts. Centered on a detailed account of the Stanford Prison Experiment, it analyzes mechanisms such as deindividuation, conformity, obedience to authority, diffusion of responsibility, and dehumanization. The book connects these dynamics to real-world cases like the abuses at Abu Ghraib and outlines strategies for recognizing and resisting destructive social pressures.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: Survival in Auschwitz (originally If This Is a Man) is Primo Levi’s 1947 memoir of his arrest in 1943, deportation from Italy via the Fossoli transit camp, and imprisonment in the Auschwitz-Monowitz labor camp. Covering roughly February 1944 to January 1945, Levi describes selection, forced labor, starvation, barter and prisoner hierarchies, and his later assignment to a Buna chemical laboratory that improved his chances of survival. The book concludes with the “Ten Days” between the camp’s evacuation and liberation by the Red Army.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The Warmth of Other Suns is a nonfiction history of the Great Migration, the movement of approximately six million African Americans from the U.S. South to the North and West between about 1915 and 1970. Drawing on interviews and archival research, Isabel Wilkerson examines the forces driving the migration, including Jim Crow segregation, racial violence, and economic opportunity. The narrative follows three migrants—Ida Mae Brandon Gladney (Mississippi to Chicago, 1937), George Swanson Starling (Florida to New York, 1945), and Robert Joseph Pershing Foster (Louisiana to Los Angeles, 1953)—as case studies of this broader transformation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Lost City of Z: A Tale of Deadly Obsession in the Amazon
Summary Abstract: David Grann chronicles British explorer Percy Fawcett’s early 20th-century expeditions into the Amazon and his 1925 disappearance while seeking a fabled ancient city he called “Z.” Drawing on archival sources and his own field reporting, Grann reconstructs Fawcett’s quest and the many subsequent searches for him. The book also examines modern archaeological findings—such as terra preta and geoglyphs—suggesting that complex pre-Columbian societies existed in parts of the Amazon.

Summary Abstract: This work presents traditional Haitian Vodou Rada songs associated with the yanvalou dance, performed by unidentified ritual singers as part of ceremonies to invoke and honor the lwa. It features call-and-response vocals in Haitian Creole accompanied by the Rada drum ensemble (manman, bula, seconde), ogan bell, asson rattle, and other ritual percussion used in spirit-possession rites.

Title of Work: A Thousand Years of Nonlinear History
Summary Abstract: Manuel DeLanda’s A Thousand Years of Nonlinear History (1997) reframes the last millennium as interacting self-organizing processes using concepts from nonlinear dynamics, complexity science, and assemblage theory. It structures the account into three strata—geological/material (energy, metallurgy, extraction), biological (populations, disease, agriculture), and linguistic/semantic (cities, markets, states, codes)—to trace how material and information flows couple across scales. Employing ideas like bifurcations, path dependence, and emergence, the book analyzes long-term transformations in urbanization, warfare, and economic networks from roughly 1000 to 2000 CE.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: The Return: Fathers, Sons and the Land in Between
Summary Abstract: A memoir, The Return follows Hisham Matar’s journey back to Libya after the 2011 uprising to seek answers about his father, Jaballa Matar, a dissident abducted in Cairo in 1990 and believed to have been imprisoned by Muammar Gaddafi’s regime, possibly at Abu Salim. Interweaving personal and political history, Matar meets relatives, former prisoners, and officials, and consults letters and records concerning disappearances and the 1996 Abu Salim massacre. The book documents his family’s decades-long search and the persistent uncertainty surrounding his father’s fate.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Tales of Belkin and Other Prose Writings
Summary Abstract: First published in 1831, this volume presents The Tales of the Late Ivan Petrovich Belkin, five short stories framed as the posthumous manuscripts of a provincial landowner edited for publication. The stories—The Shot, The Blizzard, The Undertaker, The Stationmaster, and The Squire’s Daughter—follow soldiers, merchants, officials, and gentry through duels, misdirected courtships, travel, and family conflict in early 19th-century Russia. The collection also includes additional short prose pieces by Pushkin.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Selected Verse presents a chronological selection of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s poems spanning more than sixty years, from his early Sturm und Drang period to his classical and later work. It includes pieces such as Prometheus, To the Moon, the Roman Elegies, The Diary, and selections from Faust, tracing themes of love, nature, classical antiquity, and the search for truth.

Title of Work: La Biología del Amor: Corporalidad y Emocionalidad
Summary Abstract: Maturana develops the biology of love as a biological-relational framework in which love—accepting the other as a legitimate other—grounds human coexistence. He analyzes how embodiment (corporalidad) and emotionality configure domains of action, so that shifts in emotion transform behavior, cognition, and the consensual coordination of actions that constitutes language. The work derives implications for education and social life, emphasizing coexistence based on acceptance and mutual respect.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Discourses of the Vanishing: Modernity, Phantasm, Japan
Summary Abstract: Marilyn Ivy analyzes how modern Japanese culture is organized around discourses of disappearance, in which “tradition” is staged as vanishing yet continually reproduced. Drawing on critical theory, ethnography, and cultural analysis, she traces how folklore studies, mass media, heritage tourism, and state cultural projects generate phantasmal images that mediate modernity and national identity. The book argues that these formations manage feelings of loss and nostalgia while shaping postwar subjectivity and imaginaries of the nation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Multiculturalism and the Politics of Recognition
Summary Abstract: Charles Taylor’s Multiculturalism and “The Politics of Recognition” (1992), edited by Amy Gutmann, analyzes how modern identity is shaped by social recognition and distinguishes between a politics of equal dignity and a politics of difference. Taylor argues for accommodating cultural minorities and some group-differentiated rights within a liberal framework, using examples such as Quebec and Indigenous peoples. The volume includes critical essays by K. Anthony Appiah, Jürgen Habermas, Steven C. Rockefeller, Michael Walzer, and Susan Wolf, followed by Taylor’s reply.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: The Case for the Green New Deal
Summary Abstract: Ann Pettifor outlines an economic program for a Green New Deal to decarbonize the economy while ensuring full employment and a just transition. She advocates re-regulating finance, managing capital flows, and using public and central-bank-backed credit to fund large-scale investment in renewable energy, efficiency, and green infrastructure. Drawing on precedents such as the New Deal and Bretton Woods, the book details policy mechanisms to subordinate finance to democratic goals and ecological limits.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: In the third Legendborn Cycle novel, Bree Matthews exiles herself from the Order and severs her ancestral ties, binding herself by an unbreakable bargain to the shapeshifting Shadow King in exchange for training to wield her unprecedented powers. As the Round Table fractures—its Kingsmage missing and the Scions facing war—Nick invokes an ancient law to force an audience with the Regents while a string of kidnappings and Merlin deaths escalates. Bree must navigate the Shadow King’s demands and the Order’s internal conflicts as the past continues to pursue her.

Title of Work: The Hidden Roots of White Supremacy
Summary Abstract: Robert P. Jones traces the roots of American white supremacy to the 15th‑century Christian Doctrine of Discovery, showing how it sanctioned Indigenous dispossession, African enslavement, and later legal and cultural frameworks including white Christian nationalism. Through case studies in Tallahatchie County, Mississippi (Emmett Till), Duluth, Minnesota (1920 lynchings), and Tulsa, Oklahoma (1921 race massacre), he links these atrocities to earlier colonial violence and its enduring legacy. The book also examines contemporary local efforts focused on truth‑telling, commemoration, and repair as steps toward a more pluralistic democracy.

Charlotte Lennox’s The Female Quixote (1752) follows Arabella, a marquis’s daughter raised in seclusion on French heroic romances. Filtering everyday events through those plots, she misreads social encounters as abductions and conspiracies, complicating courtship and family relations. After an illness and admonition from a learned clergyman, she acknowledges her errors and accepts marriage to her cousin-suitor.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: A tragedy set in Venice and Cyprus, Othello follows a Moorish general who secretly marries Desdemona. His resentful ensign Iago deceives him into believing she is unfaithful with Lieutenant Cassio, notably by planting her handkerchief as false proof. Consumed by jealousy, Othello murders Desdemona; once the plot is revealed, he kills himself and Iago is apprehended.

Title of Work: The Art of Sexual Ecstasy: The Path of Sacred Sexuality for Western Lovers
Summary Abstract: This book introduces Tantric principles adapted for Western lovers and outlines a step-by-step path that unites sexuality and spirituality. It provides structured practices—such as breathwork, meditation, communication exercises, movement, and ritual—for individuals and couples to cultivate awareness, intimacy, and the conscious circulation of sexual energy. It addresses resolving sexual blocks and presents exercises, visualizations, and guided techniques to frame lovemaking as a spiritual practice.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Summary Abstract: Studio Olafur Eliasson: An Encyclopedia presents the Berlin-based Studio Olafur Eliasson as an interdisciplinary laboratory led by the artist, offering an encyclopedic overview of his practice. Organized by alphabetized key concepts and short conversations with Eliasson, it documents the majority of his installations, photographs, sculptures, and architectural projects, and details the studio’s research processes. The volume includes an introduction by art historian Philip Ursprung and was published by TASCHEN, with a limited Art Edition featuring a custom cover by Eliasson.

Summary Abstract: Verbrechen (Crime) is a 2009 collection of short stories by criminal defense lawyer Ferdinand von Schirach that fictionalizes real criminal cases from his practice. The stories reconstruct individual crimes, the investigations and trials, and the backgrounds of defendants within the framework of German criminal law. They cover a range of offenses and document the factual circumstances, procedural steps, and judicial outcomes.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Eric Foner examines how the Civil War and Reconstruction transformed the U.S. Constitution through the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments, detailing their drafting, ratification, and intended scope for freedom, citizenship, and voting rights. He analyzes the political struggles and legal interpretations that first expanded and then curtailed these amendments’ reach, including Supreme Court decisions and the rise of Jim Crow. The work traces their later revival during the civil rights era and explains their continuing significance for contemporary debates over equality and democracy.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Owning Our Future: The Emerging Ownership Revolution
Summary Abstract: This book examines how ownership design shapes economic behavior, contrasting “extractive” models focused on financial gain with “generative” ownership that embeds social and ecological purpose. Drawing on case studies of cooperatives, employee-owned firms, community trusts, and mission-controlled companies, it maps an emerging shift in enterprise structures. Kelly identifies common design elements—purpose, membership, governance, capital, and networks—that enable resilient, community-rooted organizations.

Summary Abstract: Aspiring writer Alice Scott and Pulitzer-winning journalist Hayden Anderson travel to Little Crescent Island to compete to write the biography of reclusive heiress Margaret Ives—or the octogenarian who claims to be her. Over a one-month trial, Margaret gives each of them different, non-shareable fragments of her past under strict NDAs, forcing separate investigations even as a mutual attraction develops. Their rivalry and relationship unfold alongside Margaret’s partial revelations, with the story’s shape—mystery, tragedy, or love—depending on who tells it.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Set in early-1970s Harlem, the novel is narrated by 19-year-old Tish Rivers, whose fiancé Alonzo “Fonny” Hunt is falsely accused of rape and jailed after a hostile encounter with a police officer. Pregnant with their child, Tish and both families work to prove Fonny’s innocence, including her mother’s trip to Puerto Rico to plead with the accuser. Told in alternating past and present, the story traces their love and legal struggle, ending with Tish’s baby born while Fonny remains in prison.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Reclaiming the Commons: Biodiversity, Traditional Knowledge, and the Rights of Mother Earth
Summary Abstract: Vandana Shiva analyzes how corporate-led globalization extended patents and intellectual property into biodiversity and traditional knowledge, enclosing biological and intellectual commons and shifting resources from poorer communities to wealthier corporations. Drawing on three decades of scientific, legal, political, and cultural action, she documents resistance to biopiracy and seed monopolies and their impacts on communities and ecosystems. The book advances recovery of the commons and recognition of the rights of Mother Earth as a framework for biodiversity sovereignty and ecological democracy.

Summary Abstract: The Minds of Billy Milligan (1981) is Daniel Keyes’s nonfiction account of Billy Milligan, the first person in U.S. history found not guilty by reason of insanity for major felonies on the basis of multiple personality disorder. Using interviews, records, and court documents, it recounts Milligan’s abusive childhood, the 1977 rapes on and near the Ohio State University campus, his arrest and trial, and the identification of 24 distinct personalities, including Ragen, Arthur, and Adalana. The book follows his commitment to Ohio state hospitals, psychiatric treatment aimed at integrating his identities, and ongoing court oversight of his confinement and care.

Fatelessness is a 1975 semi-autobiographical novel by Imre Kertész about 14-year-old Hungarian Jew György Köves, who is detained in Budapest and deported to Auschwitz. He is later transferred to Buchenwald and the Zeitz subcamp, enduring forced labor and illness until liberation. The novel concludes with his return to Budapest following the end of the war.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: To Throw Away Unopened (2018) is Viv Albertine’s follow-up memoir, dissecting her family history and an obsession with truth, and exploring power, identity, and the damage wrought by secrecy and dysfunction among parents and siblings. It examines the limits of intimacy and the process of rebuilding after revelations. The book was shortlisted for the 2018 Costa Book of the Year Awards.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: A monumental sculptural program at the Bayon temple in Angkor Thom, Cambodia, commissioned by King Jayavarman VII in the late 12th–early 13th century. Court sculptors carved approximately 216 serene sandstone faces crowning 54 towers, typically oriented to the cardinal directions. The faces are commonly identified as the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara (Lokesvara) or as a deified image of Jayavarman VII, embodying the Khmer Empire’s Mahayana Buddhist state ideology.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Title of Work: The Unheard Cry for Meaning: Psychotherapy and Humanism
Summary Abstract: Viktor E. Frankl articulates logotherapy as a meaning-centered psychotherapy, positing the will to meaning as the primary human motivation and identifying the “existential vacuum” and noogenic neuroses as key sources of modern distress. He contrasts this with reductionist psychoanalysis and behaviorism, and presents techniques such as dereflection and paradoxical intention to help patients discover meaning through creative work, love, and the attitude toward unavoidable suffering. The work frames psychotherapy within a humanistic-ethical context that emphasizes freedom, responsibility, conscience, and self-transcendence. Published in 1978, it synthesizes clinical case material with philosophical and cultural analysis.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"
Primary Subdomain(s): Psychotherapy & Counseling Modalities,Positive Psychology & Human Potential

Summary Abstract: The Sumerian poem recounts the goddess Inanna’s descent to the netherworld, where she passes through seven gates, is stripped of her regalia, and is judged and killed by her sister Ereshkigal. The god Enki creates beings who revive Inanna with the food and water of life, but she must provide a substitute to leave the underworld. She designates her consort Dumuzi, and an arrangement is made in which Dumuzi and his sister Geshtinanna alternate periods in the underworld.

Title of Work: Pensar la Conciencia: Hacia un nuevo sistema operativo
Summary Abstract: Este ensayo de 2023 formula hipótesis especulativas sobre el origen de la consciencia y las relaciona con hitos evolutivos que habrían dotado a los humanos de la capacidad de autopercibirse y reflexionar sobre sí mismos.Examina si la consciencia podría construirse a partir de unidades básicas, si tiene ciclo de vida y si está integrada en el universo.Culmina proponiendo una doctrina filosófica que se presenta como un “sistema operativo” para orientar la vida.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Ivan Illich’s Deschooling Society (1971) critiques compulsory, institutionalized schooling as a system that standardizes knowledge, enforces social control, and reproduces inequality through a hidden curriculum. He calls for “deschooling” by disestablishing school’s monopoly over education and creating decentralized “learning webs” that connect learners with resources, peers, and mentors. The book outlines four networks—reference services to educational resources, skill exchanges, peer-matching, and directories of professional educators—to support self-directed learning across society.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
