Title of Work: The Secret of Success — William Walker Atkinson (1908, Chicago)
Summary Abstract: First published in Chicago in 1908, The Secret of Success presents a nine‑lesson course on applying the individual's latent powers to attain success in life. It stresses awakening and expressing the “I” (individuality) through spiritedness, will‑power, enthusiasm (“soul‑force”), and desire, using techniques such as visualization, attention, and mental imagery. Topics include the Law of Attraction, Personal Magnetism, cultivating an attractive personality and self‑control, and overcoming “Fearthought” to direct desire and will toward constructive ends.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Henry James’s The Ambassadors (1903) follows Lambert Strether of Woollett, Massachusetts, who is sent to Paris by Mrs. Newsome to persuade her son Chad to return to the family business. In Paris, Strether meets Maria Gostrey and learns of Chad’s intimate relationship with Madame de Vionnet, complicating his mission and delaying Chad’s return. After further pressure from additional emissaries, including Chad’s sister Sarah Pocock, Strether rejects Mrs. Newsome’s demands and chooses to return to America alone, while Chad’s ultimate decision remains uncertain.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Sahara (2002) is Michael Palin’s travelogue of a journey that broadly circumnavigates the Sahara Desert. He follows a loop across North and West Africa, traveling through countries that border the desert and documenting geography, history, and daily life in both urban centers and remote oases. The work recounts desert crossings and encounters with local communities, including nomadic groups and salt traders.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The novel follows Ilya Ilyich Oblomov, a St. Petersburg nobleman who lives in chronic inactivity, largely confined to his rooms and waited on by his servant Zakhar. Pressed by his industrious friend Andrei Stolz, a courtship with Olga Sergeyevna briefly stirs him to change, but he lapses back into passivity. He withdraws into a comfortable domestic life with his landlady Agafya Matveyevna Pshenitsyna, while Olga marries Stolz, and his affairs—including his country estate—deteriorate as he declines.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Cranford is an episodic novel narrated by Mary Smith about a small English town led by a circle of genteel women who observe strict social conventions. Through a series of vignettes, it depicts their daily lives and responses to economic and social change, including the coming of the railway. A central strand follows Miss Matty Jenkyns, who loses her savings in a bank failure, opens a tea business with discreet support from friends, and later is aided by the return of her long-absent brother Peter from India.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Europe – Western,"South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh"

Summary Abstract: After the Ceremonies is a collection of new and selected poems by Ama Ata Aidoo spanning three decades and addressing themes of colonialism, independence, motherhood, gender, and broader social issues. Arranged in three parts, it gathers previously uncollected poems alongside selections from An Angry Letter in January and Other Poems and Someone Talking to Sometime. The volume is edited by Helen Yitah.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Margaret the First is a 2016 novel by Danielle Dutton that fictionalizes the life of Margaret Cavendish (1623–1673), the English duchess, writer, and natural philosopher. It follows her youth during the English Civil War, exile with the Royalist court in France, marriage to William Cavendish, and return to Restoration England, highlighting her prolific publications—including plays, poetry, philosophical writings, and The Blazing World—and the notoriety that earned her the nickname “Mad Madge.” The book traces Cavendish’s pursuit of authorship and scientific inquiry within the constraints of seventeenth-century society.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Author Full Name: Guillaume de Lorris & Jean de Meun
Summary Abstract: Le Roman de la Rose is a Middle French allegorical poem begun by Guillaume de Lorris c. 1230 as a dream-vision in which a Lover seeks to obtain a rose, symbolizing his lady, aided and opposed by personifications such as Reason, Friend, and Danger. Several decades later Jean de Meun continued and greatly expanded the work, adding extensive debates and digressions on love, philosophy, nature, and social institutions. Together the two parts trace the lover’s quest from a courtly love manual toward a broader, didactic and encyclopedic treatment of human desire and society.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: Herodotus’ Histories investigates the causes and course of the Greco-Persian Wars, tracing the rise of the Persian Empire from Croesus and Cyrus through Cambyses and Darius to Xerxes’ invasions of Greece. It interweaves accounts of major battles—Marathon, Thermopylae, Salamis, Plataea, and Mycale—with extensive ethnographic and geographic descriptions of peoples such as the Egyptians, Scythians, and Lydians. The work states its purpose as preserving the memory of human deeds and explaining the origins of conflict between Greeks and non-Greeks.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Greco-Roman / Classical Western – Hellenic philosophy, Roman law, Stoicism, Epicureanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Europe – Southern,Middle East – Anatolia,Middle East – Mesopotamia,Middle East – Levant,Africa – North

Summary Abstract: Hunger (1890) by Knut Hamsun follows an unnamed aspiring writer in Kristiania (now Oslo) as he endures extreme poverty and starvation while attempting to sell his work and preserve his dignity. His physical decline is accompanied by erratic behavior and hallucinations, including encounters with editors, strangers, and a woman he calls Ylajali. After repeated failures to secure sustenance or employment, he signs on as a sailor and leaves the city.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: Social Works: Performing Art, Supporting Publics
Summary Abstract: Social Works analyzes socially engaged art across performance and visual art, focusing on how aesthetic aims are intertwined with the social, institutional, and logistical supports that enable such projects. Through case studies including Mierle Laderman Ukeles, The Builders Association and Rimini Protokoll, Elmgreen & Dragset, and Paul Chan, it maps debates around labor, welfare, publics, and the “social turn” in contemporary art. Bridging visual and performance studies, the book develops a framework for understanding the forms, goals, and histories of social practice.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"
Other Primary Domains: "Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy","Society, Politics, Law & Economics"

Summary Abstract: Jonathan Franzen’s The Corrections (2001) follows the Midwestern Lambert family—aging parents Enid and Alfred and their adult children Gary, Chip, and Denise—through the late 1990s as each faces personal and professional turmoil. As Alfred’s Parkinson’s-related decline worsens, Enid strives to gather everyone in their St. Jude home for a final Christmas. The narrative traces Gary’s strained marriage in Philadelphia, Chip’s fall from academia and entanglement in a Lithuanian financial scheme, and Denise’s restaurant career and complex relationships, culminating in the family’s attempted reunion.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Fairy Tales for Workers’ Children is an English-language collection of four socialist fairy tales by Austrian writer Hermynia Zur Mühlen, published in Chicago by the Daily Worker Publishing Company in 1925. Aimed at educating working-class children, the tales use anthropomorphism and simple allegorical narratives to explain exploitation under capitalism, critique religious and ideological justifications for inequality, and promote solidarity and collective action. Several stories cast children as catalysts for awareness and resistance, envisioning a future of social justice and workers’ emancipation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: The Magic Faraway Tree (1943) is a children's fantasy novel by Enid Blyton in which siblings Jo, Bessie, and Fanny introduce their visiting cousin Dick to the Enchanted Wood and the Magic Faraway Tree, whose summit leads to a succession of ever-changing magical lands. With the help of inhabitants such as Moon-Face, Silky the fairy, and the Saucepan Man, they embark on episodic adventures and narrow escapes as the lands move on and off the treetop. The book continues the Faraway Tree series begun with The Enchanted Wood.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Celtic / Northern European / Slavic – Druidic, Norse, Germanic paganism, Slavic folk traditions","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Fundamentals presents ten core ideas that frame modern understanding of physical reality, spanning quantum mechanics, particle physics, and cosmology. It describes how symmetries, conservation laws, and fields structure matter and forces, and how simple laws across vast space and time yield complexity. The book situates humanity within cosmic evolution, connecting fundamental constants, the history of the universe, and the emergence of life and mind.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work: For Discrimination: Race, Affirmative Action, and the Law
Summary Abstract: Randall Kennedy’s For Discrimination: Race, Affirmative Action, and the Law examines the history, legal foundations, and contemporary controversies surrounding affirmative action in the United States, clarifying what the policy entails and why it is both championed and denounced. The book addresses core questions about benefits and costs, stigma, eligibility criteria, and whether and when affirmative action should end, offering a concise, personal defense of race-conscious affirmative action while engaging opposing arguments.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: This book surveys the sensory systems of animals to show how each species experiences a distinct umwelt, spanning vision, smell, touch, taste, hearing, echolocation, electroreception, and magnetoreception. Drawing on research and case studies—from insects tracking polarized light to fish detecting electric fields and birds navigating by Earth’s magnetism—it explains how senses shape behavior, communication, and ecology. It also examines how human activities such as light and noise pollution alter these sensory landscapes and outlines methods scientists use to probe nonhuman perception.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Lost & Found is a memoir by Kathryn Schulz that juxtaposes the death of her father with the beginning of a profound romantic relationship, examining how loss and discovery shape a life. Organized into three sections—“Lost,” “Found,” and “And”—it blends personal narrative with cultural, historical, and linguistic reflections on what it means to lose and to find. The book traces the immediate aftermath of grief, the experience of falling in love, and the connections that reconcile these events.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Set in France in 2022, the novel follows François, a Sorbonne literature professor specializing in J.-K. Huysmans, as a Muslim party led by Mohammed Ben Abbes wins the presidency via a coalition of mainstream parties against the National Front. The new administration restructures public life—reconstituting the Sorbonne as an Islamic university, removing women from university posts and coeducation, and permitting polygamy—costing François his position. Courted to return on condition of converting to Islam, he travels through Paris and religious retreats and weighs conversion to regain his academic career and access the new order’s benefits.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Mass Trauma and Emotional Healing Around the World
Summary Abstract: Mass Trauma and Emotional Healing around the World is a two-volume edited collection presenting global case studies and survivor accounts of natural and human-made disasters, and the rituals and practices used to cultivate resilience and meaning-making. The volumes integrate biopsychosocial, educational, spiritual, and ecopsychological approaches, illustrating methods such as storytelling, music, humor, mindfulness, forgiveness, and community rituals across contexts including earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, colonization, genocide, terrorism, forced migration, and HIV/AIDS.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Title of Work: Let Us Believe in the Beginning of the Cold Season
Summary Abstract: Forugh Farrokhzad’s 1965 poem depicts the onset of a literal and metaphorical cold season as a turning point toward isolation, loss, and the end of intimacy. Through images of barrenness, fading light, and shuttered spaces, the speaker tracks the passage of time and the erosion of warmth, speech, and connection. Personal grief is set within a broader social and existential chill, acknowledging the approach of silence and mortality as an inevitable season.

Summary Abstract: Maybe I'm Amazed: A Story of Love and Connection in Ten Songs (2025) is a memoir by John Harris about how he and his autistic son connect through music, with chapters built around specific songs. Structured across ten tracks, it tells their family story through the music they share. It was published by John Murray in March 2025.

Title of Work: Learning by Expanding: An Activity-Theoretical Approach to Developmental Research (3rd Edition)
Summary Abstract: Engeström advances Cultural-Historical Activity Theory by proposing expansive learning as a model for collective transformation, using the activity system as the primary unit of analysis. He theorizes contradictions as drivers of change, formalizes the cycle of expansive learning, and details formative intervention methods such as double stimulation and the Change Laboratory. The third edition extends empirical cases in work, education, and health care, elaborates on multi-activity networks and knotworking, and refines methodological tools for tracing long-term organizational and societal change.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: Entitled: How Male Privilege Hurts Women
Summary Abstract: Kate Manne’s Entitled examines how male privilege and entitlement shape expectations of women’s bodies, labor, attention, and authority across domains including sex, family, work, politics, and medicine. Combining philosophical analysis with empirical research and case studies, it analyzes phenomena such as mansplaining, gaslighting, sexual coercion, reproductive control, and institutional bias to show how these mechanisms harm women and sustain unequal power. The book distinguishes sexism from misogyny and offers a framework for understanding how entitlement is enforced and normalized in contemporary societies.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Americas - North,Europe – Western,"Oceania – Australia, New Zealand, Polynesia, Micronesia, Melanesia",Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: Mircea Eliade’s 1954 study surveys the historical and doctrinal development of yoga in India from Vedic and Upanishadic sources through the Bhagavad Gita, Patañjali’s classical system, and later Haṭha and Tantric traditions. It examines yoga’s soteriological aims—freedom (mokṣa/kaivalya) and “immortality” (amṛtatva)—and the techniques used to transform consciousness and end rebirth, including ascetic practices, meditation, breath control, and bodily disciplines. The work situates key concepts such as samādhi, tapas, and kuṇḍalinī within Hindu, Buddhist, and Tantric contexts and maps relationships among rāja, jñāna, bhakti, karma, and haṭha yoga.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh","Himalayan – Tibet, Bhutan, Nepal",Europe – Western,Global / Transcultural

Summary Abstract: In medieval Otranto, Manfred’s son Conrad is crushed by a gigantic helmet on his wedding day to Isabella, an event tied to a prophecy that threatens Manfred’s line. To secure his succession, Manfred seeks to divorce his wife Hippolita and marry Isabella, who flees with the help of the young man Theodore amid mounting supernatural manifestations. Theodore is revealed as the rightful heir; Manfred accidentally kills his daughter Matilda, abdicates, and Theodore marries Isabella and assumes rule of Otranto.

The Yasna Haptanghaiti (“Seven-Chapter Yasna”) is a set of seven Old Avestan hymns (Yasna 35–41) embedded in the Zoroastrian Yasna liturgy and closely related in language to the Gathas. Recited during the central worship service, it praises Ahura Mazda and the Amesha Spentas, affirms asha (truth/cosmic order), and blesses the community, earth, waters, and fire. It belongs to the oldest stratum of the Avesta and is traditionally linked to Zoroaster’s teaching, though direct authorship is uncertain.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Persian / Zoroastrian – Zoroastrianism, Mazdean traditions"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: Middle East – Gulf,"Central Asia – Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, etc.","South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Middle East – Mesopotamia

Summary Abstract: A Marxist analysis of U.S. political economy, the work traces how slavery, Reconstruction, Jim Crow, and late-20th-century deindustrialization embedded racialized exploitation that systematically underdeveloped Black communities. It examines labor markets, housing, education, welfare policy, and criminal justice to show how segregation, capital flight, and state policy produced chronic unemployment, poverty, and urban marginalization. The book critiques the limits of liberal reforms and the Black middle class, centering the Black working class and linking Black liberation to broader socialist transformation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"
Other Primary Domains: "Culture, Language & Anthropology","Community Organizing, Civic Action & Democracy"

Summary Abstract: Peter Wohlleben’s The Power of Trees explains how ancient forests function as interconnected ecosystems and argues that protecting old-growth and allowing natural regeneration are more effective for climate and biodiversity than industrial tree-planting. He critiques modern forestry practices and plantation monocultures, detailing their ecological costs and emphasizing the value of leaving forests to recover naturally.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Set in Mecca, the novel is narrated by the Lane of Many Heads and opens with the discovery of an unidentified woman’s body in the alley, prompting an official response and inquiry into her death. As residents and authorities react, the lane’s voice interweaves past and present—history, myth, and everyday life—while recounting the intertwined stories of figures such as Mu’az (a prayer leader’s son), Yusuf (a history graduate), and others from the neighborhood.

Summary Abstract: Rachel Watson, an alcoholic divorcee, watches a couple from her commuter train and becomes involved when the woman, Megan Hipwell, disappears. Attempting to recover memories from a blackout the night Megan vanished, Rachel inserts herself into the investigation and into the lives of her ex-husband Tom and his wife Anna. It is revealed that Megan was pregnant and having an affair with Tom; when she threatened to expose him, Tom killed her, and in a final confrontation Rachel and Anna stop him, resulting in his death and the case’s resolution.

My Own Words is a collection of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s writings and speeches, prepared with Mary Hartnett and Wendy W. Williams, covering topics such as gender equality, the workings of the Supreme Court, law, and Jewish identity. Spanning from her school years through her tenure on the Court, the selections include essays, lectures, and tributes to colleagues. This Legacy Edition is a posthumous 2025 publication.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam"

Summary Abstract: Examines the political instructions attributed to Kautilya (Chanakya) that are traditionally credited with guiding Chandragupta Maurya in the formation of the Mauryan state. It summarizes core principles of statecraft—administration, revenue and economic policy, law and justice, intelligence and espionage, diplomacy, and military organization—as preserved in the Arthashastra and related traditions, and situates them in the early Mauryan historical context.

Summary Abstract: Set in Port of Spain’s Calvary Hill, Trinidad, the novel follows residents including Aldrick Prospect, who each year creates and wears a dragon masquerade for Carnival. Through the intertwined lives of Aldrick, Sylvia, calypsonian Philo, steelband figure Fisheye, matriarch Miss Cleothilda, and Pariag, it depicts their experiences of poverty and social change after independence. The narrative traces how shifting meanings of Carnival, calypso, and community shape their identities and choices.

Summary Abstract: Buy Yourself the F*cking Lilies is a hybrid memoir and self-help guide in which Tara Schuster details how she began “reparenting” herself to heal from a chaotic upbringing through structured routines and rituals. Presented in short, topic-focused chapters, it blends personal anecdotes with practical tools such as gratitude and reflection journaling, therapy, boundary setting, habit tracking, and relationship maintenance. The book includes scripts, lists, and exercises intended to help implement daily self-care and build emotional stability.

Abhinavagupta’s Locana is a Sanskrit commentary on Ānandavardhana’s Dhvanyāloka that explicates the theory of dhvani (poetic suggestion) and articulates vyanjana as a distinct mode of linguistic signification. The work systematizes types of suggestion—rasa-dhvani, alaṅkāra-dhvani, and vastu-dhvani—through close analysis of Dhvanyāloka’s verses and examples. It integrates Bharata’s rasa theory with poetics, detailing the conditions under which suggested meaning arises and the relationships among word, conventional meaning, context, and aesthetic relish, shaping subsequent Sanskrit literary theory.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"

Summary Abstract: Cloud Warriors examines how scientists, technologists, and field teams are revolutionizing weather forecasting to provide earlier, life-saving warnings as extreme events intensify with climate change. Title of Work: The Doctor and the Soul: From Psychotherapy to Logotherapy
Summary Abstract: Viktor E. Frankl’s The Doctor and the Soul systematizes logotherapy, a meaning-centered psychotherapy that posits the “will to meaning” as the primary human motivation and treats noögenic neuroses arising from existential frustration. He contrasts this approach with drive-centered psychotherapies and details methods for helping patients discover meaning through creative work, love and encounters, and the attitude taken toward unavoidable suffering. The book examines freedom, responsibility, conscience, and the spiritual (noölogical) dimension of the person, illustrated with clinical cases. First published in 1946 (German) and revised with expanded editions culminating in 1955, it frames logotherapy for clinical practice.

Summary Abstract: Cleanthes’s lost treatise On Sensation (Peri Aistheseos) is attributed to the Stoic successor of Zeno and concerned the Stoic account of perception as bodily impressions upon the ruling part of the soul, consistent with Stoic materialism and empiricism. Surviving testimonia place it among his physical/logical writings and connect it to debates on aisthesis, phantasia, and the criterion of truth within early Stoicism, though only titles and fragments of related discussions remain.

Title of Work: The Language Animal: The Full Shape of the Human Linguistic Capacity
Summary Abstract: Charles Taylor argues that human language is not merely a medium for labeling and transmitting information but is constitutive of meaning, self-understanding, and social worlds. He critiques the designative tradition associated with Hobbes, Locke, and Condillac, and develops the expressivist-hermeneutic lineage of Herder, Hamann, and Humboldt to recover language’s world-disclosing, articulatory, and creative powers. Through philosophical analysis and cross-disciplinary cases, he outlines the “full shape” of linguistic capacity as embodied, dialogical, and historically formed, reshaping debates in philosophy of mind, ethics, and social theory.

Summary Abstract: Hippias Minor (Lesser Hippias) is a Platonic dialogue featuring Socrates, the sophist Hippias, and Eudicus. Summary Abstract: This 2007 ETLA report by Torben M. Andersen, Bengt Holmström, Seppo Honkapohja, Sixten Korkman, Hans Tson Söderström, and Juhana Vartiainen defines the Nordic model as the mutually reinforcing combination of openness to globalization and collective risk sharing, documenting its past success in high employment, productivity, and social equality. It identifies mounting pressures from ageing demographics, globalization, and rising costs of welfare services due to Baumol and Wagner effects that threaten long‑run fiscal sustainability. The authors propose reforms to raise labor-force participation and effective retirement ages, maintain flexible but coordinated wage bargaining, improve public-service productivity (including selective privatization/outsourcing), clarify and cap the scope of tax‑financed entitlements, and tie pensions to longevity while preserving core risk‑sharing mechanisms.

Summary Abstract: Out of Character (2011) by David DeSteno and Piercarlo Valdesolo synthesizes social and moral psychology research to explain how the same individual can act altruistically in one context and selfishly in another. The authors propose that behavior emerges from a dynamic competition between fast, emotion-driven intuitions and slower, deliberative control, and present experiments showing how situational cues (e.g., interpersonal synchrony, experiences of awe, and time pressure) shift honesty, compassion, cheating, and moral judgment. They conclude that character is context-dependent and outline empirically grounded techniques for predicting and steering which tendencies dominate.

Title of Work: The Secret History of the Mongols
Summary Abstract: The Secret History of the Mongols, compiled circa 1240, is the oldest surviving work in the Mongolian language, recounting the life of Temüjin (Genghis Khan) and the formation of the early Mongol Empire. It covers genealogical origins, tribal politics, alliances, campaigns, laws, and customs, blending prose with speeches and verse, from mythic beginnings through Ögödei’s reign. The text survives chiefly in a later Chinese transcription with interlinear glosses and serves as a primary source for 12th–13th-century Mongol history.

Summary Abstract: Thyestes is a Roman tragedy by Seneca the Younger depicting Atreus’s revenge against his brother in the House of Atreus. Urged by the Fury and the ghost of Tantalus, Atreus feigns reconciliation, murders Thyestes’ sons, and serves their flesh at a banquet. A messenger and chorus describe the slaughter and prodigies (notably the sun’s reversal), and the play ends with Atreus revealing the deed to Thyestes.

An autobiographical chronicle, the book recounts Rakotoson’s return to Madagascar—especially Antananarivo—after years of absence, as she revisits places and opens the “armoire of memories” tied to her homeland and language. Written as reportage-like travel notes, it observes the landscapes and daily life of the “Red Island” while tracing a reconnection with personal and collective memory.

Summary Abstract: Tuesdays with Morrie is a memoir in which journalist Mitch Albom reconnects with his former Brandeis University sociology professor, Morrie Schwartz, after learning Morrie has ALS. Over fourteen Tuesday visits, Albom records their conversations about themes such as life, death, love, work, family, aging, and forgiveness. The book documents Morrie’s physical decline and the end of his life while presenting the lessons he shares during their meetings.

Summary Abstract: The Field (2018) is an installation by Patricia Piccinini comprising hard, white, hybrid plant forms that propose a speculative landscape with fluid boundaries and references to sexuality and fertility. A version in the QAGOMA collection, The Field (Planting) 2018, consists of 200 ABS and PPE plastic objects, each approximately 100 × 25 × 10 cm, with installed dimensions variable. It was exhibited in Patricia Piccinini: Curious Affection at Brisbane’s Gallery of Modern Art in 2018.

Summary Abstract: Filosofía de la liberación (1977) articulates a Latin American philosophy that begins from the lived experience and material oppression of the “Other” situated in the exteriority of Eurocentric modernity, drawing on dependency theory, liberation theology, and Levinas to critique totalizing metaphysics. Dussel proposes an analectical method and an ethics of liberation that takes the needs and claims of the oppressed as the starting point for philosophical, ethical, and political reflection. The work extends this framework to a critique of modernity and to orientations for decolonizing social, economic, and cultural structures.

Summary Abstract: Writing and Difference (1967) is a collection of Jacques Derrida’s essays from 1963–1967 that develop his critique of Western metaphysics through the concepts of writing (écriture), the trace, and the supplement. Through readings of Foucault, Levinas, Freud, Artaud, and Bataille, it interrogates assumptions of presence, origin, and structure in phenomenology and structuralism. The volume includes essays such as “Force and Signification,” “Cogito and the History of Madness,” “Violence and Metaphysics,” and “Structure, Sign, and Play in the Discourse of the Human Sciences.”

Title of Work: The Boy Who Was Raised as a Dog
Summary Abstract: A nonfiction work, it presents clinical case studies from child psychiatrist Bruce D. Perry showing how trauma, abuse, and neglect shape children’s brain development and behavior. It explains concepts such as use-dependent brain organization and the roles of attachment, regulation, and patterned sensory input in calibrating stress-response systems. The book outlines developmentally sequenced, relationship-focused interventions—formalized as the Neurosequential Model of Therapeutics—to address trauma-related dysregulation.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Charged examines how U.S. prosecutors’ charging decisions, plea bargaining, and bail practices shape case outcomes and contribute to mass incarceration. Through case studies—including a Brooklyn gun possession prosecution of a young man and a Memphis homicide case in which a young woman’s conviction was overturned for prosecutorial misconduct—it details the scope and consequences of prosecutorial discretion. It also chronicles the rise of “progressive prosecution” and reforms such as diversion, declination policies, and bail changes, and how they are reshaping local criminal justice systems.

Title of Work: The Book of Hope: A Survival Guide for Trying Times
Summary Abstract: A nonfiction work presented as a dialogue (with Douglas Abrams) in which Jane Goodall examines how to sustain hope amid crises such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and pandemics. Drawing on her life, research, and conservation efforts, she outlines four reasons for hope—human intellect, nature’s resilience, the power of young people, and the indomitable human spirit—and illustrates them with stories and case studies alongside practical actions individuals and communities can take.

Title of Work: Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right (Revised Edition)
Summary Abstract: Arlie Russell Hochschild presents a five-year ethnographic study of conservative Louisianans to examine the emotional and cultural foundations of the American right. Through interviews and case studies, she articulates a “deep story” of waiting in line for the American Dream, perceived “line cutters,” and distrust of government, even amid environmental harm in the petrochemical corridor. The revised edition includes updates reflecting the 2016 presidential election and its implications for the patterns she documents.

Title of Work: White Too Long: The Legacy of White Supremacy in American Christianity
Summary Abstract: Robert P. Jones examines the historical entanglement of white American Christianity with white supremacy, tracing its development from slavery and Reconstruction through Jim Crow to the present. Using archival history and PRRI survey data, he shows that white Christians across Protestant and Catholic traditions have been more likely than religiously unaffiliated whites to hold racist attitudes and to resist racial justice efforts. The book analyzes theological narratives such as the Lost Cause and institutional complicity within churches and proposes steps for truth-telling, repentance, and repair.

Caroline Hickman is an Executive Committee member of the Climate Psychology Alliance (CPA), contributing specialist psychological expertise on the climate and ecological crisis. Her work includes delivering talks and workshops on climate psychology and offering climate‑aware psychotherapy. Through CPA platforms she has explored why it is hard to face climate change, how to process eco‑anxiety, and provided resources focused on children and young people.

Summary Abstract: This volume collects Sigmund Freud’s clinical case histories centered on “From the History of an Infantile Neurosis” (the “Wolf Man”) alongside additional case studies. It documents Freud’s analyses of symptoms, dreams, and childhood experiences to reconstruct patients’ neuroses. Across these cases, Freud articulates key psychoanalytic concepts such as infantile sexuality, the Oedipus complex, repression, transference, and the “primal scene,” and illustrates the techniques of psychoanalytic treatment.

Title of Work: Gomō Jigi (The Meaning of Terms in the Analects and Mencius)
Summary Abstract: Gomō Jigi (1683) by Itō Jinsai is a systematic philological study that defines and clarifies key terms in the Analects (Lunyu) and Mencius (Mengzi) to recover their original meanings. Opposing Zhu Xi’s Neo-Confucian metaphysics of li, Jinsai emphasizes qi (ki), human feelings, and sincerity (makoto) as the basis of ethical practice grounded in everyday relations. The work established Jinsai’s Kogigaku (“Ancient Meanings”) approach and became a foundational text in Tokugawa Confucian scholarship.

Summary Abstract: Christian Astrology (1647) by William Lilly is a three-book English manual on astrology covering foundational doctrine, horary practice, and natal astrology. Book I introduces the astrological framework—signs, houses, aspects, essential dignities—and methods for erecting charts; Book II presents rules and case studies for judging horary questions; Book III treats nativities, including directions and revolutions. It is among the earliest comprehensive astrological textbooks published in English, illustrated with numerous example charts from 17th-century England.

Title of Work: Discernment: Reading the Signs of Daily Life
Summary Abstract: Discernment: Reading the Signs of Daily Life (2013) presents Henri J. M. Nouwen’s guidance on recognizing and responding to God’s presence and direction in everyday life. Summary Abstract: Divan-e-Wali is the collected poetry of Wali Mohammed Wali (Wali Dakhani), compiled around 1700. It primarily comprises Urdu (Rekhta) ghazals shaped by Persian prosody and imagery, exploring themes of love, longing, and Sufi devotion. The diwan’s early-18th-century circulation in North India is credited with catalyzing the rise of the Urdu ghazal tradition in Delhi.

Title of Work: Dynamic Thought — William Walker Atkinson (1916, Chicago)
Summary Abstract: Dynamic Thought, or The Law of Vibrant Energy (1906), blends contemporary scientific ideas with occult teaching to argue that the universe is alive and mind‑permeated, and that matter and force are expressions of mind. Surveying substance from atoms and corpuscles to planets, it reinterprets gravitation, cohesion, chemical affinity, heat, light, electricity, and magnetism as forms of mental attraction. The work culminates in a theory of “vital‑mental” force—Dynamic Thought—and a “Law of Vibrant Energy” that frames all motion and phenomena, including human thought and action, as manifestations of universal mind.

Title of Work: Racism without Racists: Color-Blind Racism and the Persistence of Racial Inequality in America
Summary Abstract: Eduardo Bonilla-Silva contends that in the post–Civil Rights era, racial inequality in the United States persists through a dominant color-blind ideology that obscures structural advantages for whites. Using national survey data, interviews, and focus groups, he identifies four principal frames—abstract liberalism, naturalization, cultural racism, and minimization of racism—plus characteristic rhetorical styles and storylines that rationalize inequality. The book analyzes how these discursive frames shape everyday talk and policy debates, reproducing a racialized social structure without overtly racist actors.

Title of Work: The Use of Bodies: Homo Sacer IV
Summary Abstract: Giorgio Agamben’s The Use of Bodies (Homo Sacer IV, 2014) concludes the Homo Sacer project by investigating “use” (chresis) as the relation linking bodies, life, and law under sovereignty. Drawing on Aristotle, Roman law, Stoicism, early Christian and monastic rules, and modern theory, it reconstructs a genealogy of use, property, and oikonomia/government. The book articulates “form-of-life” and “inoperativity” to describe ethical-political configurations in which life and its form are inseparable and juridical apparatuses can be deactivated.

Title of Work: The Digital Republic: On Freedom and Democracy in the 21st Century
Summary Abstract: Jamie Susskind examines how digital technologies and dominant online platforms concentrate power and reshape freedom and democratic life. He advances a republican framework for the digital age aimed at preventing arbitrary power through accountability, contestability, and the rule of law. The book proposes legal and institutional reforms—including platform and algorithm regulation, transparency and due-process duties, competition and interoperability measures, and new public authorities—to secure rights and democratic governance in the digital sphere.

Summary Abstract: Using de-identified U.S. tax records linked across generations for birth cohorts 1940–1984, this study measures absolute income mobility as the share of children whose household income exceeds their parents’ around age 30. It finds that this rate fell from roughly 90% for the 1940 cohort to about 50% for children born in the 1980s, with declines across the income distribution and largest for middle-class families. Counterfactual analyses show that slower aggregate growth accounts for only a minority of the decline, whereas increased inequality is the primary driver: restoring broadly shared growth as in the mid-20th century would raise absolute mobility to around 80%, versus about 62% under higher growth alone.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: Published posthumously in 1978, The Life of the Mind examines the fundamental mental activities of Thinking and Willing, with a planned third part on Judging left unfinished. Arendt analyzes thinking as an inner dialogue distinct from knowing and willing as the experience of freedom and inner conflict, drawing on sources from Plato and Aristotle to Augustine, Kant, and Nietzsche. The work investigates how these activities condition conscience, responsibility, and the capacity to judge in human affairs.

Summary Abstract: Breast Stories (1997) presents three short stories by Mahasweta Devi—Draupadi, Breast-Giver, and Behind the Bodice—translated and introduced with notes by Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak. The volume depicts, respectively, a tribal woman guerrilla subjected to custodial sexual violence (Dopdi), a professional wet nurse whose lactation is treated as labor (Jashoda), and a migrant worker whose photographed body precipitates police brutality (Gangor). Spivak’s critical apparatus situates the texts within histories of class, caste, gender, the state, and subalternity.

Title of Work: Hip-Hop Japan: Rap and the Paths of Cultural Globalization
Summary Abstract: An ethnographic study of Japan’s hip-hop scene, the book examines how global cultural forms are re-created through local “genba” (on-site) spaces such as clubs, studios, and media networks. Drawing on fieldwork in Tokyo, Condry traces interactions among artists, fans, and industry intermediaries to map flows between U.S. and Japanese hip-hop. It documents how Japanese rappers negotiate language, authenticity, race, and commerce, situating hip-hop’s localization within broader processes of cultural globalization.

Title of Work: If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler
Summary Abstract: Italo Calvino’s 1979 novel is narrated in the second person and follows “the Reader” attempting to read a book titled If on a winter’s night a traveler. Because of printing errors and a literary fraud involving a translator, the Reader repeatedly receives only the opening chapters of ten different novels and, alongside “the Other Reader” Ludmilla, searches for the continuations. The book alternates between chapters addressing the Reader and the embedded first chapters, concluding with the Reader marrying Ludmilla and settling to finish the book.

Summary Abstract: Memories, Dreams, Reflections is Carl Gustav Jung’s autobiographical self-portrait, compiled with Aniela Jaffé and published posthumously in 1962. It traces his childhood, medical training, clinical work, and the emergence of analytical psychology, including his break with Sigmund Freud. Through accounts of dreams, visions, travels, and the building of his Bollingen Tower, Jung presents key ideas such as the collective unconscious, archetypes, and individuation in the context of his life.

Summary Abstract: Paul Tough examines how the U.S. higher education system—especially admissions, standardized testing, and financial aid—shapes who gets into college and who succeeds there. Title of Work: The Mabinogion (translations by Jeffrey Gantz, Sioned Davies, Patrick K. Ford, and/or Lady Charlotte Guest
Summary Abstract: The Mabinogion is a collection of Middle Welsh prose tales compiled circa the 12th–13th centuries, blending mythic, folkloric, and Arthurian material. It comprises the Four Branches of the Mabinogi (Pwyll, Branwen, Manawydan, Math), three romances (Owein, Peredur, Geraint), and native tales such as Culhwch and Olwen, Lludd and Llefelys, The Dream of Macsen Wledig, and The Dream of Rhonabwy. The narratives depict interactions among mortals, nobles, and otherworldly beings across Wales and Annwn, centering on sovereignty, kinship obligations, enchantment, and heroic quests.

Title of Work: Cultural Encounters on China's Ethnic Frontiers
Summary Abstract: Edited by Stevan Harrell, this collection examines how interactions between the Han majority and minority minzu have shaped ethnic identities across China’s frontiers through state “civilizing projects” and local responses, situating these processes within Chinese nation-building. Part I analyzes scholarly and official discourses on groups such as the Naxi, Yi, Miao, and Manchus, while Part II traces historical dynamics—including millenarian and Christian movements, urban ethnic education, and the elevation of figures like Chinggis Khan—among Mongols and Tai/Dai-Lue. Drawing on historical sources and direct field research, the volume presents comparative case studies of colonialism, imperialism, and identity formation in China.

Summary Abstract: This work presents a concise account of the Zend Avesta, the sacred corpus of Zoroastrian scripture comprising hymns, liturgies, and doctrinal texts in the Avestan language. It explains the role of Magian (Magi) priests in composing, preserving, and ritually transmitting these materials through oral recitation and later redaction. Title of Work: Gendered Paradoxes: Educating Jordanian Women in Nation, Faith, and Progress
Summary Abstract: An ethnographic study of al-Khatwa Secondary School for Girls in Jordan, the book analyzes how schooling shapes and negotiates nationalism, piety, and gendered respectability in students’ daily lives. Framing the World Bank’s “gender paradox” designation for Jordan, Adely argues that women’s education is valued for moral, national, and familial projects rather than primarily for labor-market outcomes. Published in 2012, it contributes to Middle East anthropology and comparative education by documenting students’ and families’ perspectives on schooling, work, and development.

Summary Abstract: Shaun Gallagher advances an enactivist account of mind that conceives cognition as embodied, embedded, and enacted through organism–environment interaction. Through a series of conceptual interventions, he critiques internalist, representational models and develops enactivist alternatives across topics including perception and action, agency and selfhood, social cognition, and affect, integrating phenomenology with findings from cognitive science and neuroscience. The book shows how enactive principles reframe explanations of cognitive processes and guide empirical research.

Summary Abstract: Six Thinking Hats (1985) by Edward de Bono presents a parallel thinking framework that assigns six color-coded hats to distinct modes: White (information), Red (feelings/intuition), Black (caution/risks), Yellow (benefits), Green (creativity), and Blue (process/control). The method structures individual and group discussions by having participants adopt one hat at a time to focus on a single thinking mode. The book outlines procedures and examples for applying the hats in meetings, decision-making, and problem solving.

Title of Work: Economics Unmasked: From Power and Greed to Compassion and the Common Good (w/ Philip B. Smith)
Author Full Name: Manfred Max-Neef w/ Philip B. Smith
Summary Abstract: This book critiques mainstream, growth-centered economics, arguing that power, greed, and financialization foster inequality and ecological degradation. Drawing on systems thinking and Max-Neef’s Human Scale Development, the authors link financial, energy, climate, and biodiversity crises and present the “threshold hypothesis” that beyond a point GDP growth reduces quality of life. They outline a reoriented economics grounded in ethical principles, human needs, and ecological limits, emphasizing relocalization, democratic participation, and stewardship of the commons.

Title of Work: The Right Kind of Wrong: The Science of Failing Well
Summary Abstract: Amy Edmondson categorizes failures into three types—basic (preventable), complex (arising from interdependencies), and intelligent (hypothesis-driven at the frontier of knowledge)—and argues that only intelligent failures should be encouraged. Grounded in research on psychological safety and organizational learning, the book provides tools to reduce preventable errors, navigate complexity, and design small, disciplined experiments to learn faster. Using cases from healthcare, business, and other domains, it details practices like framing work as learning, inviting voice, and rapid testing to help individuals and teams fail well and improve performance.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Title of Work: The Book of Laughter and Forgetting
Summary Abstract: The Book of Laughter and Forgetting (1979) is a novel in seven interlinked parts that blends narrative, essay, and autobiographical elements. Set largely in post-1968 Czechoslovakia and in exile, it follows characters such as Mirek and Tamina to examine political repression, personal memory, and erasure. Recurring motifs—laughter, forgetting, and manipulated history (including the erasure of a figure from a photograph)—connect episodes about love, exile, and the struggle to preserve the past.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Two Years Before the Mast is Richard Henry Dana Jr.’s first-person account of his 1834–1836 service as a common sailor, leaving Harvard to ship from Boston to the California coast in the hide trade aboard the brig Pilgrim and returning on the ship Alert. It details rounding Cape Horn, shipboard routines and discipline, and the process of collecting, curing, and loading cattle hides. Dana also records conditions and commerce in Mexican-era Alta California, including ports such as San Diego, San Pedro, Santa Barbara, and Monterey.

Title of Work: The Expanding Circle: Ethics and Sociobiology
Summary Abstract: Peter Singer examines how evolutionary biology, particularly sociobiology, explains the origins of altruism and moral sentiments. He argues that human moral concern has historically widened from kin and tribe to all humans and nonhuman animals—an “expanding circle” driven by rational impartiality. The book analyzes mechanisms such as kin selection and reciprocal altruism while contending that ethical reasoning can extend beyond our biological predispositions. It links evolutionary accounts of behavior to the universalization characteristic of ethical thought.

Title of Work: My First Summer in the Sierra
Summary Abstract: My First Summer in the Sierra (1911) presents John Muir’s edited journal from the summer of 1869, when he worked as a sheepherder in California’s Sierra Nevada near Yosemite. Organized as dated field notes from June to September, it records his routes and camp life and describes the region’s geology, glacial landforms, forests, wildflowers, wildlife, and weather. The work recounts excursions into the high country and detailed observations of the species and landscapes he encountered.

Summary Abstract: David Emerald’s book presents The Empowerment Dynamic (TED) as an alternative to the Dreaded Drama Triangle, reframing the roles of Victim, Persecutor, and Rescuer into Creator, Challenger, and Coach. It explains shifting from a problem-focused, victim orientation to an outcome-focused, creator orientation to increase personal accountability and improve relationships. Through a coaching parable, it details practices like clarifying desired outcomes, taking “Baby Steps,” and using “Dynamic Tension” to guide effective action.

Summary Abstract: Bennet presents a concise introduction to C. G. Jung’s psychology, tracing the background and development of Jung’s thinking and outlining his personality classifications. He surveys the components of personality and the unconscious, Jung’s views on dreams and active imagination, and the role of alchemical symbolism and philosophy in Jung’s system. The book also summarizes Jung’s approach to psychotherapy and his relationship to Freud, and includes bibliographical references and an index.

Summary Abstract: Thomas Berry’s 1988 collection of essays presents a new cosmological narrative to realign human culture with Earth’s ecological processes. He diagnoses the ecological crisis as arising from a dysfunctional human–Earth relationship and characterizes the universe as a “communion of subjects, not a collection of objects.” The book outlines implications for education, religion, ethics, economics, and law to reshape institutions toward sustaining the Earth community.

Title of Work: The Forest Unseen: A Year’s Watch in Nature

The chapters integrate field notes with explanations of broader scientific context, including geology, climate, and human influences on the forest system.

Summary Abstract: The American Clock is a 1980 play by Arthur Miller that dramatizes the impact of the Great Depression on a middle-class New York family, the Baums, seen largely through the son Lee. Structured as a series of vignettes and monologues inspired by oral histories, it juxtaposes the family’s declining fortunes with broader snapshots of unemployment, bank failures, and social unrest. Summary Abstract: Carlo Petrini’s Terra Madre outlines the concept and practice of the Terra Madre network, presenting a framework for sustainable food communities and closer relationships between small-scale producers and consumers. It describes the network as a global alliance of food communities initiated by Slow Food in 2004, focused on biodiversity, ecological agriculture, and local economies. Petrini proposes decentralized, community-based approaches to reorganize the food system, emphasizing fair pricing and local alliances between producers and consumers to build sustainable food communities.

Title of Work: Sufi Path of Love: The Spiritual Teachings of Rumi
Summary Abstract: William C. Chittick presents a systematic exposition of Jalal al-Din Rumi’s Sufi teachings, drawing primarily on translations from the Mathnawi and the Divan-e Shams. The book organizes Rumi’s doctrine around themes such as divine love, the stages of the spiritual path, annihilation (fana) and subsistence (baqa), the self and the Perfect Man, knowledge and practice, and the role of Shams-i Tabrizi, relating them to Qur’anic and Hadith sources. It compiles topic-based excerpts with explanations of key terms to clarify Rumi’s metaphysics, ethics, and devotional practice.

Summary Abstract: Salman Rushdie’s novel follows Gibreel Farishta, a Bollywood star, and Saladin Chamcha, a voice actor, who survive the midair explosion of their airliner over the English Channel and are transformed—Gibreel into an angelic figure and Saladin into a demonic one. In London, Saladin endures arrest and humiliation while Gibreel is beset by visionary dreams, setting their diverging paths in motion. Gibreel’s dreams frame embedded tales, including a reimagined prophet called Mahound, a village’s sea-crossing led by Ayesha, and a brothel whose prostitutes assume the names of a prophet’s wives.

Title of Work: The Universal Christ: How a Forgotten Reality Can Change Everything We See, Hope For, and Believe
Summary Abstract: Richard Rohr argues that “Christ” names a universal, cosmic presence of God active in all creation from the beginning, distinct yet inseparable from the historical person of Jesus of Nazareth. He traces this theme through Scripture, early Christian tradition, mystics, and dialogue with science to present Christ as the divine pattern (Logos) in whom everything holds together. The book outlines implications for Christian spirituality and practice, including contemplation, sacrament, ethics, inclusion, and seeing divine presence in the natural world and daily life.

Summary Abstract: Tim Urban analyzes how societies think and malfunction, introducing a model of “high‑rung” versus “low‑rung” thinking to explain polarization, bad incentives, and tribal dynamics. Summary Abstract: Aminata Traoré examines the social, cultural, and economic impacts of neoliberal globalization and structural adjustment programs on West African societies, focusing on Mali. She documents how policies driven by the IMF, World Bank, and donor governments restructure local economies and governance, weakening social cohesion and marginalizing citizens’ agency. Summary Abstract: Edward Burnett Tylor’s Primitive Culture (1871) articulates an early anthropological definition of culture as a complex whole comprising knowledge, belief, art, morals, law, custom, and other acquired capabilities. Employing a comparative method, Tylor outlines a unilinear model of cultural evolution and the doctrine of “survivals,” in which remnants of earlier stages persist in later societies. He proposes animism—the belief in spiritual beings—as the minimal definition and historical origin of religion, tracing the development of mythology, philosophy, language, art, and social institutions across societies.

Summary Abstract: Mayumi Inaba’s memoir chronicles her 20-year relationship with her cat, Mii, beginning with the stray’s arrival by Tokyo’s Tamagawa River in 1977 and depicting their daily life together. Originally published in Japan in 1999, Mornings Without Mii follows their companionship across the ensuing decades.

Set in a remote stretch of the Adirondack Mountains, the wealthy Van Laar family controls a vast forest tract reserved for their estate and a children’s summer camp, while a mill closure leaves the nearby town economically dependent on them. After a child disappears on the property and, years later, another goes missing, a state police investigation—assisted by an inexperienced female investigator—uncovers long-buried secrets.

Summary Abstract: Moral Uncertainty develops a decision-theoretic framework for how to act when uncertain which moral theory is correct, representing credences over competing theories. The book analyzes formal properties, addresses key objections, and illustrates implications for practical ethical decision-making and policy.

Title of Work: From Bacteria to Bach and Back
Summary Abstract: Daniel Dennett presents a naturalistic account of how human minds and culture emerge, tracing a continuum from biological evolution to cultural evolution. He argues that natural selection yields “competence without comprehension,” while memes—especially language—install thinking tools that scaffold genuine understanding and enable cumulative cultural design. Integrating the intentional stance, he explains consciousness and meaning as emergent products of design-without-a-designer processes with implications for AI and human cognition.

Summary Abstract: Existential Physics (2022) examines what contemporary physics can and cannot say about foundational questions such as free will, consciousness, time, causality, and the origin and fate of the universe. Drawing on quantum mechanics, relativity, thermodynamics, and cosmology, it distinguishes empirically supported results from speculative proposals like the multiverse, string theory, and simulation arguments. The book delineates the scope and limits of scientific inference about meaning and existence while addressing common misconceptions about current theories.

Summary Abstract: Douglas Hofstadter’s 1979 book, Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid, examines structural parallels among mathematical logic, visual art, and music through Kurt Gödel’s incompleteness theorems, M. C. Escher’s prints, and J. S. Bach’s compositions. It develops the ideas of recursion, self-reference, formal systems, and “strange loops” to analyze how systems can encode and refer to themselves and the limits that result. The exposition interleaves dialogues, puzzles, and essays, linking the Austrian logician Gödel’s results to broader cross-disciplinary themes in representation and cognition.

Through case studies of Indiana’s automated welfare eligibility system, Los Angeles’s homeless services coordinated entry/VI-SPDAT, and Allegheny County, Pennsylvania’s child-welfare risk scoring tool, the book documents how these systems structure access to benefits, expand surveillance, and reproduce long-standing patterns of social control.

Title of Work: The Diversity Bonus: How Great Teams Pay Off
Summary Abstract: Scott Page (2017) analyzes how cognitive diversity in teams produces measurable “diversity bonuses” in problem solving, prediction, and innovation. Through formal models, simulations, and empirical cases (such as forecasting tournaments, data-science ensembles, and organizational studies), he shows that complementary perspectives, heuristics, interpretations, and models outperform homogeneous high-ability groups. The book specifies that these bonuses arise mainly for complex, nonroutine tasks and explains how linking identity diversity to cognitive diversity and fostering inclusion enables teams to capture the gains.

Summary Abstract: After a terrorist attack devastates San Francisco, teen hacker Marcus Yallow is detained and interrogated by the Department of Homeland Security before being released under surveillance. He organizes an encrypted underground network on repurposed game hardware to document state abuses and coordinate civil disobedience with his friends. Their campaign exposes unlawful detentions and pervasive surveillance, triggering public backlash and official accountability.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Scientific / Technological – Modern science, Positivism, Evolutionary theory, Systems theory, Cybernetics"

Summary Abstract: The book advances a theory of psychoanalysis that centers the human impulse to question, showing how Freud’s free associative method yields answers that in turn elicit further questions. Using transcripts of analytic sessions with parallel commentaries, Bollas highlights listening to the free associative “logic of sequence” and maintaining evenly suspended attention so the analyst’s unconscious can catch the drift of the patient’s unconscious. He argues that fostering further questioning can be more useful than premature interpretation, framing analysis as driven by a self-sustaining interrogative drive.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Summary Abstract: The Inward Journey (1961) is a collection of brief meditations by Howard Thurman on the interior life and the human spirit’s search for God. Organized around themes such as the quests for meaning, understanding, fulfillment, love, peace, and God, it culminates with reflections on Psalm 139.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Mystical / Esoteric – Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Kabbalah, Sufism, Alchemy, Western Esotericism"

Summary Abstract: Philippe Descola’s Beyond Nature and Culture (2005) argues that the nature/culture divide is not universal and advances a comparative “anthropology of nature.” He identifies four ontological regimes—animism, totemism, analogism, and naturalism—defined by patterns of continuity or discontinuity in interiority (mind/subjectivity) and physicality (body/materiality). Drawing on ethnographic and historical cases from Amazonia and other regions, the book analyzes how these schemas organize classification, personhood, and relations between humans and nonhumans.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism","Postmodern / Critical – Deconstruction, Feminism, Postcolonial, Decolonial, Critical Theory"

Summary Abstract: Set in 1947 Brooklyn, the novel is narrated by Stingo, a young Southerner who befriends Sophie Zawistowska, a Polish Catholic survivor of Auschwitz, and her lover Nathan Landau, who suffers from severe mental illness. Through their relationship, Sophie recounts her arrest, imprisonment, and the coerced decision she was forced to make between her two children upon arrival at the camp. The narrative culminates in Sophie and Nathan’s double suicide, which Stingo survives to record.

The Systems View of Life synthesizes systems thinking, complexity science, autopoiesis, and network theory to propose an integrated framework for understanding biological, cognitive, social, and ecological phenomena. It traces the shift from mechanistic to systemic paradigms and explicates core concepts such as emergence, self-organization, cognition as a process of life, and embodiment across levels of organization. The book applies this framework to health, management, economics, environmental sustainability, education, and public policy.

Summary Abstract: A Walk in the Woods (1998) is Bill Bryson’s nonfiction account of attempting to hike the Appalachian Trail with his friend Stephen Katz. It follows their preparations and section-hikes across parts of the trail, the logistical and physical challenges they face, and their decision not to complete the full route. Interwoven chapters present the trail’s history, geology, flora and fauna, conservation concerns, and the practices of agencies that manage it.

Title of Work: The Three-Cornered Hat and Other Stories
Summary Abstract: Published in 1874, The Three-Cornered Hat and Other Stories centers on Alarcón’s Andalusian tale of a corregidor who attempts to seduce a miller’s wife and is outwitted through a chain of disguises and mistaken identities. The novella satirizes abuses of local authority and the honor code in 19th-century Spain. The volume’s additional stories likewise depict everyday Spanish life, morality, and superstition through concise narrative episodes.

Summary Abstract: Mike Savage examines how the resurgence of extreme economic inequality concentrates assets among a narrowing elite and revives historical patterns of empire, dynastic power, ethnic division, and metropolitan dominance. He argues that severe wealth inequality fractures social bonds and destabilizes liberal democratic nation-states by intensifying cultural, social, and political conflicts. Drawing on thinkers including Marx, Bourdieu, and Piketty, Savage situates present-day wealth concentration within a long historical arc to show how the burdens of the past shape current social order.

Summary Abstract: Robert Louis Stevenson’s 1889 novel follows the destructive feud between Scottish brothers James (the Master of Ballantrae) and Henry Durie, set in motion during the 1745 Jacobite rising when a coin toss sends James to the rebel cause. Narrated chiefly by the estate steward Ephraim Mackellar, with an interpolated memoir by the Irish adventurer Francis Burke, the story traces James’s presumed death, survival, and years of ruthless wandering before his return to torment Henry. Their conflict drains the Durrisdeer estate and culminates in a fatal confrontation in the American wilderness.

Summary Abstract: The book analyzes the implications of rising life expectancy for individuals, employers, and governments, arguing that the traditional education–work–retirement model is giving way to multi-stage lives with multiple careers, transitions, and periods of reskilling. Through cohort-based scenarios, it models how people born in different decades might structure longer working lives and addresses the financial planning, savings, pension, and policy adjustments required. It emphasizes building intangible assets—productive, vitality, and transformational assets such as skills, health, relationships, and identity—to sustain income and well-being across longer lifespans.

Title of Work: Ibn Fadlān and the Land of Darkness: Arab Travellers in the Far North
Summary Abstract: Ibn Fadlān’s 922 Risāla recounts his mission as an envoy of the Abbasid caliph to the Volga Bulghar ruler, offering a firsthand record of travel in the Eurasian steppe and forest zone. He describes the embassy’s religious and diplomatic aims—delivering instruction in Islamic practice and gifts—alongside trade networks and the severe climate along the Volga. The account provides detailed ethnographic observations of the Oghuz, Bashkirs, Volga Bulgars, and the Rus, including the famous description of a Rus chieftain’s ship burial and slave-girl sacrifice.

Title of Work: Customary Law and Modern Justice in Botswana
Summary Abstract: This work examines Botswana’s dual legal system—Roman-Dutch-influenced common law alongside customary law—and how this structure shapes interactions between modern courts and customary tribunals. It outlines the jurisdiction and reach of customary courts, which number over 500 nationwide, and the statutory framework governing them, including the Customary Courts Act and the Customary Law Act of 1969. It analyzes how courts reconcile customary norms with constitutional rights, documenting judicial approaches to limitations and adaptations in contemporary practice.

Title of Work (AI check): 239 Days: 'Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey in America
Summary Abstract: This work recounts ‘Abdu’l-Bahá’s 1912 tour across the United States (with a brief visit to Canada), detailing his itinerary, meetings, and public addresses to civic, academic, and religious audiences. It presents the themes he emphasized—universal peace, racial unity, the equality of women and men, the harmony of science and religion, and economic justice—delivered in major cities such as New York, Washington, D.C., Chicago, Boston, and San Francisco.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Abrahamic – Judaism, Christianity, Islam","Modern Western Secular – Enlightenment Rationalism, Liberalism, Humanism"

Title of Work (AI check): The Mind of a Mnemonist: A Little Book about a Vast Memory (Маленькая книжка о большой памяти: ум мнемониста)
Canonical/Scholarly Translation (Best Ov: Lynn Solotaroff, The Mind of a Mnemonist: A Little Book about a Vast Memory, 1968
Summary Abstract: A.R. Luria’s The Mind of a Mnemonist (1968) is a longitudinal neuropsychological case study of “S.,” a professional mnemonist whose exceptional, durable recall was mediated by vivid synesthetic imagery and spatial schemas. Through controlled tests over many years, Luria documents S.’s precise retention of extensive lists, numbers, and texts across long intervals. The work also records the costs of this profile—difficulty forgetting, abstracting, and interpreting metaphorical language—and analyzes the relations among memory, perception, and language.

Title of Work (AI check): The Hymns of the Rigveda (ऋग्वेद)
Author Full Name: (Anonymous, Vedic Rishis), translation by Ralph T.H. Griffith
Author Full Name (AI Check): Anonymous, Vedic Rishis, translation by Ralph T.H. Griffith
Canonical/Scholarly Translation (Best Ov: Stephanie W. Jamison and Joel P. Brereton, The Rigveda: The Earliest Religious Poetry of India, 2014
Summary Abstract: The Rig Veda is a collection of 1,028 Vedic Sanskrit hymns (suktas) arranged in ten mandalas, composed c. 1500–1200 BCE and preserved orally. The hymns invoke deities such as Agni, Indra, Soma, Varuna, Mitra, and Ushas, celebrate sacrifices and delineate ritual practice, and articulate cosmological and philosophical themes, including creation hymns like the Purusha Sukta (10.90) and Nasadiya Sukta (10.129). Ralph T. H. Griffith’s translation renders this corpus into English.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh","Himalayan – Tibet, Bhutan, Nepal"

Diaspora / Transcultural Status: Local / Rooted (tightly bound to one place)

Title of Work (AI check): Bhagavata Purana (भागवतपुराण)
Summary Abstract: The Bhagavata Purana is a Sanskrit Purana, traditionally ascribed to Vyasa but of uncertain authorship, likely compiled c. 800–1000 CE, comprising 12 skandhas (cantos) and about 18,000 verses framed as the sage Shuka narrating to King Parikshit. It presents Vaishnava theology centered on devotion (bhakti) to Vishnu/Krishna, interweaving cosmology, genealogies, philosophy, and ritual, with extensive narratives of Vishnu’s avatars—especially Krishna’s childhood and youth in the Tenth Skandha—and episodes such as those of Prahlada and Dhruva. It expounds disciplines of devotion, meditation, and knowledge, integrating Vedantic concepts with a theistic focus on Bhagavan.
Tradition / Lineage (Canon-level streams: "Indic – Hinduism, Vedānta, Upanishadic, Vedic, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Yoga"
Geographic Context (Place of composition: "South Asia – India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh",Global / Transcultural
SD Contraindication (allergic reaction): May trigger Green’s allergy to hierarchy/patriarchy and exclusive theism; Orange’s allergy to mythic cosmology, miracles, and devotional surrender over rational autonomy; Blue’s allergy to the erotic ambiguity of Krishna’s rasa-lila; and Red’s allergy to obedience and self-effacement before divine authority.

Title of Work: The Interior Landscape: Love Poems from a Classical Tamil Anthology (Psychological Commentary)
Canonical/Scholarly Translation (Best Ov: A. K. Ramanujan, The Interior Landscape: Love Poems from a Classical Tamil Anthology, 1967
Summary Abstract: A.K. Ramanujan’s volume presents English translations of classical Tamil Sangam love poems from a single anthology, accompanied by a psychological commentary. It explicates akam (interior) poetics, including speakers, situations, and the five landscape (thinai) conventions that link emotion, setting, and time. The 2017 edition reproduces his translations with contextual notes that illuminate the cultural, linguistic, and literary frameworks of the poems.

Title of Work: The Wind Will Carry Us: Conversations on Cinema and Poetry (Final Work)

Summary Abstract: An 89-minute recorded conversation between Abbas Kiarostami and critic Richard Peña, the program discusses Kiarostami’s approach to cinema and its relationship to poetry, presented in conjunction with The Wind Will Carry Us. Recorded in 2014 and made available in 2018 alongside The Wind Will Carry Us on Cohen Media’s Amazon channel, it features Kiarostami reflecting on his methods, influences, and key films.
